Tommy Wiseau definitely delivers a memorable performance... no doubt about that.

Unfortunately, when Wiseau isn't on screen the movie is pretty boring. The camera work and other actors are surprisingly decent for the most part so there isn't a great deal to enjoy while waiting for The Legend to get back.

So unless you plan on getting high or hammered for the night don't attempt to watch the entire 99-minute movie as I did. Instead just Youtube it. You'll get the full Wiseau Experience, but in 1/10th the time.

P.S. If you are wondering why I said this isn't close to being the worst movie of all time... its because this kind of stuff airs all the time on Cinemax (soft-core late night movies).

review_title: Good but in a very bad way
review_detailed_main: This 2003 film by Tommy Wiseau has become notorious for its low production values, poor acting, and nonsensical plot. Despite its many flaws, "The Room" has developed a cult following and is often viewed as a prime example of what not to do when making a movie. The film's unintentionally hilarious dialogue and bizarre character moments make it a fascinating watch for those interested in bad cinema or those who enjoy that nasty "so bad that it somehow becomes good" feeling. "The Room" is a unique viewing experience that should be enjoyed with an open mind and a willingness to laugh at its absurdities.

review_title: The Room: A cult film by mistake
review_detailed_main:
The Room is a 99 minute "drama" film entirely created by bizarre director Tommy Wiseau, an American, French accented, person who fails completely at making any valid point whatsoever on his interviews, comments, dialogs, or the movie itself. Asumming that he is in fact American, you can pretty much judge from first appearances that Wiseau is one of the worst English speakers ever. He doesn't understand the basic concepts of spelling and syntaxes, making him appear like a retarded grown man, or a confused teenager trapped in Ozzy Osbourne's body.

Apart from that, reviewing this movie is almost unnecessarily, because there's nothing to debate, there's nothing in this film to be criticized or explained. Anyone with 1% of movie culture can predict from the first 2 minutes that this is one of the poorest intentions of making a decent film. The cast, the crew, the editing, the music, the direction, the landscaping... it's just ridiculous. It doesn't make any sense at all, and that's why it's a funny and distracting film. Because every character or line on the film borders stupidity and non-sense. The hole concept of dramatic relationships and social problems becomes an artificial plot that fails epically at displaying any kind of emotion.

Veredict: 30% - WATCH ONLINE The Room serves as a perfect Clase-B comedy for weekends. Watch it with your friends, or your couple. You'll laugh your a** off many times.

review_title: Very difficult to rate this one
review_detailed_main: If rating was based on how enjoyable it is, then it's a 7/10. However that enjoyment is due to how big of a dumpster fire this movie is. Despite what Tommy said later on, we can clearly see from its release that it is not intended to be a self aware comedy. I would highly recommend this terrible movie.

So bad that the makers of this film could not have been serious. Not hilarious enough that they could've been trying to be funny.

Same holds true for some of the reviews. Attempts to find symbolism in the football tossing, tuxedos, repetitious sex scenes, etc are so ridiculous that they seem like they must be meant as a joke. Unfortunately, I think some of these reviewers are serious and are reading deeper meaning into the parts of the movie that are so bad that their existence can only be explained by a level of thinking most people aren't capable of. Sadly, this isn't a higher level of thinking but rather some sub-level.

However, some of the reviews are clearly meant to be tongue in cheek and are truly the only entertaining thing to come from this film.

review_title: still better anything the asylum movies
review_detailed_main: Tommy wiseau is a great man. this movie might be awful but compared to the stuff the asylum makes this is a masterpiece

review_title: Today's lesson: bad movie, fun audience
review_detailed_main: This is a case where the movie is just awful. Nothing good can be said by a sensible intelligent person about this film, period. That said, what the 10 star young people seem to rave about is the "experience" part of the screening. As "Rocky Horror" did years ago, "The Room" has created a cult following of young people (mostly) who go to the film to make fun of the corny dialogue and silly premises. As with any "experience" film, the fun is that most of the audience has already seen the movie. They shout out the dialogue and give appropriate groans when the dialogue is exceptionally bad (which is almost always the case). If that is what you crave - a social interactive film experience - then "The Room" is your kind of movie. It has nothing else to offer... really. It is not an independent classic. It is not the great insight of a film genius. It is not the latest trend in cinema (although it closely resembles aspects of reality television). And, it is not a good movie. It is a very, very bad movie. But the experience is fun. Thus ended the lesson.

I only need to say two words: TOMMY WISEAU. He really might be the best director, producer, writer, and actor of all time. Dude can do it all. Dude wrote some of the best characters we've ever seen in film. Mark, Denny, Chris R, Peter, Lisa, Lisa's Mom, the list keeps going on. 10/10 go watch it if you haven't.

review_title: I bought the Blu-ray of The Room cause it's hard to find elsewhere, I kinda like it
review_detailed_main: It's made as if it's a porno which is probably why it got so much hate, the acting is so awful! I don't know what to think of the movie except I wanted to see The Room before I watch Disaster Artist which basically makes fun of this whacky movie. I can't believe the dialogue it seems so off yet I love cheesy films. Tommy Wiseau is kinda awesome for making such a bold mess!

This movie is worth a watch. It's idiotic and stupid and I've never seen ANYTHING so littered with plot holes, but it's hilarious!! My friend and I went to go see this movie in a theater with a lot of other fans and honestly, it was the commentary that made the movie so funny. I mean it was so stupid, everyone was laughing at it. The characters all have NO motivation WHATSOEVER for ANY of their actions, which makes it look like they all were just making it up as they went along. You will never be so confused at the same time as being amused. It is that kind of movie.

Honestly? You have to see it to believe it.

So, what I took away from this film regarding the plot is this. Johnny is getting married to his girlfriend Lisa, yet she doesn't love him anymore, she has fallen for his best friend Mark. We know they are best friends because every time Mark and Lisa have sex, he says he shouldn't because he's Johnny's best friend, then he proceeds to have sex with Lisa. Everything comes to a climactic halt at Johnny's birthday party and the lies get unraveled.

So, for those of you not familiar with the film, let me give you a bit of information regarding the production and the final film itself.

Most of the dialogue had to be dubbed, mostly for the lead actor (who is also the writer, director, producer) and most of it is out of sync. All of the cast, never acted before. The actor who plays Mark agreed to play the role 72 hours before filming began. The actor who played Peter, quit the production half way, so a new character was written and given all of Peter's lines. This character is never named, or explained who he is.

Now let's look at the subplots, events that happen in the film and the impact they have on the story.

Lisa and her mother are discussing the party for Johnny, when Lisa's mother out of the blue says this: "I got the results of the test back. I definitely have breast cancer." "Oh, you'll be fine" was the response from the daughter. The cancer is never spoken of again. One character shaves his beard and other characters decide to dedicate full conversations to it (to fill up time?). Characters are wearing tuxes and then decide to play some football in the middle of the street. I must have missed why they were wearing the tuxes, wedding rehearsal? Characters randomly drop by the house to see if Johnny or Lisa is home, it doesn't matter if they are or not, they leave a minute later and tell the person who answered the door to tell the person they said hi. Denny, a young boy that Johnny helped get a place and paid for, owes a drug dealer some money. After Johnny and Mark take care of the drug dealer, this is never mentioned again. I have no idea what happened to the drug dealer. Denny also apparently wants to watch Lisa and Johnny have sex. Characters missing halfway through, unexplained. The list goes on and on.

The first 20 minutes, there are four sex scenes. One of which uses the same shots from the previous sex scene. One couple decide to go into Johnny and Lisa's house to have sex, the don't live there, but they have easy access. Tommy Wiseau, the creator of the film, claims to have intentionally made a black comedy, this is BS. The film was clearly trying to be a serious drama and it fails at that. The acting, is well, terrible. The mother seemed to be the only one 'trying'. Well, maybe Wiseau was trying, I couldn't tell. His most emotional scene was his tantrum at the end, throwing things around and tearing the house apart. He looked like he was sleepwalking while he was doing it.

I suggest playing a drinking game while watching this, with friends, not alone. Take a shot every time someone says "I don't want to talk about it", anytime Johnny laughs for no reason, anytime you see a football, anytime roses make an appearance, anytime someone says future wife/husband and of course, anytime something inexplicable happens. You'll be wasted within the first ten minutes.

I don't hate the film, I adore it for the absurdity. He tried, failed and is now riding the failing success to the top. The film is considered a cult classic. The 'Citizen Kane' of bad movies and Wiseau is using that to his advantage, smart move. Had he tried to defend the movie, it would have turned into a Showgirls. I wish someone had given me 6 million dollars to make a movie. I would have turned something in better than this. The guy didn't know the difference between 35mm and digital, so he filmed the movie with both cameras side by side. Interesting way to do things, but not showing confidence in your actors there. At least one of them knew what kind of movie it was and split before the film was finished. I would even make a better alley way set.

I don't really know what to rate it.

A terrible movie, only made painfully funny given the horrid script and acting.

There are moments in this movie which defy explanation. Give the oddity of Wiseau, you have to wonder if you a watching some strange insight into the mind of this man, or if he might just be plain f'd. The love scenes are some of the most difficult viewing ever put to DVD. And the rampage of Johnny is just so staged. Football seems to be everywhere for no reason. Lisa's mother... Jesus.

"You are tearing me apart Lisa!" "I did not hit her... arg, I did nahit." "and I'm dying..."

Watch it if you're into the worst of the worst in life. F

Have you ever been asked by a good friend to come to see him at an open mic night or to play a couple pieces before another band? Being a nice guy you agree and show up to lend support, your friend gets on stage...and proceeds to destroy all of his chords, screeches his lyrics in an off kilter voice and generally makes an idiot out of himself. Everyone around you is booing and perhaps throwing small projectiles and you're left unable to boo (after all, your friend is now staring at you for support) and feel sort of unpleasantly helpless.

That's exactly what this movie is, and it's the fact that it FEELS like the guy who came up with this actually was trying to do this heavy artsy piece and everything about it completely falls apart at the scenes. The acting is pretty much all around atrocious, our "lead" is just horrific...HORRIFIC...he brandishes his lines like a child with a sword, jumping from complete and utter ambiguous detachment "everything will be fine" to completely off key bursts of anger. Of course he isn't playing off gold here, the sets burst from one scene to the next...one minute we're on a rooftop and suddenly we're in a living room and everyone's wearing tuxedo's, and now we're leaving to play football. Characters come into a scene where two other characters seem to be standing pointlessly at a wall, they'll spout one line and then they're gone and the next scene is off and running. There's no introduction to any of these people, I'm not given any reason to care at all about any of them. Plot points are introduced and dropped two seconds later, never to be heard about again...everything about this film is jarring and flat out poorly done.

If you INSIST on seeing this I'd recommend spending the extra couple bucks and buying the Rifftrax shot at this movie. Doesn't make the movie GOOD but at least makes it watchable and funny.

This is my favorite awful movie. I was introduced to this movie earlier this year and have probably seen it 7 times since. So bad it's good. If you want something terribly cheesy to laugh at, watch Tommy Wiseau's The Room. The memorable quotes have permanently entered my everyday lexicon, for better or worse.

The Room has changed my life. You won't be sorry you gave this film a try. The whole time I was watching it, I felt like I was sitting on an atomic bomb waiting for it to go off. Keep an eye out for the spoons in the background. The best way to experience this movie is at a midnight showing, which I have yet to do. It is a similar experience to The Rocky Horror Picture show. A cult movie of (bad) caliber.

review_title: Time to settle down, kids...or no cookies and Kool-Aid
review_detailed_main: Okay, first off --I love bad films. LOVE EM. I search them out. I watch them over and over. I roll in them like dogs in manure. So I anxiously sought out "THE ROOM" (remember, not "A ROOM" as Wiseau points out on the DVD) with my tail wagging... but really kids...this is just average, so-so entertainment. Standard low-end student film-making. Yes, I laughed at Mr. Wiseau's phonetic, euro-porn line readings. Yes, I snickered at the endless hammering of character's emotional viewpoints. (I get it, Lisa doesn't love Johnny) Yes, I rolled my eyes at the random "dramatic" plot points that come and go without much thought. But really, folks there is a lot worse out there for your viewing enjoyment. This film is just embarrassing... and not in a fun way. It's just not that lovable. For all of you out there claiming it needs to be seen in L.A. with a live audience to fully "get it" I say "Bulls***!" I saw Rocky Horror, Showgirls, Pink Flamingo's, etc. with a live audience and solo and loved them equally both ways. I'm happy some of you are enjoying this film but when all is said and done the emperor has no clothes. Ho hum. Snooze...

So innovative but yet so simple. This movie is amazing and needs to be thoroughly studied. Tommy Wiseau is a genuine jack of all trades and a master of none. He had so many ideas for this movie and I would've loved to see what he would bring but unfortunately and fortunately we have the masterpiece known as The Room. This film shows you an example of what not to do when creating a story and shows you what to do at the same time. No other movie has done this besides Kickassia, another masterfully articulate film. If you have not seen the room, I highly recommend you to do so. You will not be disappointed.

review_title: The Enigma of Talent Molested by the Ghost of Success...
review_detailed_main:
...or some such Dali-esque response seems fitting. For. Tommy Wiseau may not be exactly wise but he certainly scored an unlikely triumph with this crapulopus. He authored a movie that became an international phenomenon, a cult hit in the theatres of LA, and went on to be the subject of a bio-pic made by Hollywood A-listers (The Disaster Artist). A dream was realised in the best Edward D. Wood tradition. The Room, for many commentators, replaced Wood's magnum crapulopus, Plan Nine From Outer Space, at the bottom of the void as Worst Movie Ever Made. The difference is that people get a huge kick out of watching a film whose eccentricities make it downright enigmatic.

Tommy, who wrote and directed, plays Johnny, in a relationship with Lisa, who wants to leave him for his best friend, Mark. There's also Lisa's mom, who acts as Johnny's cheerleader, and Danny, the young milksop who keeps turning up for no reason other than, one presumes, the farfetched dream of getting into a threesome with Johnny and Lisa.

I was going to quote some of the dialogue in this review, but why spoil the surprise? The Room has acting that would better suit a XXX movie, and a script and direction which represent the perfect guide to what not to do when making a movie. Right from the opening titles, naively intercut with images of the San Francisco Bay Area, through to the first of several preposterous sex scenes, the non sequiturs in the dialogue, the corny music, the mysterious sight of several men in tuxedos tossing a baseball about on their way to...um...somewhere. And what is this muddle really about? Who is Johnny, who Lisa, who Danny, and who were we when the movie started, or when we bought tickets, and what have we become?

In the long run, there's a kind of integrity to The Room's uniquely peculiar brand of obscurity. Audiences in USA fell off their chairs laughing at this in late night screenings, and why not? It's so inept its breathtaking. It just makes you want to fathom out the auteur's vision, to ask Why of every decision. Unquestionably a disaster as a movie it was also a triumph for the artist, and how such can be possible is a mystery we may never resolve.

This movie was an absolute mess... but why did I watch it 3 times? It's a film that will live in infamy forever. I cannot stop quoting this movie. It is truly a movie from another planet. Digging deeper to find out who Tommy Wiseau is only makes this movie better. I highly recommend this movie to any movie buff. It needs to be seen.... oh hi Mark

review_title: The absolute worst movie ever made (but it's still enjoyable to watch)
review_detailed_main:
This is one of the hardest films to review. On one side, this is one of the worst films of all time, no doubt about it. But on the other, it's somewhat enjoyable to watch because of how hard everybody fails. I review films based on their quality and what they were trying to accomplish, so this review will treat this film just like any other. So get ready to read a nonstop list of how much this film sucks.

The barely coherent plot starts out in San Francisco and follows our main character, Johnny (Tommy Wiseau), as he tries to please his "future wife" Lisa (Juliette Danielle) who is having doubts about their relationship. Johnny is as "all American guy" who loves freedom, football, and fun. Accompanying Johnny from time to time and filling the story with so many needless subplots are his best friends Mark (Greg Sestero), Denny (Philip Haldiman), and Peter (Kyle Vogt). All I'm going to say is that stuff happens throughout, but it's so stupid that nobody cares.

Tommy Wiseau fills in as the star, director, writer, and producer for his passion project. It's good that he took on so many roles because it saved a couple of people the embarrassment of being a part of this film. The writing, pacing, and just about everything about this film could have been done better by a twelve-year-old. We end up watching softcore porn for the first twenty minutes of the film as three different sex scenes occur right after another, each one filled the worst R&B music ever. Characters appear in scenes for no reason and some characters just show up without a name or relationship to anyone else. It feels as if some random people got lost and accidentally ended up in the shot.

The absolute weirdest thing about this film is that it is 99 minutes long and barely has enough content to fill a poorly written short. Scenes are needlessly overlong and subplots are added for no purpose or resolution.

One could say that this film has an uplifting message for all film students out there. Tommy Wiseau was a passionate man who simply wanted to make a film, and with a script, he wrote himself and $6 million (seriously) he made The Room. If Wiseau can follow through with his dream and make the worst movie ever, then anybody can make their dreams come true.

The acting in this movie is the best part about it but, just like everything else, for all the wrong reasons. Tommy Wiseau claims he wanted to channel James Dean in his performance, which is somewhat evident. The only problem is that Dean was a great actor and Wiseau is not. Tommy can't speak lower than a yell and can't speak English well enough to deliver a sentence. Greg Sestero, Tommy's on screen and real-life best friend also had a dream of being on the big screen. The good thing for him as is that he accomplished his dream, and he'll never have another chance to repeat it. He's bad, but he can say he's not the worst in the group. That honor goes to Juliette Danielle who probably says the same three lines of dialogue, with slight variations from time to time.

With the release of The Disaster Artist and the cult status The Room has achieved over the years, I would recommend this film for anyone who feels like they don't have what it takes to make it into the film industry. After watching this, you'll be inspired to make your own film. And hey, even if you fail, you'll know you didn't fail as hard as Tommy Wiseau and his small group of wannabe stars.

I came across this film whilst viewing Cinema Sins on YouTube and decided it needed a viewing. The first thing that struck me was the horrible lines coupled with some of the worst acting I have seen and I have seen cut throat Island, This all combined with a very two dimensional plot and undeveloped character also the subplot of Lisa's mum having cancer that is then ignored for the remainder of the film which I saw as the possibly the only way to give this film some genuine moments of drama. But even with all of those and more problems going against it. This film is so amazingly awkwardly brilliant in a horrific way it's like watching a train derailing you can't look away, I honestly feel this film could of been made by Ed Wood and that in a way is perfectly as it is so bad it great and full of so many is this happening moments and odd dialog it is well worth a watch just to say you have seen The Room.

A true modern masterpiece. Is there a plot? No not really? Does anything make sense? Absolutely not. This is a community movie best enjoyed with a group of friends so you can quote it until your early demise. It raises so many questions and it answers none of them. All things said there's true passion behind the movie. It may be one lunatic of a man who has no idea how to make a movie but at least he tried his best. This movie has a unique soul. It's a true experience.

review_title: Couldn't find a word to show my disgust
review_detailed_main:
Well this man creates what he thinks is art. An artist is definitely insane and sometimes creates extremely filthy stuff. But this surpasses all levels of filth you can see on screen. The movie is unintentionally hilarious. The Protagonist is so pathetic that you feel like slapping his face. I am not sure how he convinced other actors to be a part of this project. Probably they were jobless and decided to fool around.

Pathetic. Watch this when you want to torture yourself.

review_title: Hilarious and magnificent in its own way
review_detailed_main: Quite crazy how much fun you can have watching a movie as bad as this one. No wonder it has such a huge fan base, me included.

review_title: keep this in mind: people who award this a '10' are not being serious oh hi Mark
review_detailed_main:
Tommy Wiseau may be a genius somewhere inside of his mind. I would still be interested to see it leap out at us unsuspecting viewers. For now, we have The Room on our hands, one of those real marvels of bad movie-making. It's a hilarious kind of bad movie, where one can see that the actors are trying, for better or worse (no, usually for the worse) to act in a serious capacity in their characters. The Room was written as a play first, and it shows: scenes in rooms, scenes on a rooftop (and what a view, ho-ho), scenes in a field somewhere throwing around a football, and back to the Room again. And now it's being touted by its maker as being a 'comedy'. This is called 'after-the-fact' thinking. It was made as a drama, in all sincerity, and now it's a matter of saving face, it becoming a midnight movie, a riot. It's worth it.

Watch it with friends if you can't watch it with a packed audience. It's that kind of bad movie, where one can marvel at how Wiseau managed to eff-up continuity, where actors are supposed to be in a scene, repeating things they just said, saying things that are inconsistent with things said before, characters who disappear for stretches and reappear as if they were just there in the room the whole time. I admire a filmmaker who can do something this wretched, since it shows that somewhere inside of this guy is a voice of an artist. Bad, misguided, and perhaps just untalented. But who is Ed Wood if not an untalented artist who had a lot of ideas and a lack of skills and where-with-all to do it?

Oh, and did I mention the film takes place in San Francisco? This point is hammered in so much you expect for Bullitt to roll over the hill at some point and run over one of the kids playing football. I could attempt to go further and describe the plot, but is there any aside from these several words: Johnny (Wiseau) has a fiancé he loves, she's cheating on him with his best friend, and neither of them can commit to letting Johnny go. Nothing else happens except many scenes of talking; someone may have mentioned a chamber drama in comparison to The Room, and it's not far off. I imagine Wiseau is a big fan of Ingmar Bergman, specifically Cries & Whispers (red walls, anyone?), and if so, more power to him. That it's often so bad as to be unwatchable, when not crying-buckets-of-tears hysterical in its laughter-quota, should also be noted with that.

And one more thing that needs to be said about Tommy boy: he's not a good actor. This is something crucial - he is an easy target for us folks who watch bad movies searching for the next bad actor around the corner. He's so awful not simply because of his lack of emotion in scenes, but how over-emotional he gets when, say, he channels James Dean, or at the end when he (in an act ala Orson Welles in Citizen Kane) tears apart the house at the end. When he enters on the screen it's like an 80's hair-metal cover band is missing its roadie, and he's still in training. He may be inept as a director, and writer, and casting agent, and especially at those sex scenes (good God, someone resurrected BoyZ 2 Men!), but seeing him in the titular lead role is about enough to drive most sensible human beings out of the theater in droves, or shut off the DVD and ask netflix if it was a mistaken delivery.

For the rest of us, however painful it can get, The Room is an entertaining debacle, poorly produced and all the funnier for it.

review_title: Trash, but Beautiful and Majestic Trash
And on the Eighth Day, God said, "Let There Be Tommy Wiseau"
The best and the worst movie ever made

review_detailed_main: This new film by Producer, actor Tommy Wiseau, demands that you have a sense of humor. This black comedy includes the best cinematography of San Francisco since Hitchcock's Vertigo. Wiseau, a new and mysterious presence on the Hollywood film making scene, produced and stars as the lead in this roller coaster ride of emotions which run the gamut from hysterical laughter to gut wrenching guilt. Wiseau spoof's the Hollywood love story. It's a campy version of a Tennessee Williams film with a little John Waters thrown in. He wants everyone to see themselves. The lead actress is every guy's nightmare with a sexual taste for your best friend. This is a story about a nymphomaniac with great breasts and the victim who is clueless about her scattered sexual outlook about men. Worth seeing. It's now 2011, eight years later and I would never have believed that this problematic film would have become a cult classic,"worst movie ever made" with 12 midnight monthly showings around the U.S., all these years. Edward Lozzi & Associates PR, first crticized for promoting this thing, has been vindicated for helping to turn this nightmare into a classic.

review_title: I don't care who you are...

review_detailed_main: Honestly, this movie is one of the worst films ever made if not the worst but at the same time, you are going to love it. The involuntarily hilarious acting of Tommy Wiseau plus the poorly written script is going to make you laugh all the time. As a movie, The Room is worthless but this is not a casual film, this is a masterpiece.

review_title: Watch a film about way more than a room...
1/10 but also one of the most entertaining films
review_detailed_main: This is a 1/10 simply because I can't seriously give it anything else. That doesn't mean I didn't enjoy this movie however! I have very really laughed so much at a screwball comedy let alone a movie labeled as a romantic drama. Every single scene had me in stitches. Tommy Wiseau is either the worst filmmaker ever or secretly the comedic genius the world needed. I prefer the former as him genuinely thinking this movie was going to be great makes the movie a whole other level of funny. Trust me you want to watch this movie it is an experience you won't have with any other movie. So bad it's actually amazing!

review_title: The Lonely Lady meets Ed Wood but with only 2% of the finesse.

review_detailed_main:
Short and Simple Review by WubsTheFadger

First off, I am going to keep this review very short because you already know this film is bad but in an entertaining way. I am also not doing a Pros and Cons at the end because there is no point.

The plot has many subplots that aren't addressed throughout the course of the film, the characters have constant personality changes as the film progresses on and the acting is atrocious. All in all, the film is entertaining much like Sharknado. The amount of plot holes are tremendous.

Tommy Wiseau, Greg Sestero, and Juliette Danielle deliver some of the worst performances Hollywood has ever seen. The acting is inconsistent and always sounds scripted and is always overacted.

The pacing is slow and for a film that is an hour and thirty-nine minutes long, it's an hour and thirty-eight minutes too long.

Sadly, the film is hilarious to watch and is probably one of the mist entertain movies I have ever seen because it is loaded with material.

Overall Rating: 3.2 (This is only a 3.2 because it is hilarious and kinda entertaining)

review_title: Your tearing me apart! An interesting and compelling soap opera like drama that twist with life and love while leading to tragic means.
review_detailed_main:
Finally after all these years finally watched the cult classic "The Room" as it's a favorite for many art houses and independent movie chains as the film still has countless midnight showings. Many consider it the worst movie ever made, however after watching I disagree, as I liked it the film was blended with drama and twist of love and lust that lead to bad means for all involved as really it was a good black hearted comedy.

Set in the city by the bay "San Francisco", Johnny(Tommy Wiseau) is a successful investment banker who enjoys life and love as he plans to marry his younger and sexy girlfriend Lisa(Juliette Danielle). However this is the game of life it's not always a bed of roses(unlike the love making scenes!)as lust, passion, lies, and betrayal take over.

Johnny has a best friend named Mark(Greg Sestero) and all three become involved in a web a deadly game of temptation as these games slowly, but surely lead to loss for all involved. This film is a great take and spin on life, love, and friendship, as can anyone be trusted? It proves love runs deep, yet when lust and passion mix it's a deadly combination. Overall well done movie that teaches lessons in a painful way, and the movie is spiced up by love making scenes and the acting and on screen chemistry between the actors is good for a low budget independent that would become a historical cult classic.

review_title: The king of "so bad its good"
review_detailed_main:
The acting is so terrible and stale. The dialogue is awkward and doesn't flow. I dare anybody to do a drinking game - one shot for every time they say "oh hi 'name'" and 5 shots for the infamous "oh hi Mark" line. There is just no chemistry or emotion between the characters or actors. They just seem like a bunch of fake friends pretending to like each other. The characters themselves were just dry and colorless and had no dimension at all. The story itself is stupid. Maybe different story arcs looked good on paper, but the execution was poor. And to top it all off, there are a few more sex scenes than necessary.

Now that the complaints are out of the way, let me give credit where credit is due: Everything that makes The Room bad is everything that makes The Room good.

Of course it's a bad film, but it has its charms. The story of the Room was flawed, but it really did have some good themes in there, and its obvious that Wiseau tried his best to get different messages across, particularly through the use of Danny's character. Hearing about the making of the film is interesting as well and adds to the experience (watch Disaster Artist before and/or after watching the Room). My rating is 3/10 - 2 stars for the attempt of making a decent move, and 3 stars for Sir Tommy Wiseau.

Tommy Wiseau gave it his all in this film. He wanted to make a movie, so he did. Though I'm sure the movie upon release was received poorly, he continues to work to this day and has many beloved fans that follow this cult classic. It's honestly inspiring that he achieved success, but in a way he probably wasn't expecting. As low quality as the Room is, it was at least entertaining. I plan to watch other Wiseau films someday, just to see how much has evolved, and to support an independent film maker who dedicates his life expressing himself through the art of film.

You need to be honest with yourself about why you watch movies.

Is it for great directing and cinematography?

You will not find this here

Is it for great writing and acting?

You will not find this here

Is it for a great soundtrack?

You will not find this here

are you looking for profound and incisive social and political commentary?

You will not find this here

however

if you like watching movies to laugh and be entertained

then you will definitely find that in spades in The Room

the story makes no sense and the acting is crap but every single scene is hilarious in it's own way

as far as Tommy Wiseau goes I think he is a bad writer but if he worked on it he might eventually get good. As an actor he is bad but I do think that in the right context he could actually be kind of good. What I mean is that if you gave him an eye patch and had him basically play himself then he could easily be a villain in an 80s action movie. It may not be The Godfather but who cares.

There are tons of movies that critics love and are very professionally made by very talented people that still end up being boring as hell (cough Oppenheimer) The Room on the other hand is terrible and everyone knows that but people still love watching it decades later.

If people could get over their snobbery they would have to admit that it is a great movie in the sense that it is constantly surprising and unintentionally hilarious. I'll take that over some pretentious black and white crap about the holocaust any day.

review_title: A Joyful Experience, with the Right People to Watch it With

review_detailed_main: It seems that movie goers and critics alike are torn on what to think of this movie; however for the most part the reviews are negative. to be honest i would probably hate this movie all the same if i hadn't seen it in film class and been told why the movie's so bad. This film spits in the face of what we have come to expect from movies nowadays, because it is so bad it makes you appreciate the salient techniques used in feature films that are often overlooked. "The Room" actually becomes really comical once you accept it for what it is. Its not meant to be a Hollywood blockbuster, but simply a satirical drama to make people appreciate the hard work that goes in to making a good film and how terrible and corny a film can become if its not carefully rendered to fit the public's expectations.

review_title: Didn't even have to watch the movie to enjoy it.
Will Restore Your Faith in Good Filmmaking
review_detailed_main: Many of the public lack a proper appreciation for the artistry that goes into films. They take 'the movies' for granted: just another part of popular culture. 'The Room' can restore that appreciation, not from any virtues which it possesses, but from the lack thereof. In short, The Room is an object lesson in what results from a production lacking artistry. This includes the performances, the script, the photography, the editing, the soundtrack....All these elements lack artistry in this film, and the results are so sadistic, that one will never lack an appreciation for good filmmaking ever again after seeing this movie. Some have described it as a traffic accident. I don't think this really does it justice. You might recall an accident in upstate NY a few years back. It involved an intoxicated mother carrying 5 or 6 children that collided head on with a vehicle with a father and his son riding in it, in which everyone but one child in the mother's car was killed. You catch my drift....After watching The Room, I don't think anyone could ever again be under the impression that good films just happen, or that making films is easy, or that little effort is required. 'The Room' will forever remain a testament to what the art of film sans 'art' is: and for that we owe the producers a debt of gratitude.

This is no movie, this is a cinematic experience.

I also recommend watching The Disaster Artist afterwards, it will make you understand and appreciate The Room even more.

review_title: Tommy Wiseau THE MAN, THE MYTH, THE LEGEND.
review_detailed_main:
I can't believe what I just saw, and I can't wait to watch someone watching The room for the first time. The most appropriate part in this whole masterpiece is the first thirty seconds of the opening credits. Ladies and gentlemen, here is the film that challenged all the foundations of cinema and will stand the test of time.

This piece is concluded with one of the most heartbreaking quotes that I've seen. "I've lost him, but I still have you, right? Right? Mark".

review_title: Unbelievable it was made, but it became a cult movie.
review_detailed_main: This movie is both horrible, naive and surreal. Anyway, it's unbelievable that it was done. One fact, however, deserves mention: in all disgrace, with his perseverance of Don Quixote and flamboyant and pathetic personality, Tommy Wiseau has managed to make his film, put his name on the records of the film industry. And for God's sake, the movie became Cult.
Clearly a true masterpiece. This is the most emotional movie ive ever watched. The acting was magnificent. A true piece of art work. Amazing 10/10

review_title: The Best "So Bad It's Good" Movie EVER
review_detailed_main: This (obviously) is the worst film in the history of anything, but it is worth seeing because of one man. Tommy Wiseau. His acting is like an alien came down from space and saw a 12 year old's short film and thought it was the best acting he'd ever seen, so he made Tommy Wiseau with the acting skills of that 12 year old. It's so utterly bad that it makes it wonderful to watch. I recomend you see it with a couple of friends so you can have a good laugh together.

review_title: I enjoyed this film more than most things I've seen lately.
review_detailed_main: Very easy to watch, exceptionally talented actors. Well done.

review_title: The world wouldn't be a better place to live in without this movie!
review_detailed_main: This is actually an unreviewable movie; critics shouldn't be allowed to review and rate it; it's pointless and embarrassing for anyone who tries to explain why this movie is so bad. It may be something beyond our ken! First, you need to see it to believe it; then, a re-watch is obligatory; it's crazy, I know, but it's even more enjoyable the second time. Tommy Wiseau is an uncanny character; his incomprehensibly bad acting (that's actually the movie's strong point), his one of a kind accent, his awkward reactions, movements, facial expressions, everything about him is just too damn weird; I'm not even sure he's a human being, although we must all love him as a friend... as a human bean, because... that's life! I want the 3D release in cinemas now! The purpose of my existence will be lost unless I see Wiseau's ass in 3D!! It's the only bad movie that deserves to exist! I just HAD to rate it, I'm sorry; it's a paradoxical rating. I'm giving this 5 stars and 1 star at the same time.

I just watched The Room on DVD and wonder if all this "worst film ever" hype is for real.Yes, it is bad.Yes, there are bizarre bits that make no sense.Yes, a character goes for a jog with Johnny AND is with Lisa at the same time (at least I think it was Mark in two places!) For me Urban Menace is a for more worser film, a film so bad it has no redeeming qualities.Even Plan 9 From Outer Space is worse.I think a lot of people are told what to like and dislike by the media & the internet (the average Rocky Horror Picture Show is a case in point.) People watch The Room 30 times? Is that because they feel they have to to fit in with the crowd? I give this 5 stars...the endless love making scenes were terrible and I found Lisa a bore but for me every scene with Tommy Wiseau made this DVD worthwhile.He reminds me of Christopher Walken's talentless brother who can't act or direct.The end scene with him is marvelous.

I would recommend this film, it made me laugh a lot but as Chuck D said : Don't believe the hype!

The only reason this film is remotely palatable is because of Newgrounds and all the memes that came after it. This film is literally on meme life support. The fact it takes itself seriously, the fact the actors try to act seriously and the fact that it is as narcissistic as its director really makes you question what the intent was.

That said at least it's not disaster movie.

review_title: Not as bad as it could have been
review_detailed_main: There seems to be a lot of people proposing that The Room is "the worst movie of all time". A better epithet might be "the most unintentionally funny movie of all time". The acting is terrible and the story isn't particularly good, but the camera work seems OK to me and some of the roof shots are kind of interesting. There are long stretches in the movie which aren't bad enough to be remarkable. A lot of this is just boring. I'm guessing that the circumstances surrounding the production and the cult-like fans are adding to the public conception of the movie. Realistically a movie should be judged on the content alone, and by that standard there must be many movies worse than The Room.

Laugh out loud funny! Best bad movie ever!

1 star but 10/10 title? Watch it and hopefully you'll agree

review_title: This could be the worst film you have ever seen but it is so bad, it is laughable.
review_detailed_main:
The writing is so poor that whenever Mr. Wiseau cannot come up with something interesting or realistic (which is in every scene), a character says either "I don't want to talk about it," "Whatever" or "Don't worry about it." The leading man looks like Tiny Tim from LAUGH-IN and sounds like Borat trying to do some serious acting. His "sexy" girlfriend is overweight and sits around like a third-rate porn star. I can't really tell why the odd college boy is even here except to get in trouble for buying drugs and to have some sort of weird man-crush on Johnny. The "best friend" doesn't even know how Johnny met his girlfriend of 7 years, the same one he is having an affair with. Every time she slips out of her Walmart blouse, he exclaims with great surprise, "Hey! What's going on here?" There really is no reason for anything that happens in this movie to happen. Dialogue is trite, nobody seems to have a purpose for being where they are or saying what they say. Everyone acts like they barely know one another (e.g. lovers, best friends, mother and daughter all behave very awkwardly around each other). One friend, the psychologist just disappears. The mother announces she has breast cancer and no one really cares, including her. Grown men toss a football four feet from one another. No reason.

Probably the very worst parts are the nude scenes with Tommy Wiseau. I mean, seriously, how nauseating does he have to make this already abysmal film. Fast forward through those tawdry scenes.

review_title: Failure so great that it becomes a win
This film was 'tearing me apart' but I still loved it (cult wise)
review_detailed_main:
I guess that unlike all the other reviews I've done on this site, and I've done plenty, this one should be judged on its own niche merits (or lack of them). The Room is an unintentional disaster that makes it a compounded mess of a film that you just can't help love to watch, which is what has created the cult following. It deserves the poor ratings but that doesn't reflect the genuine joy you will actually get from this film, a kind of schadenfreude.

To summarise, if you take out any film making textbook and list the key needs for any films, this doesn't fit the bill. The end result is like a trifle without the jelly, using custard not made with eggs, and using pepper instead of the topping sprinkles. It really is that strange. Everything that could be done wrong has been (without intention too).

The main aspect that astounds is how the crew were awarded $6m to make this tripe! The lead is vain as hell, being the writer/director/lead 'star' in this absurd movie, yet for all his faults he has some charisma (best admired or humoured with from afar). He can't act, direct or manage. The story has lots of lost strands, the actors aren't even actors it seems, the settings are minimal and woeful, and the whole thing has lots of laughable dialogue (and I've never laughed at love scenes in a film so much in my life!).

I watched this recently as part of a cult showing at cinema, with the spoon throwing and quote alongs, and I'd a great time. When you watch it for the first time, you can't but be carried along with the sheer audacity of what is in front of us.

Admittedly I'm not sure I'd want to do repeat viewings. The film is "tearing us apart", and is carried by the vanity and ineptitude of the lead who is pathetic but cult he is. He's a character and in this day of over managed productions, this is a crazy throwbacks.

In fairness, despite the tag, it isn't actually the worst film you'll ever see, there are big budget movies you'll see who are more deserving of that tag.

Simply, get some friends, some plastic spoons to throw about and sit & watch this film. It's unintentionally ridiculous fun.

review_title: Great movie, new ideas, black comedy.
review_detailed_main: This is very good film. I like everything about it: acting,directing, script and design. Tommy Wiseau delivered the role of his life. I was never bored at all watching it. It makes you think. The directing is extraordinary. And the ending to this film is surprising and scary. I give this 10 our of 10. Highly recommended.

review_title: YOU ARE TEARING ME APART, LISA!
review_detailed_main:
I am sooooo glad that I watched "The Disaster Artist" first! That movie made me realize what a horrible gem that this one is! Yes the acting is horrible, but it's the script and editing that really strangle this one! I had no idea where the characters were, where they were going, or where they had come from! Just a crazy mess of a film! And Tommy's creep three laugh chuckle (ha, ha, ha...)! Geez! He's like a cross of Hannibal Lecter's face, Vincent Vega's hair and clothing, and Frankenstein's monster's movements! Then add the Tommy accent! Bingo - Johnny! Ahh... what a disaster!

Johnny walks to the apartment rooftop

Johnny: I did not hit her, it's not true! It's bullshit! I did not hit her!

throws water bottle

Johnny: I did *not*. Oh hi, Mark.

Mark: Oh, hey Johnny, what's up?

Tommy Wiseau's The Room somehow manages to be one of my favorite films in the most disastrous way possible. With an intent to be a heavy hitting romantic drama and cautionary tale, this film has an effect drastically different as a finished product. Tommy Wiseau created a film so terrible that it has become a laugh-out-loud comedic hit within a large cult following. The production of Wiseau's passion project is widely known as being extremely chaotic and itself a hilarious story, as displayed in James Franco's film The Disaster Artist. Horrible camera quality caused by use of mixing digital and film, terrible use of lighting, atrocious screenplay and performances, and countless horrid sex scenes make this film a Marvel unlike any other. One of the most entertaining comedies I could ever personally name, this disaster is a hilarious viewing experience to unlike any other.

review_title: So bad, but I laughed so hard at it

review_detailed_main:
okay, i think that it is pretty safe to say this has become a cult classic. however this is not as a result of adapt cinematography but more the lack of it. you can see this just by looking at the format of the movie, it was shot in two different formats. this move is so bad that its so good the poor acting and appalling story line. make this movie simply fantastic to watch.

you can be watching this move and think wow, I'm actually really bored and then BAM some random line comes from no where making everyone watching it burst out laughing. when watching this movie it re mined me of getting the giggles in an exam and know that your not suppose to be laughing and yet you cant stop this movie is so appallingly funny!

the rating does not reflect the move just what they where trying to do/portray i like to think this is a read between the lines movie because all the best bits are unintended.

The Room is famously terrible. First, it's amazing how the dialogue nonsensically bounces around topics yet also repeats earlier conversations, going everywhere and nowhere at once. Meanwhile, entire scenes are unrelated to the narrative while other scenes are copies of previous moments. Plot points are introduced and instantly abandoned. Characters' actions are inconsistent and illogical. This is amplified by the fascinatingly bad acting, particularly Tommy Wiseau's. His energy level is often inappropriate and his transitions between emotional beats are comically unnatural.

From a technical standpoint, The Room has slight merit but only in a relative sense. The sound design is okay, but audio effects are overused and Tommy's dubbing is hilariously unconvincing. The camera framing mostly captures its subjects, but sometimes action is outside the shot. The musical mood is usually in the correct ballpark, but the end credits song is an R&B ballad that doesn't match. Lastly, the production design looks like actual sets, but they're cheap and poorly dressed. Ultimately, The Room is a symphony of disasters that is quite fun to laugh at. It's not for everyone and it's certainly not conventionally good, but The Room is a glorious wreck.

Writing: 0/10 Direction: 0/10 Cinematography: 1/10 Acting: 0/10 Editing: 1/10 Sound: 1/10 Score/Soundtrack: 1/10 Production Design: 1/10 Casting: 0/10 Effects: 0/10

Overall Score: 0.5/10.

review_title: What ? What ? Tommy Wiseau is talentless

review_detailed_main:
There have been a number of movies over the years that have achieved immortality by being so bad that they are strangely entertaining. The tradition started with Plan 9 from Outer Space and moved through Manos Hands of Fate, Attack of the Killer Tomatoes and, in the modern day, Sharknado.

It is not totally clear if this movie, The Room, falls into that category--it is so bad that you wonder if perhaps the director has a secret genius and is doing a spoof of said movies, or if his psycho-"drama" love-triangle flick is just an earnest attempt at real cinema. Probably the latter, since the dialogue, story and characters of this movie are so amateurish, so far-fetched, and so talent-less that it simply could not be. No spoof could be this brilliant. It is just horrible. The mounting "tension" as the love triangle gets ever more exposed and gives way to ever more ridiculous situations and acting, is a beautiful thing to behold, as it is executed with complete earnestness. We watch dumbfounded, and occasionally drawn into hysterical laughter.

Which brings me to the main reason you should watch this movie. It is hilarious. And it gets funnier as it goes along. And at the end, without tripping the spoiler alert, I can tell you that the last scene is one of the funniest I have ever seen in any movie in my entire life. My son and I, when we watched it, were falling off of our chairs in tears and could barely avoid having an asthma attack, we were both laughing so hard. I never thought I would see a film that could surpass Plan 9 for its campy hideousness, but this is the grandaddy of them all. Please watch The Room, it will take you away from your dreary life and put you into humorous ecstasy.

review_title: A whole new feeling is born: the Wiseaunian wtf syndrome.
review_detailed_main:
Oh hai, reviewers!

First of all, I would like to thank Mr. Brickyard Jimmym from Los Angeles, who wrote such an amazing review called "It's like sitting on an atom bomb that's about to explode". Thank you Mr. Jimmym, your review actually set loose a bit of that Wiseaunian wtf syndrome back to me, it was almost like watching bits of the movie for the second time.

Second of all, I loved this movie. Yes, I gave it a 10 star rating. Yes, I would do it again if I was just watching the movie for the first time. Yes, I am serious. This is in no way a mocking business.

Third of all, thanks Mr. Wiseau for existing. I will not write any spoilers, for I'm afraid someone might bump into them accidentally, and that could ruin someone's experience. All I want to say is, if there is such a thing as a religious experience, watching "The Room" is the closest to that I'll ever get. It is a whole new dimension of being, feeling, existing. Could it be the twilight zone? Could God have come to earth? Could I be closer to something? Further away? These are all good questions, and there are no final answers for them. Therefore, these questions don't really matter. What matters is, I never felt so closer to myself and so further away at the same time. I often felt like I was watching a movie with aliens that were trying desperately hard to imitate human's life, but couldn't, or failed for a bit. There's something that's off, but I can't pinpoint it, I can't put my finger on it and say "this is what's wrong!": and that's the beauty of it. Mr. Wiseau was right, on an interview he gave about "The Room": you have to watch this movie at least twice, you won't understand it the first time. I've seen "The Room" 5 times now, and I still cannot explain in words the way I feel, nor can I explain what the movie really is, or what it is really about. Mr. Wiseau also tells us that this movie is meant to teach us something, to teach us to be better persons because, quoting "If I lot of people loved each other, the world would be a better place."

I am not sure if watching "The Room" made me a better person. Although, I can honestly say, it has made me a happier person. And that my friends, is a precious beautiful gift. Let's hold on to this happiness forever and rejoice in it. May Mr. Wiseau be in our thoughts. Amen.

review_title: A Movie that indirectly teaches you how NOT to make a movie.
review_detailed_main:
Tommmy Wiseau's The Room is one of the most important pieces of film-making ever created. This 2003 movie with a 6 Million Dollar Budget has been memed on to death, had a enticing documentary and book surrounding its creation; and with such a insanely chaotic and toxic production, its amazing that this film ever made it to the big screen, even if it only ranked in $1,916 initially.

Being a passion project of the Writer, Director, Producer, and Lead Star Tommy Wiseau. The Room is so astonishingly terrible and the writing is so open-handed that it almost becomes a character study of him. You see how he views America, what he views as a normal 'american' friendship as they toss footballs in a alleyway over and over again, and you even get a sense of his past and his views on women with his portrayal of Lisa as a character. Despite being a R-Rated film, there's almost a child-like obliviousness to this film with how characters have unexplainable mood-swings and one-dimensional personality traits.

While its attempting to be a tragic story, The Room is so abysmally bad at what its trying to convey it loops around to being the perfect comedy. The performances leave nothing to be desired because the pure insanity behind the script and their acting creates scenes that are truly unforgettable; and when the film manages to accomplish something good, whether it be the grande & epic score or the occasional good looking shot. You will be impressed with the little things it sometimes gets right admist the flames of a terrible movie.

If you are studying film, watch this movie and watch / read The Disaster Artist. Everything falls apart so magically that it not only creates a unforgettable viewing experience, but one that emphasizes the importance of a strong and unified team. If you feel your production is anything like The Room, then run away as soon as you can.

The Room. Saying it out loud sends shivers down my spine, not in fear but in excitement. It does not happen a lot, that a movie lives up to the hype. Of course I knew the memes before watching this in early 2020, for the first time in my life. The legendary roof scene, or the "You're tearing me apart Lisa!" line, have almost religious character at this point, although my personal favourite is: "a few more minutes bitch!".

I did not know what I was missing, until watching this and I never want to go back! Thank you Tommy, for blessing us with this gem!

The Room is an independent film that was written, produced, and directed by Tommy Wiseau, a wealthy, wannabe actor/director who starred himself in its leading role. While initially ridiculed by the viewing public, The Room later attained cult status for its consistently uninspired scripting and second-rate acting. The peculiar constancy of its grade-B qualities derives from Wiseau's East-European origins, origins which bestowed a subtle, but pervasive cultural dysfluency that bled over not only onto his screen play, but also onto his spoken lines. The flattened affect attendant on this dysfluency gives The Room an aura of incompetence and a soap-opera-like character. The Room ultimately inspired the 2017 movie, The Disaster Artist, which details the story behind Tommy Waseau and the making of The Room.

I've said this since I saw Tommy Wiseau and met him at an appearance: he is the most solid proof that aliens might walk among us.

When I saw this movie for the first time, I wondered what kind of a person thinks that people act the way they do in the movie. Everything is in this bizarre uncanny valley of being close to correct, but not at all.

The best way I can explain this movie is that it's the difference between someone saying "I've got a fire in my belly" (meaning that they're motivated) versus saying "My stomach is on fire."

I gave this film a two star rating because of things I would consider more objective. It's poorly made overall, but there are some shots and choices that are actually very smart and done well, even if I suspect they are accidental. That being said, I've seen this movie more than some movies I'd give a nine or ten to and not once regretted it.

I love this movie. Despite the two star rating, it is one of my all time favorite movies to watch. Every time I see it, there's something new that pops out at me that I didn't notice before. Of course, it started out as an ironic love, but it's developed from that into an unironic adoration and appreciation of this movie that I don't have for many other movies of this kind.

Tommy Wiseau has since come out and said he made the movie as a comedy. I don't believe him, but if it turns out that it was, then he is an Andy Kaufman level of genius and dedication to character.

I can't stress enough that I have never, ever been bored or disappointed by this movie. It's incredible. Watch it with friends.

review_title: The worst movie ever made by either man or animal
review_detailed_main: No matter how low your expectations are, this movie will still manage to suck more than you thought possible. Every scene is absolutely awful. Every aspect of the movie is completely horrible, except for the pure technicals like sound and camera, which help frame how awful everything in this movie is. If they gave me a camera and specifically asked me to make the worst movie that I can, I would not be able to make something this bad. In the same time, it's entertaining, because I couldn't stop laughing at how terrible it is.

review_title: A Classic "It's So Bad, It's Good"
review_detailed_main:
At this point, "The Room" is an infamous trainwreck. It is often regarded as the worst movie ever made - so, why would I recommend it? It's not a film that is so half-assed that it is a bore to watch. No, on the contrary, it is a genuinely entertaining experience at the expense of Tommy Wiseau's delusional cinematic vision.

I'm sure many have already seen "The Room". It's inescapable for anyone that spends considerable time online. It is notorious among youtube film critics and many memes have been made using the famous rooftop scene. There is good reason that this flick is highly discussed and laughed at. It has comedically bad acting, horrendous dialogue, and uninspired cinematography and set design. And that is the draw. There is nothing more, nothing deep. It is one of the most shallow films ever created but I still implore you to put it on, preferably with friends and a few beers. You'll be in pain from laughing so much.

5/10.

Mr. Wiseau, the man, the myth, the legend. He has managed to create a film so excellent that it changed my life forever. His brilliance and skill is on par with Steven Spielberg and other Oscar winners. Only once in a lifetime does one come across a movie so spectacular as The Room. I would highly recommend this film to all.

With the soon to be released 'The Disaster Artist', I figured I would finally watch this movie. It's definitely something else. I didn't really laugh out loud at any point but it's quite amusing throughout. The dialogue comes across as starting a script in English then translating it to another language and then back to English. People blurt out dialogue in scenes like they've been coached to say it as quickly as possible. Tommy Wiseau dialogue seems like it has been dubbed throughout as it goes in and out of sync.

The plot is non-existent and scenes don't seem to serve a plot they're just there. People come over to the apartment and then leave at the end of their scene which is usually 2 minutes after they arrive. Performances range from terrible to passable. Greg Sestero who plays Mark appears beleaguered throughout which is probably not acting but more the amount of work he was doing behind the scenes.

All in all it's worth seeing to prepare to see the dramatized making of movie 'the Disaster Artist. It is a fascinating movie that only exists because a man had money and a vision so weird you can't look away.

Wait wait what? Why would I give 1 star to a film that I just called a complete masterpiece? I'll tell you why, because this movie is a different kind of masterpiece. It's absolutely terrible in every possible way but that's what makes it amazing. I'm serious, I cannot stop thinking about this film. You will be referencing lines and questioning events long after you see this movie, it's just so much more than a terrible movie. I really can't say anything more other than there's no other movie like this. It is one of the most unique things I've seen in a long time

If you watch this movie, read the book "The Disaster Artist" by Greg Sestero

Watching Tommy Wiseua's hilarious implosion "The Room" is an awe striking moment by itself but experiencing it with a large live audience is an entirely different journey! The absurd props like Footballs, Roses, Leopard Print, Umbrellas to shield oneself from the shower of precisely cued spoons make the theater feel like a well orchestrate asylum. There are regulars that attend here and you can spot them by the brevity of their call back lines and occasional Tommy costume such as wig, suit and black glasses...by the way who is the Guy in the White Silk Shirt???? What happens to Denny's addiction for sex and drugs? What about Lisa's mother? The Psychiatrist? The Party that takes 2 years to happen? and did Johnny get the promotion???? Is there possibly some sadomasochistic comedy genius behind this film and it's train wreck film-making? It could help explain the reason why every month hundreds of people crawl out of the underground of Sunset Blvd to attend the Laemmle screening at midnight. But Tommy Wiseau seems to shroud his motives and background with nonsensical dialogue making the nail biting Q&A hilarious and disturbing at the same time. I can't explain the underground cult movement this film has picked up and I can't explain why I have the urge to go back. You did Tommy, you finally did it... you are starting to make some money back from the black hole of Independent film-making.

review_title: Highly recommend it for anthropological research!!!!
review_detailed_main: I almost started eating tide pods while watching this!!!! Its like being made by aliens who just try to mimic the human behavior and fail miserably!!!! Well maybe Wisaw is an alien i dont know...for the shake of humanity WATCH THE MOVIE they may not come in peace!!!! God save us all!!!!!

Okay, there's no doubt about it that this movie sucks. However, this may be one of the most entertaining movies I have ever seen. I have been able to watch this film several times with friends and it is just as hilarious, if not more so, after each time I watch it. Tommy Wiseau has created an accidental cinematic treasure, although not in the way that he intended. If you can sit through and poke fun at the terrible acting, editing, music, and constant errors in the continuity of the story, I can guarantee that you will adore this movie like it's your own infant child.

review_title: A Tale That Will Make You Laugh, Cry, and then Feel Shame
I have a great fan theory - what if the movie is Johnny's perception of his reality and in reality he's a terrible person
Cult movie for the wrong reasons.
review_detailed_main:
Oh, I had a hard time giving it a 1, however, the movie is incompetent in the production aspect as well as the plot, acting, score... Well, you get the idea.

I found about "The Room" in the Prince Charles Cinema in London because the place has a big poster of it. Then, curiosity became obsession and I did research about everything that had to do it. No curiosity, maybe, morbid intentions.

It is laughable for the wrong reasons but it is cult entertainment for sure. It made me roar in laughter and could not believe how bad was it.

So, you may wanna give it a chance in order to witness that what people say about it, is REAL!

Tommy Wiseau may be an underestimated genius for scenes such as the rooftop scene, the fight during a party, the tedious love scenes, ail of Danny's participations, and more... Oh well, THIS IS a true cult movie.

Oh, Hi! Its so awful that its so excellent; you don't know if their doing it on purpose. The movie really tore me apart! I laughed the whole time. I have a weird interest in wanting to watch it again, and again. What really fascinates me is how did Tommy Wiseau get a $6 million budget to make this movie, and then what the hell did he spend it on? I cannot wait to see the Disaster Artist. Bye.

review_title: Absolutely terrible in a good way
review_detailed_main:
I have to rate this 1/10 because its an absolute piece of cr@p, but god its good entertainment.

I 100% recommend watching The Disaster Artist BEFORE watching this to really appreciate it. You won't be disappointed.

review_title: Move over, Plan Nine from Outer Space
review_detailed_main:
I had often heard that the title for worst film ever made went hands down to "Plan Nine from Outer Space." Recently I'd been hearing about "The Room", mostly in connection with the film "The Disaster Artist," which is about the making of "The Room"

Now that I've seen it, I have to agree that "The Room" wins the title of "Worst Film" hands down. From the acting, which runs the gamut from deadpan to hammy to outright histrionic, to the repetitive scenes, which if edited out, might have left about 10 minutes of movie (how many times did we have to see the same tedious sex scenes with the flowers and candles and curtains?) to the preposterous characters and gobsmackingly awful dialog.

And yet there is something mesmerizing about the very depths of awfulness to which this film descends. It has you gasping with shock, snorting with disbelief, and laughing out loud at the utter dreadfulness of this production.

If they gave an Academy award for awful, this movie would have taken it!

review_title: One of the best films of all time.
review_detailed_main:
When we look back at this movie fifty years from now, we're going to have to look at this as among the classics. It's truly one of the most entertaining films ever made, if not the most entertaining, because absolutely everything about it is wrong. No amount of explanation will do to prepare you for this movie (only alcohol can do that -- and a lot, to boot).

Unfortunately, though it is one of the best films of all time, it is certainly not one of the greatest, and it is in fact one of the worst.

Everything is wrong, and it's not even close. It's just wrong. It's all wrong. Christ, it's all so, so wrong. The cinematography is sickeningly hilarious. The dialogue is revoltingly hilarious. The plot is confusingly hilarious. It's all hilarious, but it's all wrong.

Watch this movie. I'm giving it a 1 because it really deserves that as a film, but if I were the type to rank films based purely on entertainment value gained, this would have a 10.

I'm one of those people who normally agrees with the "its so bad, it's good" line (being an avid fan of B-class movies and Rocky Horror). I attended this movie laughing off all the comments that it was the "worst movie in the world" as screenings sold out virtually every month. It wasn't until I was there, fatefully making the mistake to attend sober, that I realized the only way you could sit through more than 5 minutes was to be drunk/stoned/both. I can see how, viewed in a theater at midnight after a few drinks, this might conjure up its own hilariously demented cult following complete will call back lines and spoons but for anyone expecting a movie worth crowds this size, don't go. The writer/producer/director/leading man Tommy Wiseau lacks talent in both his character acting (if you could even call it that) and writing skills. The self-financed "The Room"s shortcomings go way beyond the standard array of glaring continuity errors, dodgy sets and stagnant editing...it's hard to describe how bad the acting in the film actually is. I left the cinema not only wanting my money back but wondering why 15 minutes of the movie was spent throwing a football around on a badly constructed rooftop.

review_title: A great experience with an awful film
review_detailed_main:
This is seriously the worst movie of all time; there really is no contest here. The acting, the use of shots, the music and the overall premise is unbelievably bad. A love triangle between a banker, a hunk and a blonde woman is the plot of this film which has been likened to a play by the director, Tommy Wiseau. Unfortunately this same guy is the producer and writer. Oh, and he stars in it too.

Do not go into this movie expecting the best romance ever made or even a decent romance for that matter. No matter how much potential each actor/actress holds, they all share the same emotionless line reading status. The main star of this film (and I guess rightly so because of how awesome he looks) is Tommy Wiseau who plays Johnny, a banker and lover. It is fair to say without insulting anyone that his accent alone makes the movie. His pronunciation of words and sentences has become standout moments in their own sense. Accompanying him and the other range of characters is a green screen backdrop overlooking a very bland looking city. Despite being called 'The Room', the apartment and the roof play big parts in this movie themselves.

One of the worst things about this movie is the music throughout it. Despite the movie being a romantic drama, the dramatic piano theme that would be much better suited to a TV movie about hobbits, keeps coming back to annoy us viewers throughout various points in the movie. In the opening it works quite well and sets the scene but then it gets boring very quickly and it is ridiculously overused. If I see this next time then I will be tempted to start a drinking game involving the times this theme appears in the movie! The music is so laughably bad in parts of the movie (and by parts I mean the whole thing) that this makes the movie more laughable than it already is. For example, music suddenly plays when one of the characters, Greg, enters the room and then suddenly stops. This is only one of the many instances when dramatic music is used out of nowhere for no apparently reason! When it's not cheap instrumental music, it's instead cheesy lyrical love songs that play during the clichéd sex scenes.

Another funny thing in this movie is the tendency to bring up random story lines and then get rid of them soon after. There is a breast cancer line spoken by the mother which is never referred to again in the rest of the movie. We are aware that it is a movie about love and not cancer, but if there's not going to be a resolution then don't bring it up to begin with. Another storyline that had a lot of potential to interest us viewers above the main storyline was Denny's drug money problems. A random thug appears on the infamous rooftop where he threatens Denny with a gun however after a commotion this is never talked about again. And what's with the couple who feel the need to make love in Johnny's apartment before Lisa and her mother arrive?

This brings us to another problem in the movie. Many unimportant elements such as the random couple are focused on too much in this movie. The movie focuses on the couple's attempt at love-making for a few minutes which made me think that perhaps these are two other important characters in what could be a separate plot. But nope. They are just simply secondary characters who are never really focused on again; meaning the need to show them at all is simply pointless. In a café scene, we are forced to sit through the orders of four random customers before Johnny comes into the scene! What is the point? Add to this the countless establishing shots in between more important scenes and it's fair to say this movie focuses too much on what shouldn't be focused on.

This review could go on forever because there is a lot to say about this movie. And none of it is positive. However negative this review may seem though, this movie has actually given me one of the most joyful movie-going experiences in my life. I would pay over and over again just to see this movie. It is full of unintentional laughs because of its bad direction, terrible acting thanks to our star Tommy Wiseau and the unforgettable music. And for that, I want to thank Tommy for giving us a perfect example of not only everything a movie should never be; a good lesson to filmmakers and audiences alike, but also for giving us one of the best unintentional comedies of all time. I recommend this movie for a good time, and a good time only. Definitely a movie worth paying for if it is playing in your city.

review_title: This movie is like the world's best inside joke

review_detailed_main: As the 500th review, I have to say the movie is so bad that it's good. There. Move along.

I rate it 2 stars because "The Room" is definitely the worst movie of all time but meantime it is the best bad movie ever. It is so bad that so turns out so entertaining, I've watched it a few time and I'm still enjoying it. So many things gone wrong in this movie, turns out to be a special cult film that I love so much. I'm amazed how Tommy Wiseau managed to fail in this movie. "The Room", definitely a must watch.

review_title: This film is funny...when it's trying to be serious
review_detailed_main:
Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" centers around a man named Johnny (Tommy Wiseau). Johnny works at a bank, and he is engaged to a beautiful young woman named Lisa (Juliette Danielle). Lisa is unfaithful to Johnny, claiming he is boring. Lisa begins to bed Johnny's best friend, Mark (Greg Sestero). That's all really.

This film defines bad filmakeing, a bad script, bad actors, bad acting, everything. This one isn't exactly on par with Battlefield: Earth, this one is at least enjoyable. It is funny through it's stupidity. When this was first seen, most likely by the critics, laughed at it. Out of embarrassment, Tommy Wiseau claimed it was a Black Comedy. It was marketed as a Black Comedy. That's kind of like making "Inception", and then releasing it as a chick flick. Acting was very paralyzed, Every time there was more than two people in the room, one of them would say "I have to get going". Everyone is always coming in and out of Johnny's apartment, Lisa's mother makes a comment about how "it's like Grand Central Station". People are constantly looking directly at the camera, Kyle Vogt, one of Johnny's friends, does this excessively. Almost all of Johnny's diologue is ad libbed in to the final print, he constantly looks like a fish.

All in all, The Room is a terrible movie. I gave it a two because it is hilarious to watch and make fun of. 2/10

I had seen all memes and heard all jokes about this movie and was determined to see it free because I wasn't going to spend a dime on it.
