When I finally viewed it was I saw was an absolute train wreck of a movie with a narcissist at the helm. It is painful to watch and the sad part is that you will never get that time back.

review_title: The Room is infamous for a reason
review_detailed_main: It is very rare for a film to have such notoriety that it is considered one of the worst films of all time yet there is an Oscar Winning film about the making of said bad movie. Sure, we had Ed Wood (1994), an Oscar Winning film about the king of bad film-making, but that is about it. Tommy Wiseau will always be one of the most interesting men in entertainment history. His backstory is sketchy and no one really knows anything about him. I wonder if he meant to make a film so horrible or was it an accident. It's been said that he called it a drama until the internet collectively dismissed it a serious movie. Wiseau cast himself as Johnny, a banker from San Francisco, who is in love with girlfriend Lisa (Juliette Danielle). Lisa is bored of the relationship and has an affair with Johnny's friend Mark (Greg Sestero). Johnny for the longest is oblivious as to what is going on around him and he desperately wants to keep Lisa in his life and marry her. There is also a young man named Denny who follows Johnny and Lisa around and has a drug habit that the others aren't aware of until almost the end of the film. The story sounds like a basic romantic drama, sure, but it is filled with painfully odd and unintentionally funny scenes. There are extremely long sex scenes where we get to see a little more than we need to see if Wiseau. This film is the very definition of absurd and many people love it for that reason, but honestly when I sat down to watch the whole film I was kind of bored. I had seen the infamously funny and bad scenes online beforehand, and most of the film includes scenes like that, but it's actually a little boring in my opinion. That being said, I think Wiseau is a genius in a way.

review_title: "You Runnin' the Beta Breakers This Year?"
review_detailed_main:
10 stars, no question, and I'm not being facetious. In its own unique genre of film (and it may be the only specimen in its genre), this movie reigns supreme. It's challenging to describe The Room. Yes, it is a terribly made movie, from every possible angle considered. And yes, it is terrible in a hilarious fashion, due in part to Johnny's extraordinary appearance, timing of delivery, accent, facial expressions, etc. What makes it better than other "bad-funny" movies, though, and even better than many "real" movies (yes), is that it excavates a small permanent space for itself in your brain upon the first viewing. You will be morbidly intrigued by producer/writer/director/lead actor Tommy Wiseau, not to mention his surrounding cast, and you will have many questions about the film. These questions will remain unanswered even upon repeated viewings. So you will scour the internet for anything you can find on Tommy or his film. His interviews will confuse you further. Every time he speaks, his words are so complex with oddities that you seriously don't know what to laugh at first. Tommy IS Johnny, or so it appears. This will lead to somewhat of an obsession, which is fine, as the film's cult following will welcome you. You will tell your friends about it, and each home screening will draw a larger crowd, but sometimes you will crave a solitary viewing late at night. And in some cases, you will even attend a public screening with a group of friends at your local theater tomorrow, with Tommy himself in attendance.

Not many movies have this kind of impact, be it intentional or accidental. And that brings up another important question--was this movie a truly naive attempt at film, resulting in a purely accidental masterpiece? Or is it a masterfully crafted parody, so perfect in its subtlety that it masks Wiseau's wry comic ambition? You will ponder this question incessantly, thus exalting the movie to a platform of philosophical debate. Are we laughing at Tommy or is he laughing at us laughing at him? And if we are laughing AT him, does this make it a failure and/or make us mean spirited? Many comedies fail to make us laugh this hard at all. So regardless of how the laughs are achieved, this movie is undeniably a comedic success. Maybe we are just laughing at the movie's uncanny achievement and not at Tommy personally? And if the joke is on us, is it still funny? If this is the case, it's a brilliant satire of bad movies. Tommy wins either way. Perhaps this is the next frontier of comedy. Hiring rare, eccentric amateurs like Tommy to make serious films, and thereby effortlessly creating comedic gold. It'll be the next wave of reality TV.

But for now, believe the hype and just see The Room. It generates the same personal reaction of awe and wonder that is usually reserved for the great classics of cinema. It is both entertaining and mind bending, in ways you'd never expect.

review_title: This film made no sense whatsoever, and that's what makes it a disasterpiece!

review_detailed_main: A misunderstood work of art, it deserved to win an Oscar.

review_title: A carnival of bizarre dialogue and shonky acting held together by a mystifying plot.

review_detailed_main:
Things I love about this movie: -Tommy Wiseau resembles an uglier more disfigured version of Frankenstein's Monster -All the sets are made out of popsicle sticks -Every actor is a washed up former porn actor...Including the 75 year old grandma -The 5 lead male characters are unable to throw a football more than two feet -The 12 year old boy from The Brady Bunch is a hardcore heroin dealer -Everyone at all times "has to go" in the middle of important conversation or just seconds after they entered scene. -The "seductress" who is "so beautiful" is actually a hippopotamus with fake tits in a blonde wig -The grandma is the biggest gold digger in the game (BEWARE!) -Somehow an absolute imbecile numbskull rètárdé like Johnny went from being a hotel bus boy to a high powered extremely wealthy banker in the matter of 5 years -All the horrendous clothes Johnny wears are 8 sizes too big, wrinkled, and ill fitting

It's hard to take the film seriously when the main character is a disfigured Frankenstein with lopsided shoulders, a melted-wax-sculpture face, and speaks like a molasses monster. How can this man go the entire movie without moving one muscle in his face besides his mouth. On top of his physical attributes, Johnny may be the worst dressed human being in the universe.

The film is as if an alien read "American Culture for Dummies," wrote a script overnight, translated the script from Native Alien Language to English, and then neglected to have anyone look over and proofread the script. Every line in the film is a mixture of a cliche and nonsense.

"I would like a large pizza half canadian bacon, half pineapple pesto, light on the cheese" WTF kind of pizza is that. "Honey would you like pizza?" "Ehh not really, whatever" "Great, cus I ordered Pizza :)" WhyTF you smiling when he said he didn't care for the pizza???.... *Pizza mysteriously shows up on table within 1 minute and its a SMALL CHEESE ONLY PIZZA no toppings in sight.

How to write this script: 1. Buy a book full of cliches 2. Cut out every cliche in the book and put all the pieces of paper in a hat 3. Blindly pick the cliches out of the hat one by one, and put them all in a row 4. Go through every cliche and switch 2 random words in that cliche to words that don't make sense 5. Congratulations you just wrote The Room

BTW WhyTF is this move called "the room" that has absolutely NO significance AT ALL. My guess is that the entire film was shot in one room that's how bad the sets are...

I thought i was watching a really shitty 90s porno or those HBO late night series i don't know what else to say with the money they spent they could have made something great this just felt like a bunch of actors thrown into a room and told to just wing it so bad but i tell everyone just watch it once to know what not to ever do if you ever decide to make a movie that being said prop to Tommy Wiseau for never apologizing and actually making it happen the dream of making a movie witch is a lot more then most people can say and for that your my hero man good luck with all!

The revival theater/playhouse near where I live is screening a 20th anniversary showing of this movie where they are charging $10 a ticket. Instead of going to that show, I found the DVD at the library for free.

So, where to start? The trivia entries for this title make for very interesting reading. While the end result seems like a project a group of friends did on a lark as an extended take on an SNL skit, the methods used for production (shooting on video and 35mm simultaneously), Tommy Wiseau's almost Kubrick-ian style of takes after takes after takes, and the fact that a simple film like this took six months to shoot means Tommy is talking out of his a%& when he said he "wanted" to make a bad-good movie from the word go.

Still, it's also good that he made lemonade out of a lemon by participating in midnight showings and accepts his status as a modern day Ed Wood.

Yes, there are so many dangling plot threads one could knit a sweater, and what's up with the guys in tuxes playing football? But it does have a nice score though, and apparently Tommy knew someone who could play piano well.

Cinematically, the most competent part occurs at the end with a nice montage scene while the music hits a crescendo. Also, while it's thoroughly bad from the opening credits until the very end, it's entertaining and watchable, and that is huge feat even if Tommy achieved it by accident.

What more can be said about The Room? Notorious for being one of the worst films ever made, it's received a second wind as a cult classic and to many qualifies as a so bad it's good flick.

I half agree with that assessment. Yes there are famously hilarious moments such as the flower store and the football in the alleyway scene. However, there are also way too many boring scenes that aren't funny or entertaining.

The dialogue is bizarre, it makes you wonder if the script was written by aliens. The acting is also terrible, although the amateur actors that fill out the cast look like Marlon Brando compared to Tommy Wiseau. Anytime Tommy enters a scene he brings an element of chaos, as if truly anything could happen next.

As ridiculous as he is, this movie wouldn't be remembered if it weren't for Tommy. He is the only reason this is worth watching. The element of an overconfident, ego-driven weirdo thinking he's making some masterpiece is what makes this movie so irresistible.

Greetings from Lithuania.

I won't going to tell anything new that wasn't said about "The Room" (2003) a cult movie, "Citizen Kane" of awful movies. The only reason i picked it up is because of "The Disaster Artist" (2017) - an upcoming movie about creation of this "masterpiece".

"The Room" is hilariously bad - this is what happens when lead "artist" beyond the wheel without any talent tries to create something out of league. If you don't know how - maybe sometimes its better not to do instead of doing and then becoming a joke target for centuries. I do admire that Tommy Wiseau at least tried to so something he was passioned about nevertheless.

Overall, there isn't much to say about this movie actually. It is hilariously bad picture, where nothing works, and its done so bad that i kinda watched scene after scene with my eyes wide open in disbelief that it can't be worse that this. This picture is funny in how it is bad, and that is the best one can say about this trashy little picture.

"You are tearing me apart Lisa. O hi Denny. I did not hit her, I did naaught. O hi, Mark. So anyway, how is your sex life? O hi, Claudette. Don't touch me, mautherfaucka. O hi Mike. Ha ha ha, what a story, Mark. Let's go eat, haaah? O hi doggy!" Wow, this film contains more memorable one-liners than The Big Lebowski. And wow, this character talks like he took lessons from Schwarzenegger and Stallone's School of English. So yeah, it's not hard to see why this film became a pretty big cult favorite. It's not often you see a film that is so bad. The captain of this ship is director/ producer/ writer/ executive producer and main actor Tommy Wiseau. Well, we don't have to spend a lot of words to describe the acting- part, seeing the guy can't even talk properly. And seeing the acting of all the other actors, it's safe to say Wiseau is as good as an actor as he is as a director.

But Wiseau probably sucks the most as a writer. I mean, has anyone ever seen something so incredibly stupid? Characters come and go, people talk about stuff out of nowhere and nothing seems to make any sense. The entire movie Wiseau and his friends (and a weird kid that should join forces with the kid from Burial Ground: Nights of Terror) just throw a ball, while his boring girlfriend is having boring talks with her boring mother about boring stuff. Wow, it's too bad this film only lasts for 90 minutes, I wanted to see more.

review_title: Terrible movie, but funny as hell

review_detailed_main:
As a stand alone movie, casting aside all thoughts of 'its so bad its good', this is worth a one star. Get a copy of the book 'The disaster Artist', which as a book deserves 7 stars. Put them together, and you have a world of 10 star entertainment.

I started with the book, written by Greg Sestero, who is a close friend of the star, producer and writer, of this vanity project of a movie, Tommy Wiseau. One chapter in and I thought, I've got to see this movie, it sounds horrendous!

So, two weeks later ( I am savouring the journey), reading a chapter or two, watching a few scenes...rinse and repeat.

You are transported into the bizarre world of the underbelly of the American film industry, hand in hand with a truly awful young actor, but talented writer, (Greg Sestero) and the strangely mysterious, and rich, Tommy Wiseau.

The movie on its own is probably worth a watch, if you can embrace the awfulness? Then it can be hilariously bad, especially viewed with like minded friends , and/or alcohol.

Apparently the book has been made into another movie 'The Disaster Artist'.

A cynical voice in the back of my head is asking, what if this is some big scam? A fictional book, written in order to botch together some cheap, deliberately bad movie and create a cult classic, then sell the book rights off to a proper film company?

I know, it sounds ridiculous. But that is where my head is at, and I'm just halfway through the book, and less than half the movie. But I don't care, just enjoying the ride.

review_title: I still don't know what to think -

review_detailed_main: It is hard to rate films like this one. This is the best-worst good-bad movie, if i rate it for the quality it is a 1/10 but then i can not give it that rate beacause watching it is so much fun! On the other hand, if i rate it a 10/10 i feel bad for giveing such a terrible product a high rating so i must settle somewhere in the middle.

review_title: Probably the worst movie I have ever seen in its entirety
review_detailed_main:
It's hard to describe in words how bad this movie really is. This is one of those things that you must personally experience to believe. Objectively, this movie does not deserve anything above 1/10, but since on my scale 1/10 represents absolutely unwatchable crap I couldn't force myself to endure, unfortunately I have to rate it

2/10

The movie is as bad and as cringe as anyone says it is. And that's what makes it such a beauty. Extremely bad script written by the man himself to which all the actors adhere to by the letter, people entering and exiting the set with no explanation and everything is just out of place and horrendous. It's a masterpiece because of all of these things. If you need something to cringe at and laugh about, please watch. This is a terrible, terrible joke, and by joke I mean in its literal sense. Laughing all the way through.

Do yourself a favour and read the Trivia section of this movies page, it'll make it more fun.
It might be an atrocity, but it's one of the most significant and entertaining films of the 2000s. I recommend it to anyone seeking expressions of truly unique filmmaking.

At first glance, this is just one of the worst films I've seen but then on thinking further there are a lot of small and intricate reasons that makes it even worse. From all the backstory I've heard till now, I can only think that Tommy Wiseau isn't mentally stable. I can easily see that why The Disaster Artist could be great. Usually, in such bad films, they include sex scenes for attracting viewers and that works in the case of most B movies. A significant achievement of The Room must be the multiple sex scenes that aren't remotely arousing even with enough nudity. I hope in future I will get a chance of watching this film in one of those midnight screenings where the viewers throw spoons to the screen, otherwise never revisiting this abomination.

God! This movie is beyond bad!. Honestly I have no words that could explain what the hell happened. Now the star of this s*** storm is none other then the one! The only! Tommy Wiseau!! Who clearly did not have a f**king clue what he was doing!

The story is absolutely jank! ( jank is a English term for dog s**t basically). People just don't act like that I don't care what planet your from Tommy. The characters? I couldn't tell you honestly!. Oh god and the acting! If you can call it acting, f**k me!. Tommy is the king of bad acting his so bad at it his actually good, I mean it, in some f**ked up way I enjoy watching how bad his acting is just to see if he can get any worse and as always, Tommy won't let you down.

Now do yourself a favour, if your not into wasting your time with bad movies then don't watch this, but if your anything like me and can enjoy and laugh at a terrible movie then by all means go and watch this, because this is by far the best of the best when it comes to bad movies, you won't stop laughing.

Although I can take some enjoyment out of this film I'm still only going to give it a 1/10 as it still is a bad movie and anything higher would insult the greater movies out there.

1/10

Mark: How was work today? Johnny: Oh, pretty good. We got a new client and the bank will make a lot of money. Mark: What client? Johnny: I cannot tell you; it's confidential. Mark: Aw, come on. Why not? Johnny: No, I can't. Anyway, how is your sex life?

Johnny: I kill you, you bastard! Mark: You couldn't kill me if you tried. Johnny: You betrayed me! You're not good. You, you're just a chicken. Chip-chip-chip-chip-cheep-cheep.

Claudette: Everything goes wrong all at once. Nobody wants to help me. And I'm dying. Lisa: You're not dying, mom. Claudette: I got the results of the test back - I definitely have breast cancer.

Lisa: Do you want me to order a pizza? Johnny: Whatever, I don't care. Lisa: I already ordered a pizza. Johnny: You think about everything, ha ha ha.

Don't get me wrong,this movie is incredibly bad.The reason I gave it 10/10 is because it's really funny.The Room is like a cringe version of a soap opera drama.If you would play a drinking game where everybody drinks when something cringe happens you would go straight to the hospital.I really recommend seeing this movie everytime you want to watch something that have really bad reviews. It will lower your standards by 99%

review_title: Defies Aristotle's maxim 'A Whole is what has a Beginning, Middle and an End'
review_detailed_main:
One thing I can say after watching 'The Room' is that the Tom Wiseau made absolutely no effort to bring any sort of coherence to his screenplay. This looked like the first draft of the screenplay with no editing or changes done to it at all. I didn't see any beginning to it, the middle was a turkey while the ending was even more frightening.

Even Tom cannot explain the bizarre scenes where the male characters play with the ball? Or why Tom is so fascinated with the bridge? Or why did Tom's character Mark feel that Lisa had not had sex with him for a while when two out of the first three scenes were of their love making (which includes probably the scariest scene in film history: two repeated shots of Tom's butt when he is humping). Or why Lisa isn't happy with Tom? Or why was this movie even made? What annoys me is that Tom Wiseau called this a black comedy, when this movie barely is a film. I cannot really categorize this as a feature film as it does not deserve the recognition. I can only suggest a change – rename it as 'The Party' because the last few shots of the party scene is so memorable in its ineptitude and slipshodness that.. I'm speechless.

My Rating: 0 / 10

This movie is a true masterpiece. It's not for everyone. I personally loved it and thought it was hilarious. So many great lines and mad respect for what he had done. 10/10. If you understand the concept and goal of the movie you will appreciate it more. People say it has a cult following, not sure about that but could see how it would. We thoroughly enjoyed this film and are surprised to see a score of under 4. The entire concept is just mind blowing to me and a truly appreciate the art of it. If you never watched it because of the score, give it it a try. You might be surprised, you just never know.

review_title: It's awful but we all love it
A Confusing, Dark, and Wonderful Mess.
The Room: What more to say...
review_detailed_main:
The Room has such a reputation of being one of the worst movies ever made by the infamous Tommy Wiseau. However I really disagree. I've seen so many bad movies (The Stuff, Birdemic 1 & 2) that makes me want to pull my own hair out but there's something about this movie that makes you learn things, especially about filmmaking. It teaches you the values of what to avoid and how NOT to go down Wiseau's route. The cinematography and lighting is pretty good but unfortunately my greatest criticism is Wiseau's input on the overall film i.e. directing, writing and even starring as the legendary Johnny. There are so many things about 'The Room' that simply doesn't make sense (lines of dialogue and even the plot). Mark's bizarre decisions in life, Lisa's motive to ruin people's lives and even choices of what to actually say like "Did you get the promotion" "Nah" "You didn't get it did you?".

The summarise it up. I would recommend 'The Room' to everyone simply because no one has ever seen anything like this before for it's 'originality'. It's not the worst film ever made, but I bet once you witness the magic, you'll never want to witness it ever again.

review_title: The Passion of Tommy: The Movie
review_detailed_main: After multiple viewings of The Room there is a sense of passion that springs from the film and I'm not talking about the films numerous, god awful sex scenes. I'm talking about the passion that a director has for his film. You can criticise Tommy Wiseau's acting, script writing and ability to act like a human being but at the end of the day he set out to make and film and he did. His final film isn't the drama that he wanted but watching it you can see how he wanted some of his scenes to just ooze tradegy and raw emotion (Your'e Tearing Me Apart Lisa!!) but Wiseau's execution fails to deliver this. The Room is not the worst film ever made but it sure as hell isn't the best either. It is just one of the most unique films ever made and viewings of it are more memorable and fun than viewings of other more mainstream films.

review_title: Murphy's Law in full effect: everything that could go wrong, went wrong
review_detailed_main:
It's hard to add anything new to a movie that has been described as possibly the best worst movie ever made. It has been said to resemble a depiction of humanity as done by an alien who watched only 24 hours of our television, while others praise it as the best unintentional comedy ever made. Whatever the case may be, everyone who has ever used the term 'worst movie ever' on Godzilla, Waterworld or a Star Wars prequel/sequel should be forced to watch this movie and reconsider. Opinions vary on whether The Room is retrospectively brilliant in that it stumbled upon important themes of friendship, fate and betrayal, but it is generally agreed upon that its merits, bad or good, actively contribute to the fun of watching it. There's no better proof that entertainment can be independent of quality than this movie.

In the amusing 'making of' movie The Disaster Artist, it is postulated that writer/actor/producer/director Tommy Wiseau survived a major accident years before he started his magnum opus that is The Room. I am extremely curious to know if this is what happened in real life, because it would explain a lot. As a student I learned that paintings and drawings made by patients with mental disorders could often be used to perfectly exemplify what their ailments were. If this comparison extends to all art in general, including film, then The Room is a look into an extremely fractured mind. This should be mandatory viewing for every medical student who ever considers neurology as a major.

Because let's not fool ourselves: this must be the most disjointed and inconsequential movie ever made. Wiseau claims to have wanted to make a movie about 'human nature', and it looks like he decided to go through every type of human action and feeling imaginable in a mere 90 minutes, without any narrative, logical or dramatic cohesion. Normally, a plot is a course of events where one occurrance initiates another, but most of what happens in The Room is a non-sequitur. Of all the misery, joy and ill-defined stuff that happens over the duration of this movie, only a fraction seems to have any long-lasting effect on the plot or characters in one way or another. Drugs, disease, arguments, violence, love, sex and alcohol all pass by for the sake of human drama, characters come and go, but they are often forgotten by the next scene (or even in the same scene), to be never mentioned again or no longer be of significance. You could effectively edit out the entire second act without any negative bearing on the film's final act.

This is the kind of film in which people don't seem to be doing anything, yet they claim to be busy; where mothers in 2003 still urge their daughters to marry for financial stability rather than love; where one of the actors was no longer available, so they gave his lines to a completely new character without any introduction, and where there is always time for a game of football without any symbolic or metaphorical meaning. The royal amount of sex scenes almost begs a comparison with a lot of soft-porn B-movies from a decade before, but even those had better writing, acting and directing. As hard as it is to believe, there was even supposed to be a subplot about vampires that didn't make it. Too bad, because it would have made this movie brilliant in its failure over multiple movie genres.

Coupled with his complete lack of talent in telling a story, Wiseau doesn't seem to understand what natural dialogue sounds like. Almost all conversations contain something ridiculous, overblown, pompous, inappropriate or nonsensical. Much of the movie's cult appeal comes from endless repetitions, e.g. that Lisa looks beautiful, Johnny and Mark are best friends, the world is treacherous and people don't want to talk about stuff. But the true gold is in such classic quotes like "Oh hi, Mark!", "You are tearing me apart!" or "Why? Why is this happening to me?" Granted, it doesn't help that there is hardly a decent actor in this film, but the bad script and even worse directing of the actors gives them very little to work with. Everybody seems to be going through a mood swing every two lines, and displays at least 10 different states of mind over the course of the film. Characters constantly contradict themselves or seem to have an extremely short-term memory. If there is one positive thing I can say about this movie, it is that the only things sillier than the acting and dialogues are the cheesy lyrics to the songs that accompany the gratuitious and protracted sex scenes (such as the text "you are my rose" endlessly repeated).

The only job where Wiseau fails even worse than as a writer or director is as an actor. The cult value of his portrayal cannot be overstated. He almost looks and sounds like a heavily drugged and sedated combination of Gru from Despicable Me with Loki from Thor, who is trying to impersonate Pauly Shore. It has to be seen to be believed. His final scene and the movie's finale is the stuff of talentless overacting legends. If you haven't rolled off the couch by then, you'll never will.

In conclusion, it is quite irrelevant to say that as a film, The Room makes every mistake in the book and is the most unlikely culmination of bad decisions that may have ever been made, since this is exactly the reason for what makes it so alluring. You can have discussions about guilty pleasures, but as long as there is no concensus on what constitutes great art, those won't be very meaningful. If cabinets made from wreckage and dresses made from meat can be forms of art, why not this dubious cinematographic experiment? Something so uniquely bad comes by only once in a generation. So is The Room a good movie? Not by a long shot. Does it make for interesting art? That's the idea.

review_title: Quite possibly the worst thing I've ever seen
review_detailed_main:
Ne day when I was at work, I was having a conversation with a coworker about bad movies. The "best worst movie" Troll 2 (known internationally as Goblins) came up. He mentioned a movie called The Room. I told him that the movie "Best Worst Movie" was made about Troll 2 and has the distinction of being "the worst". He then went on to tell me about the (then) upcoming movie The Disaster Artist, which chronicles the making of this shit storm.

He told me about the movie itself and I was compelled to see it. I've read about it on IMDb and Wikipedia and it sounded awful. I made it my mission to see this. I finally procured a copy and I'm now indulging in it as I write this. Where can I possibly begin?

There's a sex scene just after the four-minute mark. Everything else is almost laugh-out-loud bad. The acting, the music, the grunting and moaning. Everything. It's difficult to write this because the writing in this is beyond anything I've ever experienced. Calling it atrocious would be kind. To top it off, the camera goes out of focus periodically. Apparently, nobody bothered to check the lens, so this is a thing.

My God. Seventeen minutes in and so far there's been nothing but some minor dialogue and two sex scenes. Both scenes have horrible music and at the second one, the actors voices are dubbed over the music. You hear HIM say "Oh Lisa", but they're KISSING. This is like a bad porn movie from the early eighties (not the sex, the music).

I have over an hour left of this appalling film. Check this out...I LITERALLY have to use a thesaurus because of how mind-boggling terrible this is. I'm pausing it at times to get my thoughts straight. Back to the bad sex scene. The lines are forced and the "acting" is wooden.

Wow. Fuck me.

I appreciate Tommy Wiseau wanting to write, direct, produce, and star in his own movie. Independent filmmakers are among the people that I look up to the most. The greatest of them all is Roger Corman. He is (as far as I'm concerned) the Patron Saint of independent filmmakers. He's produced over 400 films, directed over 50, and turned a profit on almost every one (give or take a dozen or so). Tommy Wiseau is the modern day Ed Wood. That's actually an insult to Mister Wood because at least he had vision. If he had the budget that he needed, his films would have been science fiction masterpieces and not the schlockfests that they are.

Robert Rodriguez (like Tommy Wiseau) financed his first film independently. That was a little film called El Mariachi. That got so popular that it spawned two sequels (Desperado and Once Upon A Time In Mexico). Robert Rodriguez is FUCKING AMAZING. I may not be a fan of everything he does, but HE KNOWS WHAT HE'S DOING!!!!!

Fuck! Only twenty minutes in.

Okay, who in their right mind orders a pizza with "half Canadian bacon and pineapple and half with artichoke and pesto, light on the cheese"? Do these people even know what pizza is? An argument can be made for the bacon/pineapple, but who puts pesto on pizza? Maybe it's a thing and I'm being too critical.

Apparently, much of the audio was dubbed which leads to the audio being out of sync.

What the hell is this movie about? So far, it's been her having sex with two different guys, some pizza, and some horrific dialogue.

Sadly, for me, the BEST part of this Godawful movie is Juliette Danielle. She's very pretty and I like her topless scene. Too bad the THREE sex scenes in the first HALF HOUR were unnecessary . Being objective about the plot (from what I could gather), Lisa and Tommy are dating. He's her financial security and in line for a promotion. She no longer loves him and one day she gets him drunk and complains to her mother that he got drunk (he did) and that he hit her (he didn't). There's also this annoying kid named Denny who shows up at unnecessary times.

It looks like it's supposed to be about relationships, but there's NOTHING cohesive about this movie. There's a scene where Denny runs afoul of a drug dealer and the interaction with everyone is reprehensible. Lisa and her mom suddenly show up off camera and Johnny takes the drug dealer to the police, but the time it would take to actually do that isn't represented properly. He comes back about a minute later.

The CLOSEST thing I can get to a plot is as follows: Johnny and Lisa are lovers. He comes home and they have sex. Johnny's ward Denny wants to hang out with them, but they send him away so they can have sex. After he leaves for the day, she calls his best friend Mark and seduces him and they sleep together. After he comes home, they drink and have pizza, and then have sex again.

Lisa complains to her mother that she no longer loves Johnny and gets yelled at because she can't support herself. On a rooftop, Denny gets into an altercation with a drug dealer that gets interrupted by Johnny and Mark. Later on that rooftop, Denny confesses his love for Lisa to Johnny. Johnny says that he trusts her, meanwhile Lisa brags to her friend about how she's sleeping with Mark. The way people show up in this is like a bad sitcom. In fact, a laugh track would probably make this better.

Earlier, I said that Tommy Wiseau was in league with Ed Wood. I was incorrect. The directors that are in the same category as him are: Paul W. S. Anderson, Vincent Gallo, and the infamous Uwe Boll.

Not everyone should make movies and this is proof. It's further proof that if you don't know what you're doing, you should ask for help. There's no shame in that. Pride is a bad servant and a worse master.

I feel that this review is a bit irreverent, but that's appropriate given the fact that this movie falls about fifty yards short of making any kind of sense.

Currently, I have about a half hour left and this movie has gone nowhere. There isn't a single character that I care about. The plot tries to make it out of the jumbled mess that is this movie. Sadly, there's only been four terrible sex scenes that are forced upon us. Only two are necessary for the plot to move forward and while I appreciate nudity, it's unnecessary in this. This would have been better as a made-for-TV movie on Lifetime.

The most ironic thing about this film is that there's no aforementioned "Room". According to Tommy Wiseau, the title is meant to evoke a safe place for viewers. Realistically, the BEST place for viewers is far away from this monstrous creation.

I'm giving this 1 out of 5 reasons why you shouldn't let your curiosity get the best of you.

I'm going to briefly wax poetic, so please forgive me and hear me out. What makes a movie good? Is it the content and the artistry, or what it evokes? This movie is a terrible movie, conceptually. But I profoundly (I mean that in its original definition) enjoyed it. It has stuck with me for years. It has inspired lore and mystique around its creator. It is ultimately a subversive movie in its own right. In an era of cringe obsessed content consumers, Wiseau has outdone them with an ambivalence of intention. So many artistic decisions made in the movie are wrong, and yet they are unintentionally (perhaps?) all the RIGHT decisions to make this movie what it has become. A horrible piece of art, and what a great movie!

"In a minute, b¡tch!"

Infamously terrible film. I must admit, it's funny, but, man, is it repetitive and boring. Wiseau, who speaks English with a heavy European accent, plays a thoroughly nice and possibly retarded man who is about to marry his longtime girlfriend, Lisa. Unfortunately, Lisa is cheating on him with his best friend Mark. That's pretty much the entire plot of the movie. For 99 minutes, Wiseau stumbles around saying, "Oh hai!" to everyone he comes into contact with. Whenever he leaves Mark and Lisa alone in a room together, they start screwing. Their friends and relatives keep trying to convince Lisa to break it off with him, though none of them are good enough friends to just outright tell poor Wiseau. A couple of subplots get introduced, like Lisa's mother's cancer or Wiseau's young protégé's dealings with drugs, but they get dropped because the affair is just so damned interesting. The movie's sort of interesting psychologically, though pretty simplistic: Wiseau obviously based the script on his own insecurities (whether a woman ever cheated on him or not), and the film basically contemplates why he either can't get or can't keep a chick. Look up the funny moments on Youtube, but leave the actual film for the braver viewers amongst us.

Not for good reasons though.

review_title: From LasVegas July27 2004 screening at Palms Hotel Casino

review_detailed_main:
The Room is the movie based on the book and theater piece by Tommy Wiseau, American immigrant and retail park manager, who wants to immortalize his romantic life, sexual hatreds and obsessions into a dark, twisted drama of betrayal. Its also a film that's so badly acted and produced that its generally hilarious.

There's nothing really "cool" about the Room, as some cult movies actually are, its just a story of an honest, though somewhat creepy looking finance worker, who's almost-plump suburban girlfriend Lisa has plans to run off with the guy upstairs. The rest of the cast is: Lisa's mother, a vengeful sexual predator with breast cancer and Denny, a wholesome American sitcom teen that wants to watch Johnny (Wiseau's on screen character) and Lisa having sex. Denny's also got some underhanded goings-on with a local thug involving narcotics, something that unravels dramatically on their buildings rooftop where much of the films conflict scenes get especially fiery.

Two points: this movie is filled with SEX, also its FUNNY AS SH*T, because the cast can't act and the plot points are all confused or very badly telegraphed.

Its also worth 'splaining that Denny is sort of a surrogate "little brother" to Johnny, as he has no family of his own. Each scene sets Johnny up as selfless, idealistic, and an nurturing, except for one major event where he tries to fry Lisa for framing him for domestic abuse.

The movie cost a freakin' bundle: writer/producer/director/star Wiseau commissioned a steamy R&B track for the movie, and his crew an assorted costs crept into the millions, plus billboard advertising to promote his project. Clearly, they didn't have the basic technical know-how for getting the best from their equipment; the most telling sign being the visible interlacing throughout the film.

I won't spoil the ending, but I can add that personally, when I first found this film, I laughed uncontrollably for about a week and a half. Maybe a year or so later I returned to the movie, and it appeared to be littered with filler scenes, except for a few great one-liners. In a sense the film satirizes the fascination with love, betrayal and the sacred rite of bland, secure suburban fulfillment that's at the heart of a lot of TV drama and soap story lines. Its a funny movie, but mostly by accident apparently.

A computer game and paperback novel detailing the films troubled production is available also.

review_title: How Did This Movie Get Made?
review_detailed_main:
Picture this scenario: A man of mixed European background who has made a living in the U.S churning out the kind of soft-core porn movies they show on Cinemax every night decides to invest his life savings into a film that will prove his genius to Hollywood. In a burst of alcohol-fueled energy he bats out a script called "The Room" in one night. Then, casting the script with mostly porn movie actors and himself, he produces, directs, shoots, edits and releases his 'masterpiece' without ever deviating from that first draft.

That's what this thing looks like---the product of a decidedly minor talent with a full blown ego who either fired every person who tried to point out the "garbage in, garbage out" rule to him from day one, or who just hired a bunch of people who didn't care and were just happy to get a paycheck.

And don't buy into the "so bad it's good' excuse with this one. It's so bad, it's literally impossible to remain focused on it. It's why remote controls were invented.

To sum up this steaming pile if cinematic achievement; It's 99 minutes of your life you will never get back.

If we had to choose the king of trash movies, that title would probably go to The Room. It's so horrible you can't help but love it. And just wait till you hear some background information! Tommy Wiseau apparently financed this movie by selling leather jackets imported from Korea. An actor decided to leave the crew while filming, so they picked another person to finish shooting his scenes; because of that, we have two completely different people playing the same character. Doesn't this sound promising? The Room tells us about the life of Johnny (Tommy Wiseau), a successful banker who lives with his soon-to-be wife Lisa (Juliette Danielle), has many friends and is loved by everyone. Unfortunately, his girlfriend doesn't love him any more and is having an affair with his best friend Mark (Greg Sestero), who is constantly battled between his desire to be with Lisa and not wanting to hurt Johnny.

Everybody agrees that nothing about this movie works. The story is recycled, the acting is bad and the cinematography is not worth mentioning. Certain scenes and characters are put into the movie for no apparent reason, except for making it last longer. The dialogue is repetitive and predictable. I guess you're supposed to sympathise with Johnny, because he's such a good, naive person being betrayed by the two people he loves the most – but you don't, because all the feelings in this movie are just words. But, after you get over the first minutes of confusion in the beginning, The Room is guaranteed to make you laugh really hard.

Besides, this movie is a cult. Who could possibly forget the roof scene, in which Johnny talks to himself and later realises Mark is also present? The famous phrase "oh hi Mark" is used in this scene. Or all those inexplicable random football tossings, that once happened while the characters were in tuxedos? And of course, the flower shop, one of the most confusingly useless scenes in movie history. All this can be pretty frustrating to watch, but you shouldn't take it too seriously. If you don't, at the end you might even want to see it again sometime, maybe just to have a few good laughs and to remind yourself that it can always be worse – you could have been born as Tommy Wiseau!

Rating:2/10 Read more at http://passpopcorn.wordpress.com/

review_title: 1 cannot describe the pain i feel

review_detailed_main:
This movie is really bad. The acting is poor and it is just not funny.

DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE. Unless of course, you really want to see just how bad movies can go.

Directing 1/10 Story 1/10 Acting 0.1/10

Overall Rating 0.1/10

I don't even know why this movie was made. It is absolute rubbish. If Tommy Wiseau or whatever is name is tries to make another movie, please shoot him. I hope that this movie eventually burns in hell because that's what this movie makes you want to do. Never have I ever seen a piece of trash.

I felt the need to clarify my 1 star review, considering The Room is in my top 20 favorite films of all time.

Truly unforgettable. Performances that will leave you breathless. From laughter.

A cinematic marvel that has brought me countless hours of joy.

A script of pure insanity filled to the brim with memorable quotes.

The script, with the off kilter performances, and it's attempt at cinematic framing all come together to create...

The greatest bad movie of all time.

Cliche as it is, it is the Citizen Kane of bad films.

Side note, it's had a good track record for date nights. I don't think I've shown this movie to anyone and they didn't laugh.

I tried to watch this thing for about 20 minutes but it just kept getting worse and worse, so I ended up fast forwarding the whole thing. The acting is horrible, the dialog is awful, the sets are bad...etc... so why watch it at all? I am so sorry I wasted those 20 minutes of my life. I will never get them back. I hope no one else makes the mistake of ever seeing this. What was the director thinking? I honestly do not know. There are bad movies out there, that are so bad that they become good. This is not one of them. This movie is just bad. It cannot even be called a movie. I tried to see the value of this film, but I just cannot understand what the director was thinking. It seemed like an interesting plot, but the development of the story fails miserably.

This is not a movie you watch for the acting, the writing, the cinematography, the screenplay, or the score. You watch this to laugh at its writing, cinematography, th screenplay, the writing and its score. You watch this while you're 40% drunk and would laugh more at dumbass situations rather than actual jokes. You watch this to better appreciate The Disaster Artist, the Movie about the making of this movie, which was Oscar nominated. And most importantly, you watch this for Tommy Wiseau. The Legend. The Genius. The Most meta-comedian in Hollywood. You would hardly find any movies that are meta-funny these days. Just go ahead and watch it, and watch the Disaster Artist next.

review_title: The Website Told Me To Review, So....
review_detailed_main:
I've never heard of this movie until I tried watching Adult Swim on April Fools Day, and this movie was showing as a joke. I only watched it for a few minutes but what I saw was the "sex in the belly button scene" and I thought I suddenly had late night Cinemax and the channels flipped on me.

I never knew what it was until the Nostalgia Critic reviewed it and I was too curious for my own good so I Netflixed it.

Yup. It's pretty bad... but it's one of the funniest movies I've ever seen! Seriously, watch it! But not by yourself. Get some of your buddies together, drink a few beers and laugh your @$$ off!

I have to give Tommy Wiseau credit. Granted, he made one of the worst movies ever made and he's mentally unstable, but he sure knows how to get it seen!
A masterclass in film making. This is far and away the greatest film ever made. Emotionally and cinematically breathtaking.

review_title: It seems like a daydream of depressed Johnny
A total failure of a movie!

review_detailed_main:
This surrealist attempt of movie is disgusting. The worst thing of all time.

Plot less, ridiculously directed, the worst photography ever... everything is so bad that deserve such a under classed review as the one I'm writing in this moment.

There are a lot of bad movies which at the end are funny. I won't expend my time enumerating them. All of you know which those are.

But don't be tricked with this one. This film lets you with a great sensation of emptiness. I felt empty and sad during more than a hour after watching this piece of...

After Reading some reviews and bloc entries about the "cult" status of this "the room" and the iconic shout: "Your are tearing me apart, Lisa!" plus the intriguing factor of Tommy Wisseau I decided to give a chance to the film because I thought that, at least, the laughs would be granted. Wrong.

Not a single laugh in 90 minutes. Not a single emotion more than a progressive change of mood from apathy to depression.

Does it sound overreacted? I'll try to explain the reasons: 1-The acting of the entire cast is immeasurably bad. I don't know how much I going to live (I hope that at least enough to see another 1000 movies) but I'm sure that I'm not going to witness another acting such as crappy as this. 2-Tommy Wiseau. The first I saw his face was in a IMDb's user list and I must recognize that it captivated me. An enigmatic face, worthy of being typical evil troubled villain of a b-series bad movie. But I lost the interest for him in the very first scenes of "the room". The worst thing about his acting is he believes he is a first class performer whilst actually he is... he isn't even funny. It's a shame I can't use a better English in order to describe him 3-Was this nightmare's Budget 6 million bucks? In this moment is when I start to cry and when I feel that I would give a huge hug to Wiseau If I were to meet him someday because he's nothing more than a victim. A victim because the entire crew of the film laughed in his face. With 6000 dollars every user of IMDb with a Handy cam, a microphone, 6 Friends and a PC would have made a better experiment than this.

In conclusion, don't waste your time watching this. This film has nothing to show. Anything to remember. This is not a movie. This is not cinema.

review_title: Plan 9 is Oscar worthy compared to this nonsense
Don't let the hype fool you, this movie is AWFUL!
review_detailed_main:
After watching The Disaster Artist, which was a pretty good movie, I knew I had to watch The Room, because some friends of mine told me that The Room is so entertaining, so I gave it a shot, and I wish I didn't.

This movie is MUCH worse than people say it is, it's terrible in every way. I literally had really bad head trauma after watching the second half of this! The acting is bad, the directing is bad, the sets are bad, the editing is bad, the camera angles are bad, and the lighting is bad. And the worst part, is the writing! The dialogue is extremely atrocious that this film is excruciatingly BORING! I only laughed three times during the "YOU'RE TEARING ME APART LISA!", "LET'S TAKE HIM TO THE POLICE.", and "WHAT'S GOING ON?" that Lisa yells while Johnny and Mark try to save Denny from Chris R wanting to kill him for not giving him his money back. Everything else in the movie, I was extremely bored, annoyed, and I also got extremely sleepy that I had to eat so much food in order to stay awake! This film also has so much disgusting sex scenes that I even felt a little traumatized. Not to mention, the music is also terrible! The classical music is so obnoxious that it makes me wanna destroy my own TV, but luckily I didn't do that. Tommy Wiseau is also a terrible actor. This is literally the worst acting I've ever seen in a movie. I've never seen a movie this bad besides "Cats" (2019)

I would not recommend this movie to anyone. This is not a "So bad, it's good" movie, nor is it a black comedy or a regular or decent comedy, this is a movie that should not have been made and that should be avoided at all costs. Don't believe all the hype and support, they don't even know what a bad movie is! You wanna see a good movie about Tommy Wiseau, watch The Disaster Artist and skip this stupid movie at all costs!

This film deserves less than a 3.6/10. It deserves more like a 2.5/10!

The script is poor at best. Its storyline is lackluster. The acting is dull. It is not possible to connect with the characters since their acting skills coupled with poorly written dialogue, spells disinterest for the viewer forced to watch this mess. Sorry for the review. It's best to warn innocent, unsuspecting viewers--consider it a public service.

Realistically this movie is AWE-FULL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It's soooo BAD and it taking itself seriously makes.... Like I need to explain what every single person who's ever seen or heard of this movie knows we all know why we laugh at this movie. I'm no different except for the fact that I don't have any appreciation or respect for Tommy Wiseau after what he put Greg through while making this nightmare, I love watching the movie while not caring about the real disaster artist who dreamed up this lovable garbage. But a movie that sucks so bad to the point of laughing my ass off this hard I love it.

I think this movie is a timeless masterpiece. Why, you may ask?

The factors of a movie that make it good, if done well, are good cinematography, good acting, good writing, and good direction. I think this movie excels in every single one of those things.

The Cinematography is absolutely breathtaking. The way the camera gets blurred and shaky at random parts of the movie really gives you the FEELING of the trauma and stress that Johnny is going through, because this movie makes me feel the same way, confused, stressed, frightened.

The Acting is phenomenal and I'm stumped by the fact that none of the actors got an award for Best Performance. Tommy Wiseau's acting, especially, is absolutely stellar and 100% convincing, the way he puts absolutely no effort in any of his lines, like the "Oh Hi Mark" scene, is a creative and intuitive way of telling us about what his character is like.

The Writing is incredibly clever, and it really makes you FEEL like you are watching a movie about Aliens trying to pretend to be human. The dialogue is very consistent and totally doesn't have a million plot holes in every single scene.

Tommy Wiseau did a wonderful job at directing this movie. As I walked out of the theatre, I was looking for a bleach shop when I realised that this movie is actually a timeless masterpiece that will stay with me for a very long time. Sure, I burned the theatre down after watching this movie, but, I eventually did realize how amazing this master stroke of a movie really is. Bravo, Tom Wiseau.

review_title: One of the Best Worst Movies Ever!!!
Warning: watching THE ROOM may be hazardous to your brain cells.

review_detailed_main: And Greg and Juliette and the flower shop doggie and even the old lady. If I wrote this after my first watch, I'd of given it a 1 but Greg's wonderful book enlightened me. I'm a Roomie now. I watch it at least once a month. Each time I find something new. So much fun.

First ever full, front-to-back watch, despite being overly familiar with every last baffling line delivery and nonsensical plot point. Glad I got to experience Wiseau's seminal masterpiece on the big screen, alongside a theatre-full of audience members that seemed to know each and every frame. Slightly tiring, however, to have people laughing uproariously at a constant tempo, causing me to decide early on that this is the "so bad it's good" movie choice for boring people. It's had its time; watching this in January 2022 felt as though someone were making Chuck Norris jokes or fashioning shareable "troll-face" images - a little embarrassing. Nevertheless, I still found much of it quite funny, and it's hard not to with such a tremendous helping of incompetency on display: the stilted performances, obviously including Wiseau's own poorly-dubbed, awkwardly delivered (but in a different way every time) tour-de-force; the blatant green-screen; plot threads seemingly setup that then go nowhere (Lisa's mother had breast cancer, right?); random, unrelated establishing shots of locations that characters never visit (really gets a lot of mileage out of one clip of the Golden Gate Bridge); new people constantly appearing without introduction, then leaving just as soon (WHO IS MIKE?); the same three sets being used throughout; even the props are bizarre: stock photos of spoons framed around Johnny's home, and are they drinking Scotch topped with vodka? Needless to say, it's a bit of a mess, and certainly a monumental failure on every narrative level, if one can be so generous as to grant this film a narrative. Wiseau is the X-factor, the mysterious auteur at the centre of it all, a man whose accent is as unplaceable as his intentions, and as inexplicable as his budgetary sources. The self-aggrandisement is overwhelming, with every character insistent that "Johnny" is their best friend and the greatest guy you'll ever meet, always talking about him when he's not there, yet continuing to ruin his life regardless. The lengthy sex scenes set to borderline-parodic slow tunes are uncomfortable to sit through and indicative of the palpable male gaze behind every aspect of the production. Listening to the conversations Wiseau writes for his female stars is as enlightening as it is hilarious; in an attempt to portray some perceived, inherent unfaithfulness in women, he unwittingly reveals precisely why his relationships have likely failed in the past: he understands no one but himself (and a hyperbolically perfect version at that). Imagining what Wiseau thought he was making boggles the mind - some modern-day Greek tragedy, complete with irony and high drama, culminating in a Citizen-Kane-esque room-smashing scene; above all, a depiction of how Great Men like himself can be torn apart by all those conniving women. Therein, of course, lies the humour: the timing is so naturally comedic and the absurdity increases so surely that one cannot help but laugh at the disaster playing out on screen. It captures an odd kind of cognitive dissonance, the sense that one is watching something very closely resembling a film while so clearly not being one. That said, movies get worse than this - not much, but they do - the main theme in the score is decidedly pleasant and the camerawork, all things considered, is not the worst. (Apparently this was shot on 35mm and HD video. Simultaneously. Might as well have started a money bonfire while you're at it.) I suppose this is partially responsible for its cult status, as it's a lot more accessible than cinematic diarrhoea on the scale of, say, After Last Season. Why is it even called The Room? Perhaps a misspelling of The Roof, as they seem to spend a lot more time there than in any specific room. That's it, I'm done: rating 1/10 and moving on.
Bad acting,bad plot,all is bas,yeah i know its the best bad movie because is hillarious but is BAAAAAD

review_title: You people don't understand anything man, leave your stupid reviews in your pocket
review_detailed_main: Tommy Wiseau's 2003 masterpiece channels the influences of David Lynch's Twin Peaks multiverse, CBS' groundbreaking period drama The Big Bang Theory and daytime erotics, leading to the complete cinematic experience.

review_title: Yeah, this movie is pretty is hilariously bad!
review_detailed_main:
Director/writer/actor Tommy Wiseau has created quite a movie experience with this. The Room has become a cult hit and now is shown in theaters where people yell and laugh at the movie, and really the unintentional humor is all this thing has going for it. The acting is just awful, especially from Wiseau, the direction is strange, as is the writing and the awful soap opera synth music. Everything about this movie is laughable, so it's good people have realized this, and Mr. WIseau has made a name for himself in the Ed Wood department.

Johnny (Tommy Wiseau) is a successful banker who is engaged to his "beautiful" "future wife" Lisa (Juliette Danielle). She is cheating on Johnny for Johnny's well intentioned best friend Mark (Greg Sestero), who knows the whole situation is wrong. Also in the mix is Denny (Phillip Haldiman), a semi-retarded 18 year old who lives in the same apartment as the other characters. He gets into a pickle with a drug dealer. And Lisa's whiny mother Claudette (Carolyn Minnott) has breast cancer. And Lisa's friend and her boyfriend are making whoopee in Johnny's apartment while they are away. All these great sub-plots...none of which have any outcome on the film. Very strange!

Discontinuity is one of the biggest problems with this movie. Many sub-plots are introduced and then immediately dropped, including those mentioned above. Character traits are introduced and then forgotten, like Johnny's dislike for drinking alcohol, which is immediately ignored. Along with scripted discontinuity, there's plenty of bad editing to be found, where characters mouths don't match what they're saying, and where the characters bounce around the screen and inanimate objects move about the room. One character who is never introduced appears and begins yelling at Lisa, and the question pops up, "Who the heck is this guy?" But we never get the luxury of knowing his name. All we know is that he must be friends of theirs or something.

This movie is also notorious for it's horrible scriptwriting. Every time anybody sees anyone else they always say in a surprised way "Oh, hi (insert name here)!" This phrase must be used forty times in the movie. In addition strange and bizarre non-phrases are used, such as the ever popular phrase, "Leave your stupid comments in your pocket!" This film is riddled with nonsensical dialogue, and pointless scenes, and that's one thing that makes this such a hilarious film, is it's complete lack of sense.

Acting is another aspect that isn't this movie's strong point. Tommy Wiseau is undoubtedly the worst actor in the film, giving a bizarre droopy eyed performance where he not only gives bad readings, but makes some of the ugliest and most stupid faces you could imagine. Greg Sestero is a better actor but still not good. He seems to be a soap opera character, and reading that he has appeared in soap operas that makes sense. Phillip Haldiman's portrayal of Denny is probably second worst in the film. The character is absolutely idiotic and a complete perv, and the acting just makes the character all the more pathetic.

Despite this film's weakness (everything about it!), this is really a funny movie if you can appreciate horrible cinema. This thing is just awful start to finish, and it definitely will have you at least smirking through most of it!

My rating: BOMB out of ****. 99 mins. R for constant sexuality, language and violence.

review_title: An awkward cult movie intended for comedic viewings instead of dramatic

review_detailed_main:
OK, so I stumbled on this film masterpiece by total accident. While I was searching for new apps. on my cell phone I came upon the ugly mug of Tommy Wiseau and his deep intense stare....similar to that of man who's been hit over the head with a frying pan. From there I had to download the sound board and instantly I was hooked. I had to get this movie no matter what the cost...and like the speed of Wiseau's painful laugh I had the movie in my hands a week later.

This epic adventure takes place in San Francisco, I believe, with a background soundtrack that spins the hits from those classic 90's cine max after dark flicks. Wiseau's screen presence is similar to that of Patrick on SpongeBob SquarePants, comical and ridiculous. I'm not sure where to begin because I'm not sure if this is meant to be a serious script or one of utter illusion and embarrassment. It's random scenes and even more ridiculous classic "lines" are so out there that you can't turn it off nor do you want to recommend it to anyone because you're afraid people will think you ate crayons as a child.....a lot of crayons.

I think it can be summed up like this, The Room is a movie that you will watch to laugh, watch to cry, and watch to completely make yourself feel better that you were born on earth and you don't get fed crazy pills everyday.

review_title: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Tommy Wiseau's The Room.
review_detailed_main: The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the jokes will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also Johnny's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they're not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike The Room ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Johnny's existential catchphrase "I did not hit her! It's not true! It's bullshit, I did not hit her! I did not!... Oh, hai Mark!" which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Tommy Wiseau's genius wit unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools.. how I pity them. And yes, by the way, I DO have a "Oh hi, doggie" scene tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothing personnal kid.

Two stars is the rating I reserve for movies that are so bad, they're good. One star is for movies I loathe. I do not loathe The Room. I kind of love it. It is 'the' bad movie. Like Troll 2 and Birdemic, this film is consistently inept. And it's all thanks to one man. The incomparable Tommy Wiseau. And he is incomparable. A true auteur, Tommy funded this, his dream project, and kept it in theaters for years until the world finally relented and acknowledged its 'greatness'. The story, the writing, the direction, the acting, the set design, the 'special effects', all combine to form a perfect storm of suck. Watch it with friends, then check out some interviews with Wiseau. Also recommended: The Disaster Artist, a book about the making of the film by Greg Sestero, one of the leads.

The best comedy of the century! Tommy Wiseau ingeniously makes you believe you're watching a drama with some suspenseful elements. However, his incredible writing and directing skills actually serve to conceal his true purpose-to present us with a light, carefree, and surprising comedy!

After a 90's decade filled with comedies relying on laugh tracks, Tommy Wiseau, with his unique style, becomes an inspiration for raw comedies, free from this device, that would emerge from the first half of the 2000s onwards. (i.e. The Office, Everybody Hates Chris, Parks and Recreation and so on)

A brilliant comedy, a must-watch for anyone who loves the seventh art.

10/10.

review_title: its like an unintentional parody (which makes it 10x better)
A comedy hidden in a drama
review_detailed_main: This movie is the definition of "so bad it's actually good." The director/lead male role/writer (pretty sure he was also the writer) is trying to make a serious movie, be a serious actor, but trying way, way too hard, and the end result is this deliciously cheesy movie. It's pretty dated, which adds to the fun. There's a totally unnecessary love scene with rose petals & music that's cringe in the best way. But it's the lead guy's acting that takes the cake. Overacting at its peak! The line delivery sometimes is great ("I did not hit her! I did not! Oh hi Mark.") You just need to go into it with low expectations and be willing to embrace the cheesiness. Don't expect a serious drama. I do feel bad saying all this, because I believe the director was out to make a serious movie, and it gets shredded & laughed at. I hope that he can at least embrace the fact that although it wasn't the outcome he was maybe expecting, this is a much-loved movie because of how silly and bad it is. I'm grateful he made this film.

Few people will have watched this film without first having seen or read "The Disaster Artist" (or at least being aware of the story*). Without the context of 'star' Greg Sestero's 'making of' memoirs, "The Room" would be challenging to sit through. The film opens like a 'soft core porn' flic (reminding me of Showcase's semi-adult (and almost as unwatchable) "Red Shoe Diaries", 1992) but goes nowhere in the erotic department (although starlet Juliette Danielle shows a lot more skin than the film "The Disaster Artist" (2017) suggests). After the titillating opening scenes, the movie degenerates into a disjointed, almost plotless, tale of love, betrayal, and footballs. Having seen "The Disaster Artist" and read some of the on-line comments, I watched "The Room" with rapt attention, waiting for the iconic "Hi Mark"s, "best friend"s, neck lumps, BB guns, doggies, and (of course) footballs. This scrutiny doesn't make the movie better, but does make for interesting viewing and gives insights into how much craft must go into making a 'good movie'. Oddly, IMO some scenes might have been excellent in other circumstances (four buddies in rented tuxedos, stressed-out while waiting for a wedding to begin, retreat to an alley for an impromptu game of football could have been a memorable scene in the "The Deer Hunter" (1978)). Auteur, star, and bank-roll Tommy Wiseau is as interesting as the film itself and, of all the reviews that I have written on IMDB, this one is the most likely to be read by the reviewed film's director. Lacking the quirky goofiness or bloody excesses of legendary 'bad/cult' movies' (such as "Plan 9 from Outer Space" (1959), "Two Thousand Maniacs!" (1964), or "The Giant Claw" (1957)), "The Room" would have sunk into the abyss of forgotten movies if not for "The Disaster Artist". Now, the film is celebrated as a cult film in its own right and, with one film, Wiseau may have become this generation's Ed Wood. *I think, but there are more than 100 reviews of the film on IMDB that date from before the 2013 publication of Sestero's book.

review_title: As irresistibly erratic as Trump's presidency, but a lot more fun
review_detailed_main:
It's hard to imagine a released movie gone worse than this one. It's so spectacularly bad that you start to perfidly enjoy the infantile foolishness behind every scene and dialogue. Almost everything you are going to see is inexplicable and plain stupid. Once you've overcome disgust and second-hand embarrassment hard to swallow, you will take a wonderful trip through a hilarious failure, laughing all the time, shocked by the sheer power of surprise and waywardness of almost every scene you see. The director's foolishness is literally beyond belief.

It's amazing.

You wonder how some actors and staff could resist Wiseau's erratic directing, or how he himself must have been unaware of everything. Then, you think of Donald Trump's presidency and start to feel sorry for the staff around him.

You will end up wanting to know more about the movie and Tommy Wiseau, and watching that disaster a third or fourth time to make sure you didn't miss some real gem of brilliant idiocy hidden in the background or between two lines.

Best enjoyed with a couple of friends and a few light joints.

review_title: This might be the worst film I have ever seen
1 star, but not so bad it's good.
review_detailed_main: What others say is definitely true. The acting is high school level at best and the plot is more than simplistic. However I just can't stand behind those that say it's so bad it's good. It's not. It IS surprising that they managed to spend $6Mil on this tripe, but after listening to Wisaeu's forced laughter the 3rd or 4th of ~200 times it's just boring.

review_title: Worst part is i really enjoyed
Tommy Wiseau is my new Idol.

review_detailed_main: This film is harmless so I can't give it the lowest possible rating, but my god, it's stupid. If laughing at how awful something is and having fun with that is your thing, then this is your film. Otherwise, Tommy Wiseau is atrociously bad across the board here, as a writer, actor, and director. There is not a shred of artistry in what he puts up on the screen, nor any sign of talent over the film's 99 minute runtime. I'm not sure which was greater, the number of softcore sex scenes that go on too long, the number of times the guys awkwardly throw a football around, or the number of conversations between mother and daughter where they say the same things to one another. Meanwhile, there is a tinge of misogyny in its charmless story. It's kind of depressing to me that this has such a cult following as it seems like a celebration of stupidity, but I guess unintentionally funny is just not my thing.

review_title: A masterpiece of trash film making
review_detailed_main: The story of 'The Room' can honestly be inspirational. Tommy Wiseau was a nobody before this film and now we all quote his lines from this disaster. I have never reviewed such a film, a film that is filled with horrible acting, editing, lighting or special effects yet for some reason is so great. Of course the pure stupidity of this film was never intentional which is why it is so hilarious. Wiseau intended this to be a breakthrough motion picture, the film that would catapult him to the top of the food chain in Hollywood. This attitude can be seen when you watch 'The Room'. It is very easy to spot the indulgence of the film maker, he gives it his all in the film. Don't get me wrong, his performance is truly terrible but he is still trying so hard which in a lot of ways I admire. The film went through horrible production issues, many of the crew members abandoned the project and Wiseau had to find replacements. I admire that he continued and finished the picture even with everyone against him. The film offers some of the hardest laughs I have ever seen in a film, I laughed more frequent than even in some of the better comedies. This is absolutely a remarkable picture that I believe should be seen by everyone. Especially that we are now getting the behind the scenes story of this film in this year's 'The Disaster Artist'. In summary, I do not think that 'The Room' is good movie, it's the exact opposite but what makes the film so great is the fact that they were trying so hard to make a good movie. Wiseau wanted to make a thought provoking and dramatic picture, but it turned out to be a perfect example of a disastrous piece of art.

review_title: Good or bad don't matter, you create the value.

review_detailed_main:
The room is one of the best bad movies out there. Wiseau's acting is so bad, so overdone and so stupid it's amazing. The plot makes no sense and takes itself way to serious. The pacing varies from decent to atrocious yet it has a weird charm to it that keeps you engaged for the majority of the movie. I say majority because the only flaw that this movie has is it's length. It's too long, waaaaaay to long. The last 30 to 40 minutes are a drag to sit trough and you just want it to end. They could've easily done that too since there are a lot of scenes that repeat themselves or are completely pointless.

Overall i'd say it's worth checking out if you're in for some dumb entertainment that you can watch either alone or share this wonderful experience with a friend or two.

review_title: How do you rate a masterpiece?
review_detailed_main: An epic abomination on all levels that is arguably the most compelling thing ever committed to celluloid. Just jaw dropping in how bizarre and insane it is and I don't know if I should give it a 10 or a 1. Some bad movies are just boring, this is never that, it's filled with WTF moments and should be seen by all people.

review_title: The acting is so bad it's good
review_detailed_main:
I've never seen a movie so bad it's good. The acting especially the main character is so bad but so rewarding at the same time. It's as entertaining as a serious magician trying to impress you with tricks that don't work the way it was meant to work and still delivering a show.

So the movie is about a drama between a man and a woman. There is pretty much no plot but it involves cheating and a lot of sexual scenes. Also there is a lot of confusion and hilarity involved between other characters. This is the kind of movie you must watch as if you are reading a book "between the lines". It won't make sense but you'll be surprise to find out your own meaning to it. Certainly a cult classic.

review_title: This movie is tearing me apart!

review_detailed_main:
I just got back from holiday with my family, and as you may know unpacking two cars full of road trip equipment can get very heated and stressful. So I decided that we all needed to chill out once we had finished, and simply the room is the perfect movie for chilling out. There is nothing I can say about the room that has not already been said. I love it. I love it. I love it.

Watch it if you somehow haven't.

review_title: The movie about this movie is better
review_detailed_main:
If you're watching this without other people, you won't be pressured into pretending it's brilliantly funny and deep. It's neither. It's just bad. Watch it alone... Or without anyone that has been told it's great. You'll see.

The writer and star seems to have done a good job being mentally unstable enough that Hollywood fawns over him. Who else would they want to emulate, after all? He's perfect for them.

But seriously, don't watch this soft core shame show. Not on a dare. Not at a midnight showing. Not on your buddy's Plex. It's just not worth having to pretend you're so enlightened afterward because you "get it". Gag.

On the surface of it, The Room is yet another really bad movie about failed romance. There are plenty of them out there, I'm sure. However, what makes The Room so alluring is its creator and star, Tommy Wiseau. I am obviously not alone in this fascination, as the film has enjoyed a cult status for many years and has recently seem a mocku-docu-drama-whatever insight released with James Franco at the helm. As ridiculous as that film is, it does help shed a light on the backstory of Wiseau himself.

As perplexing and morbidly fascinating that Mr. Wiseau is, I cannot shake the feeling that this guy just got lucky. Where he (and his money) came from is still a head-scratching mystery, but casting him or The Room in any sort of light that paints it as purposefully bad, ironic or even artistic is just plain wrong (I saw the awkward character interactions of The Room compared to the works of David Lynch and whilst I drew my own similarities with the surreal or awkward moments, the directors are quite obviously leagues apart). If there was no such thing as meme culture, there would be no career for Tommy Wiseau, and he would most likely just be another dreamer who had a stab at Hollywood and then fell into obscurity.

I mean no disrespect to the man, as The Room is incredibly entertaining despite its deathly pace and repetition. I could just happily go through my entire remaining existence in this world without ever seeing this film again.

In case you didn't,this movie will explain how to execute a perfect-EXCITING EDGE OF YOUR SEAT ALL THRILLS NO FRILLS MEANINGFUL and INTELLIGENT life.....with lines like:"Hi Doggy." and "You are so sexy Lisa."
