(Oh Hai...HAhahaha..)And what would life as a man be without playing football in tuxedos...so relevant to my life :D.Tommy Wiseau shows his true talent here.After all,it's not A ROOM,it's THE ROOM...Do you know about life?Welp,watch it unfold here,professionally and with lovable characters such as Lisa,Johnny,DENNY Of course,oh and that old lady too,this is sure to keep you coming back for references on how to execute a well thought out conversation with everyday peeps just like you meet in Rooms each day...YOU WILL NEVER WALK INTO ANY ROOM WITHOUT A DEEPER PHILOSOPHICAL QUESTIONING AFTER WATCHING THIS."hi doggy..." "oh hi johnny,i didn't know it was you,here you go"-"Thanks,bye"..."it was a long day-very stressful"...OH AND A GREAT soundtrack....Thanks TW ;D

review_title: So bad it's good? Not really, it's just bad.
review_detailed_main:
I totally get watching a movie with a knowing smile and one's tongue firmly in cheek as you watch this train wreck of a film get absolutely everything wrong. I understand why it has a cult following: it is almost a masterclass in film making ineptitude. But surely giving this film a rating of 10 subverts that notoriety? Whatever.

Simply put, this is a big, pile of steaming rubbish. Technically it is no better (and indeed, in many ways worse) than a cheap day time soap opera. There seems to be a lack of basic blocking, framing and focus. The acting is universally atrocious with the 'actors' blurting out lines with the same verve as first time porn performers. The script is incoherent with a multitude of incomplete story arcs, google translate dialogue and utterly insane narrative. You could forgive any of these issues if this were made and conceived by 7 year olds but the fact that this is made by actual, real grown ups makes one question our progression as a species.

I read somewhere that this cost 6 million dollars to make. I would love to see the budget breakdown because just about any film student could make this with some amateur actors and an iphone and it would be better.

So yeah, I get it: it is really, really bad. Maybe one of worst movies to ever get a release. But it's cult status does not make it a 10/10 movie.

review_title: A must see for film students
Girls Will Always Prefer the Pretty Boys
review_detailed_main:
A cult legend among the worst films ever made, "The Room" is Tommy Wiseau's love affliction to the world. With an interesting backdrop on both the man and the film the stars aligned and crashed in this sterling display of mundanity and bad acting by the lead character.

With scenic San Francisco as the background, a long haired, world weary, craggy-faced, d*****y guy making big bucks (typical) is engrossed with a homely gal and does everything for her. Problem arises when his object of affection is smitten instead by his handsome and fruity-looking best friend. And so a tale as old as time unfolds with laughter, fist fights, a gunshot and a football thrown back and forth.

What really sets this film apart and consigns it to the bottom barrel of "so bad it's good" is Tommy Wiseau's truly awful acting. With his funny accent and barely altering facial expression it's not just ham, it's the entire pig itself. To watch the scene at the end of the film where his character has a "breakdown" is a chuckle for the ages. Coupled with the amusing sex scenes and you know this is amateur hour, bad amateur hour. The film isn't bad as a whole as the acting of the other actors are competent and the script is typical. With its clear lighting (which is how films should be shot mostly; a rare credit to Wiseau for that!) and odd combo of awkward acting and flat dialogues the film is a throwback to '80s-'90s soft porn flicks with their glitzy backgrounds and Razzie-inducing performances.

A film much ballyhooed for being considered more bad than it actually is, "The Room" has since it's gravity-proving release been celebrated in film, books, reunions, spoofs, games and what have you elevating Wiseau to cult stardom which he's milked for all its worth. For some laughs and to be witness to one of the strangest individuals one can come across onscreen, this is a room with a view.
God forgive me for wasting the time I spent watching this Only entertaining because it's funny how bad it is

I would never have learned about this movie, had not it been for James and Dave Franco's "The Disaster Artist" (which remains among my favorite movies). And tonight, this movie received a celebratory theatrical showing, as today marks 20 years since it opened (roughly 4 months before I was born), and I went to see it at my local theater.

The film tells the story of Johnny (played by Tommy Wiseau), a successful banker, who's a month out from marrying his girlfriend, Lisa (Juliette Danielle). However, Lisa is unsatisfied with everything he gives her, so she starts sleeping with Johnny's best friend, Mark (Greg Sestero), behind his back. She also gets Johnny drunk, and then starts lying to everybody that Johnny hit her. From there, it's clear that nothing will ever be the same for Johnny again.

The film's lack of quality is made instantly clear by the visuals alone; specifically, the ugly and garish sets, the awful, unnatural lighting (this movie was shot on 35mm and HD digital video at the same time), the awful camera angles, the heavy use of incredibly unnecessary establishing shots of San Francisco, and the shocking amount of blurry, unfocused shots. The editing is incredibly messy, and there are loads of continuity errors. Furthermore, most of the characters' costumes are gaudy and ugly. Johnny's signature outfit, especially, is a visual cacophony. But visuals aren't everything, of course. In addition, the sound editing and mixing is horrible, bordering on incompetent. The movie is loaded with bad ADR jobs that sometimes don't even sync up with the characters' mouth movements (Johnny's especially), and seem to have had no noise reduction used on them at all aside from Johnny's (sometimes you can hear hissing when a character speaks!).

The acting in this movie may be some of the worst acting I've ever seen, especially from Tommy Wiseau, the writer, director, producer and star of this movie, as well as Greg Sestero, who plays Mark. As Wiseau's incredibly weird accent makes it instantly clear as Johnny, English is not his first language, hence the bizarre and often juvenile dialogue, especially from Johnny. The script is also pretty repetitive, with almost everybody saying, "Oh, hi", or "Don't worry about it", in literally every scene. There's also story threads that come and go, especially the infamous bit of Lisa's mother, Claudette (Carolyn Minnott), revealing that she has breast cancer (and jarringly calmly at that), which is forgotten about within two seconds.

Also, the characters are not only all unlikeable, they are very bizarrely written. For instance, Johnny laughs fondly upon hearing a story from Mark about how a girl he knew got beaten up for having more than one guy, and ended up in a "hospital on Guerrero Street". Lisa's motivation for cheating on Johnny also changes every two scenes or so. As for Peter the psychologist (Kyle Vogt), who disappears two thirds of the way through the movie, he's totally inconsistent, with his opinions on Lisa changing depending on what the scene calls for.

And to cap it all off, there's the music. Mladen Milicevic's score for this movie is completely overwrought, messy, and never seems to match the tone of any scene, dragging the bad sound design down even further. And let's not forget the truly awful R&B/pop songs that accompany every disgusting, unnecessary sex scene.

All this comes together to form a movie so laughably horrible, that it ends up being incredible. All by itself, this movie is terrible in every single way, which is why I give it a 1. But I watched it tonight in a movie theater with my parents, and several other people, and it was ultimately a VERY fun experience. I recommend it to any theatergoer, because it's enjoyable when you're laughing along with other people!!! Otherwise, if you're watching it at home, you're just wasting your time.

(Last edited: 11/13/24)

review_title: Cult film for people who have no idea of actual cult films
review_detailed_main: Why this gets the attention it does is a mystery. I can only put it down to vapid hipster culture. No different to teeny boppers rushing from one boy band to another. Dumb insects attracted to flashing lights. One hipster told another hipster who then told two. Then four etc. Suddenly a "cult classic". If you want weird and bizarre, try _The Bold and the Beautiful_ when they had their demonic possession episode series which is infinitely more entertaining than this. Hipsters are a social cancer. This is evidence.
This movie is 100% nonsense - you have to watch to know how not to make movies and how you can waste million of dollars. Like seriously - why?

review_title: How can something like this exist ?
review_detailed_main: This were the most boring 100 minutes of my life, but at the same time, the most confusing. How can something like this be made? I can't say that the other actors where acting good, but this guy.... what is wrong with him ? Is this a joke ? Was this for fun ? I guess not, cause it had 6 million dollars budget. This is the worst movie I've ever seen in my entire life and I'm glad I did cause now I know how to respect other movies.

review_title: Oh, hi movie! (Quoting Tommy Wiseau). This "movie" is so bad that it almost doesn't seem real. But, is it still worth watching?
review_detailed_main: "The Room" (2003), oh boy..... Where in the world do I begin? This "movie" has found a spot on my list of the top 10 worst films I have ever seen. Boring and confused storyline, dreadful acting, cheap special effects, dull sets/locations, and a predictable generic soundtrack. The story is actually based off a novel written by Tommy Wiseau, who is responsible for the existence of this "movie". He couldn't get the book published. Huh, I wonder why? So, he resorted to getting his novel made into this train wreck, oop, I mean, "movie". If the "film" is any indication to how the novel is laid out, then we can see why no one would help him get his book published. The story is basically a love triangle between main character Johnny, his fiancee Lisa, and friend Mark. Now at first glance, that just sounds like your typical every day love triangle plot. But I assure you, it's a lot more than that. A lot more than that! This "movie" is littered with subplots that don't add up, additional characters that contribute nothing to the story, so on and so forth. I guess Tommy Wiseau is a big Zack Snyder fan; who is the true king of unresolved subplots! If it wasn't for the unnecessary plot holes, then the story would have somewhat of an impact. Even though it's your typical love triangle story told over 1,000 times before. Another thing, just look at the "movie" poster, it looks like a poster made for a horror movie. Since when was "The Room" ever remotely classified to be a horror film?! As far as the acting goes, it's just as abysmal as the storyline. Tommy Wiseau is, by far, the worst actor in this "movie". The rest of the actors are just as bad as well, maybe Tommy Wiseau's presence just rubbed off on them? In this "movie", he plays the main character, named Johnny. But that's not all he does for this "film". He also wrote, produced, executive produced, and yes, directed this "film". Every other actor ranges from just plain bad, to lackluster. However, there are two actors who do look like they're actually trying. Greg Sestero as Mark doesn't do that bad, but he's still substandard. There is one actor who puts on a great performance, Dan Janjigian as Chris-R. He is, without question, the best actor in this "film". Ironically, he wasn't even a professional actor at that time! He never had any training to be an actor, just wrap your head around that. The person with no acting experience puts on a better performance than everyone else. Something doesn't seem right there! The special effects are just as cheap and generic as you would expect. Honestly, I've seen better effects in movies made back in the 1950's! The sets/locations are dull and boring, and you can tell that the majority of the scenes were filmed in a studio! But, the exterior scenes aren't too bad, as it's filmed in San Francisco. All of the exterior shots of the city are the true saving graces for this "movie", but even those can actually get repetitive. They somehow made California boring! How is that possible?! Finally, we have a boring and cliched soundtrack to tie this diarrhea stain together. Not only is the soundtrack lazily edited, but it's just boring. The only part of the score I remember is the opening credits theme. I'm sensing a pattern here, that some of the worst movies have the best opening sequences, in order to try and fool the audience that it's going to be a good movie. Yes, I do understand that all movies need a strong opening to give a good first impression. But they seem to always forget, the rest of the movie has to be good as well! "The Room" is truly, the epitome of how not to make a movie. It should be required viewing for film students in college, so they can learn the basics on how not to make a movie, to avoid ruining the future of cinema! There is nothing positive I can salvage from this waste of film making. I'm giving this "film" 0 out of 5 stars on my scale. If I could rate it 0 stars I would, but 1 is as low as I can go. Ignore the 1 star rating on IMDB, my true rating is 0 stars. To end my review, I'm going to just say this. I know you'll think I'm crazy, but "The Room" is seriously worth checking out, it is one of those bad movies that you have to see to believe. You will not believe your eyes, it's so bad, that it's surprisingly kind of good! It has gained a cult following, and it is popular for all the wrong reasons. If you're going to watch "The Room", I suggest watching it with someone else. Then, it'll be much more fun to laugh at! To Tommy Wiseau, the disaster artist, let me just ask you this: what in the world were you thinking? "You are tearing us apart!"

review_title: The most fun you can have with your pants on!!
review_detailed_main:
This is hands down the most fun i have ever had watching a film. The Room was recommended to me by a friend as being the worst film ever made, and even that didn't prepare me for what i witnessed. I have seen better acting from primary school kids and the production values make you really wonder why this need 6 million dollars to make. The errors in this movie are incredible and all this seems like it was made just to prove how not to make a film.

All this ends up making a movie which made me cry constantly for all 99 minutes of pure rubbish. Some of the scenes make no point, but all of the mistakes make it better. I watched this film about 20 times in 2 weeks and could watch it every day for the rest of my life.

This is hands down one of my faviroute movies, and is for everyone who watches it, if you are looking for a good movie to watch on a night in with friends this is the one. you MUST see this movie.

100/10

review_title: I can't wait to review this movie
review_detailed_main:
Actually, I don't want to talk about it.

All jokes aside, I now know why this has been named one of the worst movies of all time. I found it hilarious when people would enter a scene only to say they have to leave 2 mins into the conversation. This movie is worth the watch purely to say that you've done so, I wanted to watch it before the disaster artist for a bit more context.

Everything about this is so bad that it makes you feel as it it was almost made this poorly intentionally. I'm giving it two stars as I still somehow finished this movie despite it's lack of acting or character development.

Although this is not best movie's, but also it's not worst movie. A good idea that could be much better. It could be a masterpiece if the director and actors were another ones and script was edited by a good writer. However I like this film.

review_title: Omg! This movie is so much yes!
review_detailed_main:
When I heard about this movie I was shocked to hear it get so many bad reviews. But this movie is the BEST MOVIE EVER!

It's filled with the sad tale of a man losing everything he had, his fiancé stolen by his best friend.

Never have seen anything like it. This movie not only is good but the acting is so amazing. It's like I'm right there in the movie. It puts a twist of real life into the movie scene. Definitely two thumbs up.

All I can say is the people who believe this movie will go up in flames are wrong. This movie puts the best to shame, it makes people wonder what real acting is.

With a movie about the making of The Room coming out, I thought I'd break down and watch it. I cheated and watched it with RiffTrax, though, in case the unintentional comedy aspect failed on me.

The movie is a fascinating curio that is inept to a level that is hard to even describe. It's not just the broad strokes, like the inane story or the hanging subplots or the abysmal acting. It's also the moment to moment directorial choices. For example, in a scene involving a loan shark, Lisa gets upset and reacts with over-the-top emotion. But in the cutaways to the actor she's talking to, his emotional tone doesn't jibe and it's not clear they are working from the same script. This is pretty common in the movie.

It's not just that director/writer/star Wiseau has no concept of the language of film but that he doesn't seem to understand how people work. He's like a robot who has tried to figure out human interactions and failed abysmally. There is not a moment where anyone does anything a real person would do in the same circumstances. None of the characters make sense, none of the actions make sense. While famous bad-film-director Ed Wood seemed to understand what a movie was supposed to look like, even if he couldn't make it happen, Wiseau appears to have lived alone in a box his entire life.

Well, not quite, because one gets the impression that Wiseau is mad at someone he dated. Lisa is basically a psychopath, suggesting that Wiseau thinks women are just plain out to get him.

Would this have been funny without RiffTrax? I'm not sure. Some things, like the plentiful, tedious, *endless* sex scenes, are painful even with jokes in the background. Other times I could see where in the right mood I would laugh at the terribleness of it all.

Anyway, *with* RiffTrax it's pretty fun, although I thought they were being unfair to the actress playing Lisa, who was undeserving of the body shaming lines.

Baby face.

Oh, hai mark.

I did nahhhhtt.

YOU'RE TEAEING ME APAHT LISA!

review_title: See it, hate it, and then love it
review_detailed_main:
Terrible movies flood our screens every year. Some will make you want to demand your money back or simply tear your eyes from their sockets in a bid to end the suffering, but chances are, once it's finally over, you'll never think about it again. There are plenty of terrible bad movies, but great bad movies - those that truly stick with you - are in an incredibly short supply. There's a real art to creating something so jaw-droppingly bad, so head-scratchingly awful that you start to question your very existence. Tommy Wiseau's The Room, commonly referred to as the Citizen Kane of bad movies, has this art perfected. When the film trickled into selected theatres back in 2003, nobody could have predicted the impact it would have. Nobody, that is, apart from narcissistic writer, director, producer and star Tommy Wiseau.

Only Wiseau undoubtedly had visions of being showered with admiration and awards, even timing the film's release to qualify for the Academy Awards. Instead, The Room quickly developed a reputation as a side-show, screened regularly as part of the midnight movie circuit where audience members would shout the movie's memorable catch-phrases and hurl plastic cutlery at the screen. Wiseau has since explained that The Room was always meant to be a black comedy and never intended for it to be taken seriously, but that's about as believable as the director's claims that he was born in America. In fact, nothing about The Room is believable, from the wobbly-looking sets and wooden actors to the stilted dialogue and painfully long sex scenes. When you discover that this actually cost $6 million to make - somehow funded by Wiseau himself - you'll be wondering how the hell it ended up looking like an Australian soap opera.

Wiseau plays Johnny, a wealthy banker who seemingly possesses no character flaws. He has the appearance of a weather-beaten vampire with a head full of tar-dunked hair and a voice that resembles Christopher Walken if the King of New York actor was born in Eastern Europe and had suffered a stroke. His "future wife" Lisa (Juliette Danielle) has grown bored with Johnny and infatuated with his handsome best friend Mark (Greg Sestero). Despite pleas from her mother Claudette (Carolyn Minnott) to stay with the man who will take care of her financially, Lisa seduces Mark. After a night of drinking, Lisa falsely accuses Johnny of hitting her ("I did not hit her! I did naaaht!"). But being the optimistic, all-round great guy that he is, Johnny doesn't let this get in the way of emotionally supporting his young neighbour Denny (Philip Haldiman), the man-boy orphan who Johnny treats like a son, or to throw on a tuxedo for a game of catch with his buddies.

The Room resembles a 100-minute sitcom episode during which one or two sets are visited by a roster of minor characters that in no way resembles real life. Sub-plots, such as Denny landing himself in trouble with a gun-wielding drug dealer or Claudette's revelation that she has cancer, are introduced only to be never discussed again. Rather than exploring the characters by actually giving them something to do other than walk into a room and offer mundane advice, Wiseau would rather give us no fewer than four extended sex scenes, three of which involving the filmmaker's bare arse thrusting against Danielle's stomach. Scenes play out on rooftops and alleyways that are clearly sets with a green-screen backdrop, raising the question of why Wiseau didn't simply shoot on location. But thanks to endless establishing shots of San Francisco landmarks, we know that they're definitely not in a Los Angeles studio. It would be easy to talk about The Room for hours and not even scratch the surface of just how strange yet utterly fascinating it is. See it, hate it, and then love it. And tell your friends to do the same.

Idk how to rate this movie. It's obviously a terrible film, but so unintentionally goddamn funny that it'd feel wrong to give it anything less than a 5. I laugh every time I see the flower shop scene. "You're my favorite customer."

Review: 'The Room' is a romantic-drama film directed by Tommy Wiseau. When people think of a movie that is so bad, but still feels the need to tell other to watch it, it's this movie. If you can enjoy a film that's so bad it's good, then give this movie a watch; you won't regret it. I actually had to take breaks between the scenes because I was laughing so hard at how awful it was. The film centers on a melodramatic love triangle between amiable banker Johnny (Tommy Wiseau), his deceptive fiancée Lisa (Juliette Danielle) and his conflicted best friend Mark (Greg Sestero). Nobody in this movie is known today for other projects aside from this. Not one person in this movie was good, but Tommy Wiseau is on a whole other level of bad. Not only does his dialogue not make sense in the scenes he is in, but his facial expression and tone don't make what he is saying. What make the Room superior to all of the 'so bad it's good' films is the fact that it's a riot. You see unlike other films that have 1-2 unintentionally funny scenes and the rest is a bore the Room is a non-stop extravaganza. Literally every scene has something wrong. Overall, the fact that "The Room" has gathered such a cult following is no surprise. There is something both pathetic and a little unsettling about how Tommy Wiseau regards the cynical interests his movie has attracted for a genuine recognition of his talent. .5/5

I started watching this movie as a joke with my friends. During the movie I laughed yelled and cried. The emotions he puts you through are wild. I cried at the ending and throughout I felt his pain. After watching it I bought 4 copies, 1 for me and the rest for my friends. After it came 5 months later it came with a signed photo graph addressed to me directly! It was amazing. I hang it above my tv permanently and when I'm down I look up at him and he always makes me feel better. His story is inspirational, if you try hard you can succeed even if it's not the way you thought you would
Terrible movie but the acting is so bad that it becomes entertaining to see how low professional cinema can go

review_title: Confusingly Touching but far too Long
review_detailed_main:
After being out for more than fifteen years, and having its utterly crazy production process immortalised by The Disaster Artist book and film it's safe to say that this movie has earned its place in cinema infamy. And for good reason; there is not a single redeeming element to this film, yet I still find the film strangely endearing.

As you watch the film you'll find yourself sympathizing with the actors as opposed to the characters, even if you haven't seen or read The Disaster Artist. After seeing the performances you'll obviously start speculating about what happened, and personally I think the realization that this was made by a fellow human as a passion project is a gut punch on its own considering the reception it got.

I've seen many people rate this movie as a 10 or a 9/10 but I don't see it. The first half hour is pretty funny but after that the movie just drags on for what seems like forever. I think a lot of the reviewers have forgotten that as most of us experienced it through YouTube clips and reviews, we didn't have a full viewing, which blurred the judgement of many.
It's funny without trying to be. I get why there was a film made about this film.

This is an emotional rollercoaster with the ups and downs, and not the good kind of rollercoaster. This is the one that shakes your insides so much, it feels like your guts will fly out. Why then? Why do I want to ride it again?

My friend and I just finished this film and were left in awe. You can rate some scenes at a 7, but some of them hit you so hard you are left crying out "12 out of 10!!!" The acting is atrocious, the pacing is horrific, the unresolved subplots leave a bad taste in your mouth, the diolauge is first grade material, the writing just doesn't make sense, the choppy camera work is heretical, and the sex scenes... oh the slanderous sex scenes... the FOUR slanderous sex scenes. This movie hits every wrong you can put into a movie without missing a beat. But, I'm in love with it.

My friend and I love to critique movies. We discuss what scenes could have been changed, what stories could have been tweaked, what plot points could have been done differently, and we thought about fifty different things to move this movie from it's current rating, to at least a 6/10. After further discussion though, we would change not one thing about this movie.

Some would argue that tweaking the movie would change it from being "So bad, it's good" to just mediocre. Though I agree, I dont agree this movie is "So bad it's good". I would argue it's bad. Theres nothing good about it. It deserves to be the worst movie ever made. I felt no investment in the characters, the plot, the story, etc. Yet, I found myself invested in the characters, the plot, the story, and everything in between. I don't know what's happening.

This is not some flick that's too dramatic, thus ends up being a comedy, hence making it "So bad it's good." No! There's much more to it than that. You're drawn into the movie, you become mesmerized, it's philosophical, it's beautiful... it's magical.

I'm probabaly here, but there is only one comparison that comes to mind that us humans can ponder to existentially relate to the vibes this movie exudes. That is, the final stage of Death and Dying: Acceptance. It's ugly, it's unnatural, but we let go and find peace in the relief.

Cinima is definitely a hobby of mine, and love discussing it. As a daily user in this website for years, this was, I believe, my first review. I'm glad I saved it for this one.

Well done, Johnny. *Wipes tear* well done.

review_title: An infamously atrocious cinematic blend with bad acting, bad writing, and overall bad execution spirals into an unusual appetite of "so bad it's good"
review_detailed_main:
More often than not, when Hollywood falls into the misfortune of slapping audiences with a bottom-of-the-barrel cinematic atrocity, the final fate is it spirals into obscurity with virtually everyone forgetting about its existence within a matter of a year (maybe less). Then there is rare films such as 'The Room' that succeed at achieving the strange feat of soaking the audiences with laughter for how horrendous it is in quality. That is where Polish-born director Tommy Wiseau (or wherever on Earth he was born, who knows?) and his friend Greg Sestero come in. After a longtime struggle to sell their script to major studios, it was up to this duo to come up with their independent black comedy. The results are something initially unsurprising: a disastrous, slipshod, horribly acted slugfest that spent the following ten years growing an unusual cult status from audiences who relish in laughing at the final product for how wildly inept it is. In short, it is a rare cinematic pain- inducer that everyone is willing to withstand. So the story here follows Johnny (played by Tommy Wiseau), a San Francisco banker who is on his way to marrying his long-time girlfriend Lisa (played by Juliette Danielle). What the poor sap doesn't know however, is that Lisa has grown bored of him and decides she is not in love with him and has unexpectedly fell in love with his best friend Mark (played by Greg Sestero). Although Mark is initially reluctant, not wanting to soil his friendship with Johnny), Lisa is too persitent and pulls him into a romance that soon sends everyone's lives in a downward spiral.

This film completes the handbook of how not to make a cinematic picture: horrendous acting, despicable excuse of a script, production values that would fit best for a middle school play, and dialogue that is just flat out bad to the core. If you wondering about the story, well, that's pretty much of an eye-roller as well. But Tommy Wiseau's mysterious distortion of artistic value evokes the mystery of how one can make such an atrocity and somehow provide a oddly fresh source of laughter. Wiseau, spending the entirety phoning in a mawkish performance and delivering his lines with total lack of authenticity, puts on the show with his goofy chemistry with Juliette Danielle. But once Lisa's plan to disavow her engagement with Johnny takes action, that is when the unintentional hilarity ensues. Each scene taking a place on the rooftop with the San Francisco, tacked in sloppy green-screen effects, has moments of "so bad, it's good moments" spectacle. Nearly every other scene, however, slips into the cracks of "so inept, it's just bad". That is not even including Wiseau's braindead way to filming and editing each scene, especially in the overlong sex scenes in which we witness repeated footage of Wiseau's nude back. Secondly, how often do you go to a friend's house and find pictures of silverware in the living room? Now that is just silly. Above all, the events that transpire are too short of substance in terms of execution the point where even the unintentional hilarity factor has difficult to dig up.

The Room may indeed fit perfectly in the category one of the worst movies in cinematic history, but in its own special way. Regardless, the level of ridiculousness still falls too shallow to uphold a proper "good because it's bad" spectacle. It is more of just plain bad and not enough of funny bad, which is simply disappointing to say the least.

I love a good movie and I love a good bad movie. "The Room" isn't either of those. It's just BAD. A couple of the actors do their best with what they have to work with but it's very little. It's really hard to say what Wiseau's greatest weakness is: his acting, his writing or his directing. They're all awful. This movie must have gotten its 9 Metacritic score purely out of sympathy. I am, however, looking forward to watching "The Disaster Artist," if only to enjoy how it's possible to make a good movie about making a bad one.

One of the most infamous bad movies there are. They're still showing this in select theaters, a bit like Rocky Horror Picture Show. Not because it's in any way a good movie - it's all things conceivable, but not that - but because it's such a good movie to sit through with your friends and riff on it.

The wannabe magnum opus of its director/writer/producer/executive producer/lead actor, Tommy Wiseau, The Room is the story of Johnny (Wiseau), his fiancee, Lisa (Juliette Danielle), and his best friend, Mark (Greg Sestero). It's a story about how Lisa suddenly becomes bored of Johnny and cheats on him with Mark. And all the bizarre and bad things that happen because of it.

And when you put it like that, it actually sounds a bit boring. So just what makes this movie so fascinating, and admittedly fun, to watch? The execution. And the fact that Wiseau actually had a budget for this, but had no idea what to do with it. The sets are decent, they use professional cameras and lighting, there's even some green screen utilized. Put this is all used to film one of the most egregious student films there is. The dialogues are laughably wooden, the acting even more so, there's way too many badly filmed sex scenes, there's like a bazillion continuity errors and plot points, it's pretty clear they accidentally cut out some key scenes, and the ending is so over the top melodramatic that it's glorious.

A student film, in a nutshell. But one filmed by a man at least in his late thirties. (We actually don't know when Mr. Wiseau was born, or where. There has been speculation. The word extraterrestrial might have been mentioned.)

Watching this film is a prolonged exercise in asking the question "Why!?" and learning to cope with the fact that there are no answers. And that can be a lot of fun, in a baffling way.

Definitely worth watching. Yes, it's bad, but it'd be hard to watch this film without knowing that. And when you go in with the right expectations, you'll most probably enjoy yourself.

Best movie ever Best movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie everBest movie ever

review_title: (Probably) not the worst movie ever made, but close enough.
review_detailed_main:
I wasn't privy to the existence of this so called "cult classic" until the proliferation of YouTube reaction videos and James Franco's biography movie about it. After dozing off multiple times during its 90-minute run time, I powered through this chore with no aftertastes whatsoever. The Metacritic score pretty much sums it all up: 9 out of 100, which establishes The Room as one of the lowest scored movies ever, and I have to agree with critics this time around.

Is this movie any fun? A few chuckles admittedly, primarily from the leading actor/director/writer Tommy Wiseau's monotone acting/delivery, plus that gif-worthy line "You're tearing me apart Lisa!" Nevertheless, these moments are too inadequate to make up for long sequences of mind-numbing dialogues and confounding interactions galore in this movie. If you're bent on watching this out of curiosity, or merely to better understand James Franco's The Disaster Artist, I suggest you fast forward through it within 5 minutes so as to save your precious time.

Okay, let me ask you a question. Have you ever watched a film that is clearly awful, yet still enjoyed it? Well, that is my view on The Room. It has everything that a bad film is built up of; terrible acting, awful plot, insanely poor CGI. Yet, despite all this the movie does one thing that very few films I have ever saw can do. It makes me laugh for at least 90 of the 99 minutes. It is just one of those films that you can watch and watch and watch and it never gets old! Tommy Wiseau (the writer, director, producer, tea lady, raver and cheesy quaver)claims that the film was meant to be exactly how it is..... Aye, right Tommy! The film is funny because clearly it was meant to be serious, and it turned out to be a joke. After starring in this film, i'm surprised that any of the actors managed to get another job. To put it simply, watch this film, reflect on it and then pass on the good word... oh and don't forget to look out for the spoons and the cancer.

review_title: Unintentionally or intentionally funny and weird drama.
review_detailed_main: Everyone makes fun of this movie, some hate it, some love it. Some think it's misunderstood gem, some think it's one of the worst movies of all time. To be fair I do like the premise of this movie, but everything goes so weird, I don't even call it bad, it's just bizzare. Just to name a few interesting unexplained things: Spoon art, weird dialogues, recycled sex scenes, weird acting, the suspicious relationship between Denny and Johnny/Lisa and many many more things. I do believe this movie is worth watching, it does have some unpredicatable things and for most part it's a very funny and unique film. You should atleast respect the creator as he alone wrote/directed/procuced/starred in this movie at the same time and all was made from his own money, no support. That's a lot of effort and love put into this film.

review_title: A Perfect Example of Good for Nothing.

review_detailed_main:
That is to say, I didn't mind it once I decided to not take this film seriously- at all. The film was parodied in James Franco's Disaster Artist with good reason. It doesn't make sense, it's put together with bad cinematography and editing despite its large-ish budget.

The actors simply cannot act and are incredibly melodramatic at times and rather unexpectedly to the point that it jolts the viewing experience. There's truly not a lot of redeeming qualities in this film until you loosen your belt, recline the chair back and simply passively absorb the train wreck that is playing before you. Then you might have a laugh.

Apparently the aliens from Contact who watch our TV broadcasts and try to find ways to respond to us have been eyeing late night cable drams with "sin" or "temptation" in the title and this is what they sent back. Or else the kids from the remedial English class got their hands on a camcorder and decided to make an internet sex tape, and the aliens from Contact were watching that...

If anybody has a better explanation for how a movie like this, a movie with no conception of human behavior or interactions on any level could exist, I would love to hear it. Even the worst movie makers manage to hit a correct dramatic note every once in a while by sheer statistical accident. But here, the writing and acting manage to fail with such unerring consistency that it is almost an achievement. Words such as 'surreal' do not begin to describe the experience of watching this movie. Its sheer terribleness on every possible creative level exceeds description. If you took ninety minutes of clips from a South American soap opera, spliced them together in random order and got blind street junkies to come with dubbed dialogue, you would still have a more coherent drama. The Room is so totally bad for every moment of its running time that it becomes a master class on cinematic ineptitude. The dialogue is awful, yet the actors still manage to make it seem much worse than it is by mistiming lines and giving inappropriate responses throughout the movie. The pacing of every scene, every exchange, seems off. And despite a reported budget of $6 million (??!) everything looks cheap and hurried, like a film class project that was left to the last minute.

The story construction is so inept that almost nothing that happens pushes the story forward, and virtually none of the plot threads get resolved. In fact, most of them are mentioned once and never come up again. Early on, for example, the mother casually discloses that she has cancer, and that is all we ever hear about it. This however is the film's secret virtue. When no plot point is important or connected to anything else in the movie, the viewer is free to play connect the dots.

For instance, Johnny's announcement that he failed to get a promotion at his bank shows his underachievement in the financial world. As financiers are sometimes called 'big swinging d*cks', this could be hinting that Johnny is underachieving anatomically as well. This would explain Lisa' perpetual dissatisfaction with him. Or perhaps Lisa' attitude is actually outwardly redirected self-loathing over all of the Weight Watchers meetings she has been missing. Mark's perpetual surprise over how Lisa's undressing indicates that she wants sex and not something else could be masking his own disappointment that she wasn't handing him her clothes to put on for some cross dressing role play. Such disappointment would go far in explaining the sternness of Mark's resistance to her chubby charms. Danny's drug purchase explains his apparent disconnection from reality throughout the film. The kid is clearly on goofballs. Has the mother's cancer spread to her brain? Memory impairment might explain why she keeps having the same conversations over and over. These are all ripe food for thought, and The Room's arthritic pacing gives the viewer plenty of opportunities to toss them around like footballs thrown by guys in tuxedos.

What a scream! I could not stop laughing. A clever comedy? The most awkward sex scenes. Cringe worthy. Characters that add nothing to the story. A script that speaks straight from Tommy Wiseau's brain. It's like he is inside everybody. Confusing and delightful and cringy.

review_title: It's so bad, it's good. I don't think so.
review_detailed_main: If people said it's a masterpiece, I would be 100% disagree. This is not a deliberate attempt to make this film so confusing and awkward. The appalling quality of the film was a result of poor acting and terrible direction. Probably going to watch it again for a good laugh.

review_title: Horrible, Funny And Let's Face It: Not Much Better Than Most Would Do Either!
review_detailed_main: Tommy Wiseau is an accidentally on purpose genius. What I mean is, his movie is an accidental hit but his intentions were truer than true! He lives in his own world, with his own standards and there, in this world, Tommy Wiseau is king! Not just any king either: He is a good king; he is an admired king. His people worship him and why not? He is good to his people. He treats them respectfully. He gives them all the encouragement and friendship they require. In Wiseau Land, he has been the elected king 687,327,921 and a half times now! And while, yes, his movie is VERY indulgent and self centered, it's charming and oblivious. He really does see himself as this all-American, perfect without fault Johnny character. He wants us to perceive him this way, and I say, we should. Why the heck not? He's not hurting anyone and I think we owe him for all the quotes, memes and laughs he is providing us. Now I will admit that the movie is not for everyone. Heck, it's literally just for Mr. Wiseau---but it's noteworthy, to me, if just for the fact that someone said, "Ah dun care wha any bahdy say! Ah will make dream movie! People, they use me; they lie to me and I dun care any more---oh, hai Greg!". Tommy made his dream come true; put his stupid heart on the line and succeeded in his failure! He made a negative, a positive and that's pretty hard to do sometimes! So while it is not a great movie, it's a great example of what someone can do if they really put effort into their selves...

review_title: So bad you have to see it to appreciate it's greatness.
review_detailed_main:
The Room is an incoherent mess full of unconvincing acting and lousy writing.....And that's what make's it amazing. This film is astonishingly bad. Despite Tommy Wisseau's assertions that this film was created as a black comedy this film was actually intended to be a tragic story of betrayal. The fact that this film is as bad as it is without trying to be bad actually make's this film one big joke.

If you can enjoy a film that's so bad it's good then give this movie a watch; you won't regret it. I actually had to take breaks between the scenes because I was laughing so hard at how awful it was.

Give it a watch and enjoy this jewel of a film; you'll be spouting lines from the film in no time.

Infamous as a "so bad it's good" film, Tommy Wiseau's The Room (2003) has aged like yogurt left out in the sun. I first encountered this movie as a teenager, and it was a riot. I laughed at the iconic scenes and found it hilarious. But rewatching it for probably the fifth time as an adult, I find myself wishing for more from the cinephile community. There are so many more interesting "so bad it's good" films than The Room, and it's a bit disheartening that this one has such a strong reputation when films like Miami Connection are out there.

What gives The Room its lasting power is the bizarre, yet unforgettable presence of Johnny, played by Wiseau himself. Whenever he enters a scene, it's like a manic breath of fresh air amidst softcore porn scenes and pithy melodrama. You can even tell that some of the actors think the whole thing is ridiculous. This is especially clear in long takes, where their facial expressions shift between lines, as if they can't believe the scene they're in. I first noticed this during the infamous alleyway football scene, where the "boys" toss around a ball while barely concealing their disbelief.

Recently, a production designer mentioned that the digital backgrounds for The Batman (2022) were inspired by the rooftop skylines in The Room. I can see that-those rooftop scenes do have a certain unintentional grandeur behind them. Wiseau recently released his follow-up film, Big Shark, but this time he seems to be in on the joke, which makes for a much less interesting result.

What truly gives The Room its staying power is the sincerity behind it. Wiseau really wanted to make a good movie. It's shot on film, even though in 2003 many low-budget projects had switched to MiniDV. There's an original soundtrack, and an attempt at craft, even if it didn't work out as intended. I just hope that The Room's fandom is open to expanding their horizons because there are countless hidden gems like The Room waiting to be rediscovered and embraced by a new generation of viewers.

review_title: Everything about this is appalling, but it forms something special
review_detailed_main:
The Room is perhaps one of the most spectacular films that I have ever witnessed. I have never seen anything so inept and troubled in my life. Indeed, there is something so pathologically wrong with The Room that somehow you can't quite help but applaud it while at the same time feeling like you must take a shower. Central to the film is Tommy Wiseau; the man in charge of the production. When exploring the background surrounding the film it can be noticed that Wiseau went to extreme lengths to make certain that this film be created. He wrote it as a novel and somehow managed to raise $6 million for the production of it. In fact practically every story I hear surrounding the making of this film is hilarious.

This film is Wiseau's centrepiece, it feels as if it's his life's work. Yet, he doesn't stop at purely making it, he stars in it too. Wiseau plays the role of Johnny, an Angelic figure devoted to his "future wife" Lisa (who is perhaps one of the biggest enigmas to ever appear on the big screen). Johnny is certainly something special; without him this film would not be what it is. He is the central orb in which the rest of this tragedy collapses around. He is perhaps the most complicated character ever created; some believe he is from Croatia, Belgium, Norway, Finland and I've heard Denmark too. Whatever country he is from, he certainly isn't American as Wiseau has claimed. Heck, I still wonder whether he's even of this world. Whatever the conclusion, Johnny is perhaps one of the greatest characters to ever come into creation.

The entirety of this film is almost as if it was written by someone who had never been part of any society. The whole thing makes no sense, it's almost nihilistic in the way that it redefines the framework of rules in film. Though, it has been claimed by the staff to be deliberately terrible. This was something quickly admitted to. However, I'm not truly sure that it was intentionally this awful. I think that there was a fair bit of effort put into it, certainly by Wiseau. Whatever the belief, this film manages to do everything horribly wrong, nothing about this, not one scene was something that I thought was lucid. It is a burning trainwreck of awfulness. But amongst the rubble it leaves you amazed at the sheer level of ineptness that you have just witnessed. It leaves you with a need to watch it again. Overall, The Room is a piece of genius that only a severely mentally ill person could ever create and pull off to the level that Wiseau has.

review_title: The Room: A So-Bad-It's-Good Cult Phenomenon
review_detailed_main:
The Room, the 2003 film by Tommy Wiseau that she both directed and starred in, has carved a place in popular culture for reasons other than those it probably meant. A theatrical tale of friendship, love, and betrayal, it's often heralded as one of the greatest "so-bad-it's-good" films ever made. Instead of being emotionally compelling as its makers intended, The Room is a mad dash of absurd speech, pointless story twists, and strange acting that makes it wonderfully entertaining and unpleasant. Johnny (Wiseau), a prosperous banker, is at the heart of the narrative when he learns that his fiancée Lisa is having an affair with his best buddy Mark. The film continues, and though Johnny loves her, his world falls apart, which in itself is illogical because the characters are not given sufficient depth to make sense.

The most infamous part of the picture is Wiseau's portrayal of Johnny, a figure who has become legendary in the world of bad movies. His strange language, fake line pronunciation, and extreme mood swings have made him one of the most famous characters in film history. Wiseau also wrote the script, which is full of old-fashioned, odd, and humorous phrase twists, such as the well-known "Oh hi, Mark". These scenes have become self-sustaining and ingrained in The Room's culture because they are so unexplained and out of context.

Even with its narrative and technical problems, it is these very shortcomings that add to the enduring appeal of the film. It has become a cult classic, and people attend midnight screenings just to laugh at the utter ridiculousness of it all. In a live, interactive environment, audience members commonly quote lines, hurl plastic spoons, and celebrate the chaos that is the movie's existence. Rarely does a film's very badness elevate it to the level of cherished aberration. Despite being a celebration of all that can go wrong with filmmaking, The Room manages to turn into a celebration of all that makes movies remarkable.

review_title: A Crime Against Art, Cinema, and Viewers
review_detailed_main:
The Room is in no way a normal movie, and so I will not be attempting to give it a normal review. Instead, allow me to present, unedited, a series of social media statuses I posted while watching it in theaters.

10 minutes in and I may be off girls forever. The very concept of romance may be ruined

I think this movie was written by an alien whose entire knowledge of humanity comes from watching late night broadcasts on Lifetime.

...With dialog by a Mexican soap opera writer via bablefish.

Has anyone in this movie seen a child before?

Tommy Wiseau is clearly not human. Something this deep in the uncanny Valley must be a robot covered in human skin. And not the fresh kind.

This may be the first time an announcement that someone has cancer has produced a chorus of bad laughs.

This movie handles serious issues like lines on a checklist. The more the better, no matter how awkwardly you cram them in.

I think everyone in this movie is functionally retarded.

Oh my goodness they're playing "catch."

I think the editor just had a seizure.

Who brings a football to a wedding party?

Every conversation feels like it's cobbled together from random snippets of sound tests.

There is no reason for any of the scenes in this movie to be in this movie.

I take it back. Everyone in this movie is retarded and on laughing gas.

I have seen better fights in preschool.

And now the sound just disappeared. The main character is lying on the floor dead and the preview to another movie is playing on the speakers.

Finally, I wish to say that forcing audiences to look at Tommy Wiseau's bare ass should be considered a crime against humanity.

This film is designed to be good but ultimately falls flat on its back. The writing, acting and directing are all so sub par. You can tell there was a lot of money behind the film despite the tragic product that was made. There is a reason that James Franco made a film called "The Disaster Artist" based on the making of this totally inept film. It's because the film was truly a disaster of magnificent proportions. I speak about this film with some degree of contempt purely for the fact that money (a precious commodity) was wasted to make it. It has its moments of being funny purely because its so bad, but even those moments wear thin.

review_title: Can a film be so bad, it's good?
review_detailed_main:
This film is something else, I don't care who you are or what kind of films you watch, you will never see another film like this in your entire life.

First, let me talk about the one thing everyone who has seen this film will think about, Tommy Wiseau's acting. What can you say about it, it is without doubt the worst acting that has ever been put on screen. Not one word he says through out the entire film will make you believe a thing that is going on. Yet at the same time, it's just so damn entertaining, my favorite scene is when he is having his tantrum towards the end of the film.

The dialog in this film is also so strange it makes you think, how could a self respecting actor/actress agree to do such obvious bulls**t. But, at the same time, that is what makes it so interesting, I want to keep watching, it's hilarious.

This film actually gets points for how bad it is. God, it had me in stitches. Mr Wiseau, take a bow, you have created something so bad it was actually kind of enjoyable.

I've seen a lot of movies during my life. This isn't just a film but rather a guide for "How Not to Make a Film". Basically you watch this and then you analyze it. Then you don't do anything that they made in this movie and just like magic you have a great film.

Thanks Tommy Wiseau

review_title: A masterpiece of a bad film
review_detailed_main: This movie is trying to win a Oscar so bad but the poorly written, bad acting, and kinda slow paced kept this movie down. It's so bad that it's good type of film in my opinion just like what happen to me with Halloween Resurrection (2002) like I like that film as a bad movie and I also like this film as a bad movie too. I feel bad about just watching it on YouTube instead of buying it, maybe someday I will buy the movie. This is worth a watch with a friend to watch bad movies with.

review_title: One of the greatest films of all times...
review_detailed_main: This movie changed my life. Within the first half of the movie, it had already become my all time favorite. From the shocking plot twists, to the beautiful cinematography, this masterpiece is a wonder to behold. I am so glad this film was made known to me and would suggest it to anybody looking to have an emotional, exciting, and surprisingly fun time.

review_title: 2 stars for I don't want to see it
review_detailed_main:
I suspect this is one of a few recent movies, see my review for Rabid (2019), that, IMO, seem to have been deliberately botched, in order to appeal to a niche audience - the "it's so bad, it's good" crowd or to tick off people "I can't believe you liked that junk!" "Phony good reviews!" etc ... No thanks.

---------------------------------------------------------------- 1 Deliberately botched 2 I don't want to see it 3 I didn't finish and or FF'd through it 4 Bad 5 I don't get it 6 Good 7 Great but with a major flaw 8 Great 9 Noir with moral 10 Inspiring with moral.

This movie is on of the most beatiful thing to ever grace my vision. I find myself drawn to the complex, not at all inconsistent, characters, and the emotional and intriguing plot. Sod the haters, this is a masterpiece akin to the Godfather trilogy.

The Room is literally the Citizen Kane of bad movies. The acting is terrible and lots of subplots. But, before I watched this film, I heard somewhere on YouTube and saw the title "The Room" so I assumed it was just some crappy horror film and forgot about it. I had no idea who Tommy Wiseau was, until The Disaster Artist came out. So as you can guess, I got curious. And I watched the film. It was NOT what I thought it was. It was just so weird and odd. It's not just Tommy Wiseau who's odd, every actor in this film seems odd.

The film is about a successful banker named Johnny (Tommy Wiseau) who live happily in San Francisco with his fiancée, or "future wife" Lisa (Julliete Dannielte). Until she gets board for no reason, and cheats on him with his best friend Mark (Greg Sestro). From there on, nothing will be the same.

This is one of those films where it's so bad it's good. And I am a big fan of this movie and can't stop watching it. Tommy Wiseau himself has stated that this film was always meant to be a comedy, so I guess it was never actually meant to be taken seriously.

Now, I've talked a lot about the bad stuff, but let's talk about the good stuff.

I think the reason why people still watch this film is because it brings people together. All over the world there's midnight screenings of it and people love it and laugh together and throw footballs to each other. It's very funny and I highly recommend it.

When I watch The Room today, and don't see a funny cult classic. I see a reflection of an odd but very talented man who had a very clear vision and wanted to share it with the world. I think one thing I love about Tommy Wiseau is, he dosen't care what other people think, and I really respect him for that. So I'll end this review with a quote by Tommy Wiseau.

"You can laugh, you can cry, but please don't hurt each other" - Tommy Wiseau

Well... I just can't understand how anybody can see this movie like a masterpiece. I tried to watch it,.. really, but i just give it up. It is unwatchable. I understand comedy, I understand parody, bad movies etc.. This movie is nothing of this. This movie is nothing at all. Sorry... Don't waste hours of your life watching this movie, it is pointless. It is better if you try to finish your sudoku game ;)

Just because you have a lot of symbolism, doesn't mean that it is a good production... it just means that it can be looked into - if you can manage rewatching. The production value was just terrible. The script introduced characters abruptly and was so repetitive that the audience was throwing fits. It was not realistic, and was not committed to being absurd or surreal either. The acting was some of the worst I have seen in my life. The sex scenes were unnecessary and even comedic, drawn out, and my God, reusing footage (some called that symbolism for the love being repetitive, but I just call it lazy filmmaking. There were other ways to show that). Random 'plot points' are brought up, and never mentioned again (like 'We're expecting!'), and the sets were so amature (a dude fell at one point and the walls shook mad, there were green outlines on actors from the green screens... just make it stop). Overall, the film was a joke. It was an art house flop. Only watch it if you are at a midnight cinema, and can throw spoons and footballs at the screen. My local theatre plays it once a month so people can get drunk and yell lines at the screen. It is hilarious because it is so terrible.
Watch this as a comedy not a serious romance! If you keep this in mind you will have great laughs!

(Despite a seemingly 'positive' review, I rated the movie a 4, and for three reasons:

quoting "Tootsie": 'God forbid it lost its status as a cult failure


it's a little nod to Roger Ebert who gave four stars to what he believed were the great movies, the film is indeed bad in a great way




I heard and read so many good things about all the bad things in Tommy Wiseau's "The Room. But if it didn't really encourage me to watch it, I still checked on the 'classic' moments from Youtube and my curiosity was fully satisfied, I knew the main lines and catchphrases and I could see why the film had became such a revered (or reverse) classic, but I didn't care about watching it as much as I didn't care about "Plan 9 From Outer Space", morbid curiosity is something I lack for that matter.

If it wasn't for James Franco's release of "The Disaster Artist", an adaptation of Greg Sestero's book chronicling the apparently disastrous making of the film and how an ambitious project turned out to be the "'best worst movie ever" made, nothing would have raised my curiosity. I suspect there are many viewers who're going to watch the film before checking on Franco's. It's like a rebirth for Tommy Wiseau and a definite entrance of "The Room" as one of these movies known for the wrong reasons, but known nonetheless. The ways of Hollywood are unpredictable and many stinkers have achieved more fame than 'classics'. "The Room" is one of them. Paraphrasing a slogan from Eddie Murphy's "Boomerang": it stinks so good!

To call the film 'bad' is an understatement, you could sum up the story by saying it's about a man who loves a woman or a woman who loves a man, but they're not the same, it's also about a kid who owes money, a thug who wants it badly, a drug deal, a mother who has breast cancer, a girl who wrongfully accuses her fiancé, I mean, future husband of hitting her but he insists he did not... in fact the film is beyond the idea of 'being about something', most of these subplots have no set-ups and no resolutions whatsoever, they just happen without even having a reason to happen, it's like mixing up the idea of cooking with throwing ingredients on a saucepan and waiting for something to "happen".

There's indeed a sense of anarchic disdain to any screen writing requirement, a succession of bits as random as possible that whether it's intentional or accidental is besides the point, it's bad in a genuinely genius way. And don't get me started on the acting. The film made me believed there are three schools of acting: good acting, bad acting and "Room" acting, Tommy Wiseau is a school by himself, he recites his lines as if he had just learn them phonetically, he doesn't look straight in the eyes, his mood changes suddenly, his lines are punctuated by the weirdest laugh ever and start with "Oh, Hi!" so many times it'll certainly inspire some drinking games.

ButWiseau finds his match in all the actors who act is they've been picked like Homer Simpson when he became the monorail driver. The actors have no experience and just give enough conviction to convey the right ersatz of emotion, but the effect is all the same, it's laughable. You don't laugh because they act bad, but because you know what you're supposed to feel and you're baffled because they don't even try, and I guess that's the film's secret. Indeed, there's a sparkle lighting that movie and making it immune to sheer disdains, it's like we laugh with it but not at it, as it seems unbelievable that none would be aware of how bad it is.

"The Room" rises below the idea of great movie, it's bad but make you care about how bad it is, and not every great film becomes a classic, not every great film inspires a movie about its making, much more, there are so many movies trying to be 'great' and falling flat, it takes some guts to make a film that doesn't even try to be great and succeed gloriously.

review_title: So bad it's good? Nah, it's just bad...Oh hi, Mark!
Between the intermittent cataracts of Spoon River . . .
Just not my cup of tea
review_detailed_main: I am not a film expert nor enthusiast at all. So please don't get mad at me for my opinion. I watched this film for an assignment for my CTVA class. Although, the movies that were listed as assignments were pretty cool. The cool train stopped entirely immediately after watching this movie. I have heard about this film through Youtube shorts and Tiktok. Famously, the flower shop scene. I just did not like the film at all whatsoever and really had to force myself to finish this movie. To the point, I was doing chores and having a friend to come over to help me continue throughout this movie. I took a total of 8 breaks throughout watching because I really could not watch it in one sitting. I guess you could say the acting was below average. I do not know if the acting portion was ironically or ironically conveyed, but I did not like it as well. Every interaction that I had to see was just so weird. It was like robots talking to one another. Or like NPCs dialogue in a cutscene for a poorly made videogame. I really do not like trashing movies because I feel that I am not credible to do so. I just believe that this film is just not good. And I do not see myself recommending this to anybody in the near future or at all. I know people have different opinions and tastes about everything, so I am not gonna say this movie is just an utter failure, because it is not. It's different from other films, but I just did not have a good time while watching it.

review_title: The Room is Love The Room is Life
review_detailed_main:
The Room is by far the best movie I have ever seen in my short life. After viewing this I felt happy, angry and sad all at the same time. A fusillade of emotions is what Mr Wiseau delivers you, all on a platter of 'Oh Hi' and that angels laugh that he so luckily possesses. I am honestly surprised that this film is not number 1 on IMDb, it should be an everyone should rate it 10 stars out of 10. It is a rare cinematic gem that is so enjoyable, no matter what you were expecting, no matter what you know about the plot it is the most enjoyable and heart-warming hour and forty minutes you will ever spend in your life. That's a promise.

The Room is Love, The Room is Life.

The Room is Love, The Room is Life.

review_title: Not that bad, after what I've been told...
review_detailed_main: It's a low budget movie, alright. The scripting and acting are a little bit cheesy at times but overall is a decent movie within the genre.
Yet unintentionally and through the Disaster Artist ends up being very watchable and funny

This is easily the worst 'thing' that I've ever sat through. Me and 7 of my friends were having a movie night yesterday and my friend Stephen brought this with him, claiming "I don't know what this is and apparently no one on the planet does so we should watch it." There was me, Stephan, Mason and Shane who are all male and Anna, Katie, Zoe and Gina who are female (I'm saying this just so I can establish and go into more detail about one of our reactions later) and all of us had different reactions to what we were seeing. Me, Mason Anna and Katie were looking on in confusion throughout the whole thing, Stephen and Shane were laughing uncontrollably, Gina was offended and Zoe fell asleep.

There was just so much stuff wrong in this thing that I repeatedly asked the question "why was this made? What possessed Tommy Wiseau to make this? Did he intentionally make this bad? Did he make this to settle debt? Did he actually think he could become a memorable film director?" I can only answer one of those questions, he became a memorable film director/producer/writer/actor but for the wrong reasons.

Where do I start? The acting is some of the worst caught on camera. I was in an amateur theatre production by Queen's hall arts called Minor's Strike and I would like to emphasise, it was an amateur production and all of our acting was praised in the performance and I was 13 at the time. These actors, who are around their 30s/40s are acting worse than we did and we were amateurs and hadn't taken acting school at the time. Tommy Wiseau is easily the worst though. He is the worst actor and this film and what goes well with a bad actor you might ask? Badly written dialogue for this bad actor to spout out.

"We have a new client at the bank we make a lot of money, anyway how is your sex life" This is an actual piece of dialogue that was delivered by Tommy Wiseau, imagine that an 8 year old French boy is saying this line and you will get Tommy Wiseau's whole performance.

There are also these really uncomfortable sex scene moments which is what Gina was offended by. I know that we're in an age where the ESRB raters are awfully sceptical about letting certain age demographics watch certain movies and usually controversy is applauded by audience and that's why Harvester and Hatred got as much attention as they did but this thing in The Room, these sex scenes which is applauded by possibly the horn word (not allowed to say it because of IMDb's rules) teenage boy demographic, these sort of scenes are just plain awkward for people to sit through. Also, there is about 5 of these uncomfortable sex scenes in this film, each lasting about 5 mins. Which means the total amount of time we spent watching some porno was just under 1/3 of the film.

There are also these really weird scenes that don't go anywhere. They happen and then that's it.

I wish there was a way that I could unsee this film and none of you get this film, even if you're curious, don' get it. I wish to never see Tommy Wiseau in anything again, if he even is in anything else and if he is, there's something wrong with this world.

review_title: You are tearing...oh you get it
review_detailed_main:
Well, it was fascinating to finally be able to see one of the most notorious bad movies of all time "The Room". I don't know how the movie got its name. I mean, I guess there is in fact a room featured, but it's no more featured than any other movie. Anyway, like most bad movies, it suffers from being dreadfully boring. Everything about this movie is so awkward it makes me hate it. I think the most annoying thing is how Johnny keeps making this "cheep cheep cheep" noise over and over, imitating a chicken. Wait, isn't that a chick?

There are literally three sex scenes in the first half hour of this movie. We do finally get the fourth one near the end. Any film with four sex scenes that isn't a porno deserves to be considered one of the worst films of all time. They're so monotonous and pointless. There's this one scene where a guy tries to kill this one guy which goes nowhere. The characters all get tuxedos so they can...play football? What? It is so dreadfully boring. We see Johnny fight this guy. It stops, but then he does it minutes later. Why is this happening? None of this means anything.

This film is dreadfully monotonous to the point where I really just wanted it to end soon but at least I was fortunate enough to download the Rifftrax version for it. It was so hilarious especially with how Disembodio wanted to talk through all the sex scenes. This was a movie that I had to have the Rifftrax audio with, because I knew it would be too horrible for me to do without it. This also ended up being featured in what many people consider to be the Nostalgia Critic's best review. Tommy Wiseau himself didn't like people mocking his movie. He shouldn't have made it so bad.

With Rifftrax, I really liked, "I hate you guy who looks like me!". Another great one was, "First, death to all patio furniture!". There was also, "I'm not feeling good today", "Why?" with the riff, "I saw my fiancée naked". I also loved, "Another underwear conversation related tragedy!". Call me immature, but I thought, "He's being a big baby" was great with the joke, "Should see him in his diaper, ow!". The money is well worth it. 1/2*

review_title: It's not the classic that Troll 2 is.
review_detailed_main: I was hoping for a movie that was so bad it's good, and I felt a little let down by this. When starting the movie I was amused to see Tommy Wiseau's name appear twenty times in the opening credits. I knew I was in for a treat as soon as Wiseau said his first line, "Hi babe". Then we got a gratuitous sex scene that lasted way to long, then we saw Lisa talking to her mother about how she doesn't love him anymore, then she cheats on Johnny with his best friend, and soon I noticed a pattern happening in the plot. Gratuitous sex scene, Lisa talks to mother, Lisa cheats with Mark, rinse and repeat. Eventually the story does go somewhere, without flagging myself for spoilers, let's just say it has an unintentionally hilarious grand finale. Although Wiseau is the most hilariously awful actor, because of the repetition of plot, and the super cynical nature of this movie I didn't like it as well as other bad movies.

review_title: You are taring me apart Liza!
review_detailed_main:
This film tore me apart, much like Liza tore apart Johnny from the room. The fact that this production was shot for 4,000,000 and that Tommy Wiseau did everything astounds me. This will forever remain one of the worst films of all time.

Tommy definitely isn't American.

He claims he is, but I don't think so. Also, the amount of ADR in the room deeply confuses me. Why? WHY? WHYYYY?????

What a story mark.

The characters in this are so poorly written, the cinematography is so bland, the lighting is so flat, the direction is so awful, the acting is so disgusting and Tommy Wiseau is so un-American that I think this should be screened in Hollywood Theatres.

Now.

"The Room" is a Comedy - Drama movie in which we follow a man's life who is a successful banker and lives happily with his fiancée in San Fransisco. After sometime she changes her behavior to him and also tries to seduce his best friend. Everything changes from that point the relationships between them won't be the same again.

I have to admit that I watched this movie knowing what is all about so, I was prepared for it. After watching I understood why this movie is considered the best worst movie of all times. The plot is very simple because there is not a plot or connection between the scenes and you have to figure out many things by yourself in order to cover all the plot holes. About the interpretations now, Tommy Wiseau who played as Johnny the successful banker was the worst by far but extremely funny on his role or maybe in his real life too, Greg Sestero who played as Mark the best friend of Johny was equally bad with him and of course Juliette Danielle who played as Lisa, Johny's fiancée was a bit better than them. It has to be mentioned that the direction which was made by Tommy Wiseau who was also the producer of it was simply hilarious because you could not understand what was going on in this movie or why is this so bad.

Finally, I have to say that "The Room" is a bad movie but if you have a bad day at work etc just watch it and I am sure you are going to laugh a lot and you feel a lot better when it finishes. Don't have high hopes or expectations from this movie and you aren't going to be let down by it, watch it and just laugh.

What can I say? I laughed. I cried. It became a part of me. I almost wish I had never seen it, so I could watch it again for the first time. If anyone thinks this bastard is not a genius (Tommy!) they are mistaken. I would probably watch anything this man put on film, or video tape, or doodled on a napkin. Don't deny us, you asshole! Make another movie!!! I beg you! :::sob::: I've seen better movies...I've MADE better movies...but there is nothing in the known universe that can make me laugh, cry, beg for mercy, or try to poke my own eyes out with a stick like THE ROOM. If you need a reason to live, just watch this thing a few times and your own life will seem quite normal by comparison. If you think you are ugly, just watch Tommy's creepy-eyed smile and lizardy skin. If you think you have no acting talent, just watch this amazing cast stink up the screen. It is an esteem builder. I loved it more than I love all the MST3K movies combined.
It's hard to know what Wiseau was thinking. Was he intending this to be the worst film in the world? Or a comedy? It's a weird insight into the mind of an enigmatic and unusual real life character.

review_title: oh hi mark....you know what they say, love is blind
review_detailed_main: What can be said about the Room that hasn't been said before, this movie is simply one of the most enjoyable cinematic experiences i've had. I bought the Room off of amazon after viewing clips on youtube. The best $10 I have ever spent, it changed my life and the lives of my friend. Since then I have hosted over 8 Room screenings at my house. My friends and I can't stop quoting it and singing the songs. We have learned so many lessons, such as how to play football in small spaces, the powers of persuasion and seduction, the art of interior decorating, and finally how to catch your cheating lover. In all honesty, this isn't the prime example of exemplary acting, writing, cinematography, directing, musical composition, or editing, but as long as you have a good group of friends, a couple of skotchkas and a great sense of humor, you will have fun watching the movie. If not, you are a chicken...cheep cheep cheep cheep cheep!

review_title: Doomed by Innexperience, Marked by Reputation

review_detailed_main: I suppose that you just have to leave your brain at the door for this nonsense. Sadly, at this most recent showing in London, we were not permitted to throw spoons (nor in theory, to call out - but, hey - good luck with that!). Anyway the somewhat unattractive "Johnny" (Tommy Wiseau) is living with pretty fiancée "Lisa" (Juliette Danielle) who decides that she'd probably rather hook up with the rather handsome "Mark" (Greg Sestero)... Will they get rumbled? Will things ever be the same again? Of course, the dialogue is abysmal, the sex scenes filmed in an out of focus fashion that we can only ever be truly thankful for, and the soundtrack is so cheesy that the whole thing just engenders audience participation on quite an unprecedented scale. This is garbage; there is no other word for it - yet it is eminently watchable (after three bottles of wine and some i/v gin). Carolyn Minnott is wonderfully earnest as mother "Claudette", too. It's amateur in just about every way, but funnily enough that might just be the reason it has achieved cult status. Aim very low, and you will still be setting your sights too high!

Haha This Film is a meme.

The only Reason to watch this is the laught of Jonny and the start of the conversations.
