review_title: As they say, Best worst movie of all time
review_detailed_main:
For some obvious reasons, this movie has earned the title of being called the ''best worst movie of all time'' and I think it is because of the fact that the storytelling was somewhat off putting. The plot revolves around a banker whos successful life unravels when his soon to be bride starts an affair with the bankers best friend.

What was the part that was off putting? Well it was the weird and bizarre dialouge deliveries as well as many unsolved plots in the movie. I was watching the movie with a friend and there were parts where we thought were awkwardly funny and kinda off beat.

Movie seems as if it has an inconsistent tone and confusing.
A shockingly bad film but through the Disaster Artist I found quite unintentionally funny. Bad writing and acting

This is the greatest worst movie ever made. it's hilariously laughable throughout. i can't believe this movie was even made. i hesitate to even call it a movie. the main guy is hysterically bad. every single thing that happens in the movie is a joke. every line is horrendous. it's worse than anything i thought possible. i love it. Hilariocity scale: 5.0 (2 viewings)

review_title: THE ROOM: A must see movie, in a group or by yourself
review_detailed_main:
After many at home viewings of THE ROOM and one particularly awesome theater experience - and by awesome I mean experiencing a movie with audience participation in a way I had never before encountered: audience participation that genuinely enhanced the experience of watching an already immensely entertaining work (and that's a rare kind of awesome). I can only conclude that THE ROOM is my personal favorite film to be experienced in a group setting, my favorite film to introduce to people, and probably just my favorite film to sit down and watch all on my lonesome.

First, what it's all about... It's a story about a man named JOHNNY who is a good person living in a world of devious people. His good intentions and simple, sweat dreams of a happy life begin to fall apart as those around him abuse his good nature; his loyalty, his giving, charitable spirit, and most painful of all his manipulation at the hands of his love Lisa. His betrayal through the sudden onset unfaithfulness of his beautiful bride to be is the driving force of the room: A good person surrounded by such undeserved pressures results in a film that is ultimately a view into the emotional and physical destruction of the character JOHNNY - an everyman, of sorts - as his friends, his lover, his job, and finally his grip on reality betray him.

It's a dark film, but with many light moments as interesting, quirky characters drift into THE ROOM and JOHNNY's life, bringing with them unique personal situations, problems, and other glimpses into young, modern urban life in America. These flashes of brightness and Americana drama serve as a backdrop to the exacerbating suffering of our Hero.

THE ROOM is a story of betrayal and loss, weaved in to a world of colorful, compelling characters. It is the saddest drama; it is the blackest comedy; it is the saddest love story. It's a lot of things, all of which you should see. Once you are 5 minutes into the film, you cannot turn away. It's a museum quality example of independent film in the United States.

And yes, I should mention something of the acting, writing, sets and such. The performances and staging are poor compared to studio films. But the experience is incomparable in any context. Go buy this movie at AMAZON, setup a THE ROOM party night and experience the work for yourself.

The dialogue is broken, the story is below average and has plot holes, and the acting is subpar. This all makes for a movie filled with memorable quotes due to how bad they are. That being said, the movie is still good for a bundle of laughs.

review_title: A Rocket RollerCoaster set for an explosion!
review_detailed_main: Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" is a truely wonderful timeless film with a large cast in miscellaneous locations. I have seen this movie three times and each time I get something new out of it. With a sharp blend of Arnold Schwarzennegger, Van Damn, and Dr. Frankenstein's monster Tommy's performance is brilliant, hilarious, powerful, and even moving at some points. The screenplay & dialogue are even better pushing the limits of seventh grade drama. Armed with a blind cinematography and tri-pod supported by a one legged dwarf the film shows real life situations in a raw and entertaining manner. All the characters are loveable and enjoyable to watch, especially Denny a lifelike teenage puppet with the sensitive heart of gold. The character "arch" goes all over the place like a rocket rollercoaster too confused to stay on the track but entertaining none the less. I loved this movie, it may sound like I am being cynical but really I am not! This is tommy's first movie and by golly it is fun (just as long as you don't take it seriously). I think that this film will definitely find an audience and a large cult following. I recommend this quirky "dark comedy" drama sitcom play movie to anyone who loves to laugh and enjoys a good time. his movie gives amateur filmmakers hope for the future. Thanks Tommy, you taught us to laugh and love again. 9 3/8 stars!

The Room has been highly criticized for several years since it's release in 2003, and has become a cult film among many film fans. The film as a whole is quite unique and lives up to it's hype of "so bad it's good". The Room features acting that is noticeably bad as the actors rarely show proper emotion as you can tell as if they don't know what it is they are doing. As well as the dialogue (consisting of "Oh hi" and "my future wife", along with others)

Watching this film as one would know it's not good makes the viewing better. There is a lot of unintentional comedy in this film coming from the characters, the situation and overall chemistry and random unneeded sex scenes. The Room is quite funny in that aspect and is funnier than many recent comedies of the last few years. Although not labeled a comedy and more so a drama, though some claim it as a dark comedy- which makes sense.

=== As a rewatch 01/20/18' the Room remains a highly entertaining and unintentionally funny film. Having revisited this film from after watching the Disaster Artist, there is much in which that film did in which we see here in the room. As have already pointed out, this film was meant to be serious but within the characters' acting and overall lines, awkward sex scenes and other bizarre happenings, this film is more content with being a dark comedy. Better on a second viewing with more content of paying attention. For another rewatch 04/28/20' and a couple years later, the Room still holds up as an unintentional dark comedy filled with bizarre scenes, dialogues and an overall aspect which makes it a unique watching experience.

As a movie, I can't give this more than 0 stars as this isn't a movie, this is a feature-length compliation of random, bizarre memes. As a collection of memes, I give this 10,000 stars. Seriously, I know this wasn't meant to be a complete comedy but this is really entertaining to watch. I recommend this to anyone who needs cheering up.
I laughed out loud all the way through it. Read the trivia as you watch it and that makes it better.

This is the second worst movie I have ever seen. It's so bad that it competes with "Troll 2".

But unlike "Troll 2" ... "The Room" is so bad it's excellent! The scenes where Tommy Wiseau appeared always made me laugh, and the lousy performances just delighted me. "The Room" is one of the worst movies I've ever seen in my life, but once I saw it, it fascinated me. Once you see this movie, you will never forget the day and year you saw "The Room."

So I watched this movie based on the hype around it.

Its a semi-sensical plot executed in a very odd way. The actors are weird. The lead character Johnny is, in my eyes, a true introvert trying out acting. He obviously acts out his lines while wishing to crawl back in the cave he would prefer.

The love scenes are awful and embarrassing. And there are a lot of them.

Moving the plot along happens while our non-sensical and under explained characters interact in the most awkward way.

I was prepared for a bad movie but at least expected it to be funny. Its was chuckle-worth in the onset while we get introduced to the weird dialogue. But after a while it gets dull.

I give it 2 stars because the production is decent and the music is wonderfully inappropriate.

review_title: I am FED UP with this world!
review_detailed_main:
Writer-producer-director Tommy Wiseau plays Johnny, an unlikely bank executive who dotes on his younger fiancee, Lisa (Juliette Danielle). But the selfish and scheming Lisa has fallen completely out of love with him after seven years, and she starts to think exclusively about number one. Now thinking that she loves Johnny's best friend Mark (Greg Sestero), she sets out to seduce him. And, despite the advice of others in their circle, she's in absolutely no rush to tell Johnny the truth.

This movie certainly became a legend in its own time, even if for all the wrong reasons. Its absolutely ridiculous (but oh so quotable) script quickly entered the public lexicon: "Oh hi Mark.", "You are TEARING ME APART, Lisa!", "Ha ha ha, what a story, Mark.", etc. The fact that this script is so cheesy is compounded by a lot of cheesy acting, as well, with Lisa's mother (Carolyn Minnott) a hoot as she tries to harangue Lisa into staying with Johnny for financial stability purposes. That said, the movie is never more amusing than when the inimitable Wiseau is on screen.

One can believe that Wiseau started this effort with serious intentions, trying to examine the importance of trust and transparency in relationships & friendships, but the silliness of the plot & dialogue just sink the whole thing. Not that that's necessarily a bad thing; people quickly came to embrace "The Room" as a modern classic in terms of "so bad they're good" movies.

A poorly-made clunker with a hilariously melodramatic music score and a couple of really bad songs, "The Room" is ideal viewing if one is in the mood for a lot of laughs and has a lot of beers at the ready. It's THAT daft.

Five out of 10.

review_title: Greatest bad movie of all time but I love it
review_detailed_main: I just watched "the disaster artist" movie that movie is about tommy wiseau and perfectly describes his character and mindset and I got really interested to watch his actual movie, then I watched "the room" I was like OMG this movie is a masterpiece, I really enjoyed watching this movie I recommend you first watch the disaster artist staring james franco and then come watch this film!

A beautiful yet tragic tale of love and betrayal. I found myself rooting for the main character Johnny. He felt like a friend. A true masterpiece. Can measure up to any Tarantino or Scorcese film. I greatly recommend this work of art to anyone. Wiseau is a wise man and a scholar, he pulled my heart strings like no other man. Wiseau's art has scarred me and changed me in ways I couldn't begin to explain. Combining his talent for screenwriting and his charming personality, he crated a film that will not only entertain you, but will also leave you being a better person. A truly unforgettable experience. 10 out of 10.

Perplexed, unresolved plot holes, coupled with exceedingly desolate acting, to the tedious tune of a mundane, out of place score, The Room is quite possibly the worst film ever made. However it could also be the most prodigious fabrication ever to grace celluloid. Is Tommy Wisseau, the star, producer, director and egocentric narcissist behind this creation, an idiot savant trolling us all, or merely a halfwit dunce who can't distinguish the difference between creating a film, and the malodorous odour that vacates his anus? Technically-speaking, this 'film' is brimming with ignominious blemishes, from nonsensical editing to a complete absence of any sort of character development. The generic plot involving a woman cheating on her partner with another man is just yet another stain on this technically-dreadful piece of film making. Yet what draws the countless numbers of cult followers, the numerous screenings worldwide and extravagant publicity surrounding The Room? Is it the captivating and perplexing appeal of the outlandish and elusive Tommy Wisseau, whose origins lay unknown to this very day? Are the fans simply entertained by how implicitly bad the film is? The reason The Room may quite possibly be the worst best film ever created, is because every single aspect of the film, subtle or not, is characterised by the poorest of film-making standards, from the movements of the characters to the situation and setting of the scenes. Mr Wisseau could not have deliberately created a film this mind numbingly awful, as that would have been near impossible. Go see this, you won't regret it.

People clearly have no knowledge of Brecht or of film's abilility to deconstruct within itself when they pan this movie. It's about work and film and the way we create false images of ourselves over and over in the interests of furthering romantic relationships, though we lie it's not that. In a real world where almost every conversation starts with 'Oh, hi {{name}}' this film dares to be honest and was destroyed by people so used to the artifice they hate honesty. This is real art, up there with Citizen Kane and 2001. In the words of Radiohead: "Well I'm ok, how are you, thanks for asking, thanks for asking". This is the necessary reply to 'Oh, hi Mark, how are you?".

review_title: So Bad it's Good doesn't carry The Room

If The Room were a comedy film it would be fantastic, however, the film was made to be a drama, and if you take it seriously, the performance of the film is horrible, the script is one of the worst ever written, the editing is terrible and the direction is horrible. However, the film has fun, and it has a lot of fun, and it is very funny, the only reason I have not evaluated this film better is the fact that it was made as drama and takes itself very seriously. I recommend everyone to see this classic Cult bad, the best of the worst, The Room.

review_title: Just when you've seen it all...
review_detailed_main:

review_title: Its Bad & Good At The Same Time
review_detailed_main: The Room, is worshiped as one of the best bad movies of all time. From the mind of actor, director, writer and producer Tommy Wiseau, it follows Johnny, a successful bank executive who lives with his fiancée, Lisa who little did he know had been seducing his friend, Mark. What makes this film awfully charming is the dialogue. The acting is awful the camerawork sucks and the direction is terrible. Lines like : "Oh hi Mark" and "You're tearing me apart Lisa" are some of the most memorable things about this so bad its good movie from 2003. If you haven't seen it yet, i recommend this movie for a bad movie night.

While watching this film, i wanted to laugh at it. i went in knowing the film is stupid in a funny way. While there is its funny moments, it falls flat. The film makes you wonder "why" things are happening. Characters walk in people's houses without permission, people don't use the phone, make dumb decisions, and the fact that the scene transition is repetitive. You'll see characters talking in one scene, then there is a random sex scene afterwards. The sex scenes really bring this movie down, they're uncomfortable to watch and you are really tempted to skip them. There are way too many sex scenes than there should be. The movie has it's funny moments, but you can watch those scenes on YouTube. Overall, my experience was awkward, confusing, and sometimes funny. I give this one a 4/10.

review_title: A movie that will tear you apart
review_detailed_main:
I've finally discovered this movie because of the release of The Disaster Artist which is about the making of this film and the fact that one of my local cinemas has screened this film for one hundred months in a row.

There are movies that are so bad that they are genuinely entertaining like the vivid and weird Samurai Cop. Other films are so bad that they are genuinely horrible and don't have anything going for them like the vapid Hobgoblins. The Room is actually a mixture of both types of bad movies. The first thirty minutes of the film were extremely hard to sit through and basically just consisted of poorly shot soft porn scenes. However, the final hour or so was so absurd with numerous strange subplots and a certain raise in tension that it kept my attention until the end.

There are a few elements that I genuinely like. First of all, the camera work isn't too bad if compared to numerous contemporary low budget flicks with shaky camera perspectives. Secondly, Juliette Danielle isn't only nice to look at but has a certain appeal as confused sociopath and careless femme fatale. Thirdly, Tommy Wiseau's acting skills, even though they are wooden, definitely have a memorable and unique touch and aren't like anything I have ever seen in my life. Fourthly, the movie's soundtrack blends in very well. I wouldn't call it great but it serves its purpose in the different scenes.

The other elements are so bad that they keep my attention. The acting skills vary from below average to bad. The dialogues are so thin, repetitive and wooden that an average elementary school student could have come up with something more intriguing. The main story could be described in three sentences but takes more than one hour and a half hours to unfold in a painfully slow development. The numerous unnecessary subplots going nowhere are cringe-worthy oddities that turn out being unintentionally memorable. The decorations and settings look cheap, fake and misplaced. The overlong sex scenes look so unreal that they are actually everything but exciting.

Among the biggest oddities are the random spoon pictures, the main character's friends making love in his living room for no apparent reason, the emotionless dialogue about breast cancer, the numerous random football scenes and the two fake scenes involving characters tripping and getting injured. My favorite part is however the scene in the flower shop with the overtly quick exchange of senseless dialogue lines. This scene alone shows everything this film is about: a random scene with an unimportant side character, weak acting skills, bland dialogues, ordinary settings and unintentionally funny improvisation.

The Room might have several purposes. It shows us how not to make a movie. It's a great party flick to watch with your friends to switch your brains off. It's a welcome distraction from your everyday lives. It's bizarre, goofy and almost surreal in its very unique style. It's a movie you won't ever forget. These are perhaps unintentional accomplishments that most serious films however fail to achieve which is why Tommy Wiseau still deserves some serious respect for his project.

Despite its numerous obvious flaws, it's a weird experience you won't forget anytime soon which is exactly why this disaster of a movie became a cult classic. The sad thing is that Tommy Wiseau put so much passion into this project that I would honestly recommend watching this movie over any exchangeable contemporary superhero sequel flooding the world's cinemas. The Room is one of those movies you should have watched once in your lifetime for all the reasons stated above. I'm sure I will watch it again with a bunch of friends after having just discovered this film on my own this week.

review_title: This brings new definition to the word "bad".

review_detailed_main:
Having achieved infamy as being one of, if not the, worst film of all time it was about time I settled down to watch this and see for myself.

The answer? It most certainly is up there.

The dialogue is perhaps the most ridiculous, nonsensical ever committed to film. In some places it just doesn't even match with what is happening on screen leaving you completely bewildered but in a state of amusement for sure. The infamous "I did not" scene will have you both roaring with laughter and shaking your head at the ludicrous nature of it all.

This film is full of bizarre & random scenes such as playing football (American) in a tuxedo, excruciating long and unrealistic sex scenes, absurd conversations with friends, nonchalantly discussing illness and that hideous out of place laugh that made me fell nervous and uncomfortable every time it sounded.

The acting is in the premiership of dreadfulness. I cannot believe that these people were paid for doing such an awful job – there is certainly hope for us all yet. Nothing is said with any passion or commitment to the project. Everything is said matter-of-factly straight from the script pages.

So is this film "so bad it's good" or "so bad it's hated"? Truth be told it's neither and is that rarity of just being plain bad. It is however definitely worth seeing to delight in its absurdity.

I'm not an expert in film or cinematic techniques (as you can undoubtedly tell from this review) but just a guy who watches a lot of films. Whilst it is true that this is an awful film in its acting, writing, production and direction, it is incredibly difficult to be too harsh for one reason; Tommy Wiseau. Here we have a man, who despite not being the most talented has achieved something most of us never will – by making this film he has followed his dream and there is something heart achingly beautiful in that most illusive of human endeavours.
This is by far the best movie I have seen in my life. I would recommend watching it!

I saw the movie in its entirety for the first time a few months ago. Last weekend I saw a special midnight screening of the movie and it was an amazing experience. The fans were not fans...They were acolytes of Tommy Wiseau and his vision. The dialogue is at most time a grammatical nightmare and the acting would make some Oscar winners cringe. The Set and special effects look like a school play. But the message. THE MESSAGE! Thesehoesaintloyal and neither are your boys. Its a movie you have to watch knowing its going to be bad. But in comparison to a Jerry Bruckheimer ego stroking this is a work of art.

review_title: A movie so bad that my Netflix DVD copy skipped a few times into the film so i returned it without warning...
review_detailed_main: The upcoming release of The Disaster Artist, about the making of this terrible movie, has increased popularity of this little known yet increasingly popular cult movie that failed big time at the box office when it opened in 2003 yet became The Rocky Horror Picture Show for the millenial generation and beyond. It has been so popular that many Youtubers have created what ifs for popular hit movies based on the room.

The Room is an interesting film. It's the kind of movie where everything that could go wrong, did go wrong. It ended up becoming a cult classic. Tommy Wiseau playing Johnny, the film's lead, delivered a performance which was awkward, over the top, and intriguing. His line delivery was impressive. This film was an absolute dread to watch but he was very talented nonetheless. The dialogue was awkward and nonsensical and it made it memorable. Scenes meant to be serious turn out hilarious due to the bizarre script and even more bizarre acting. There were some plot holes here and there as well. The supporting cast added their own brand of weirdness to the mix. Lisa brings her own strange energy and the character Denny is a whole different story. In conclusion, this film wasn't that good. It reminds me of a film I watched when I was a kid, "Fred." Both films kind of suck but they kept me interested and engaged. Overall, this film was an experience that I'll look back at fondly.

review_title: Nobody was in the Room where it happened
review_detailed_main: Oh my gosh what a terrible movie. But of course I say terrible as in how bad from any of the aspects of filmmaking. But you can have a really good time watching this still. It is so bad that it's just flat out hilarious. There are some scenes that looked like an accident happened on set and they just kept it in. There are some hilarious lines because it's all just nonsense. It's amazing that this movie got made at all. Of course it's a 1/10 if we grade it seriously. But gosh darn it it's like a 9/10 for the pure entertainment I get from how badly made this movie was. I guess Tommy really made solidified a new way of filmmaking: make it so bad that that is how people will love it and be entertained. I'd you don't know, Tommy meant for this movie to be serious. And look what we got. You're tearing me apart Tommy!

review_title: Certainly One Of The Worst Films Ever
Tommy Wiseau is a LEGEND,so is The Room
review_detailed_main: i am no exception to the fans of this movie or wiseau,who will always be remembered for this movie,even if he makes a movie like pulp fiction in the future.This movie is like a slow poison,the more you watch it the more addicted you will get to it. I suggested my friend to watch this movie and there will be blood back to back,and the effect was amazing.You can see so much similarities bwn day-lewis and wiseau,both are such method actors. This is probably the best screenplay and camera-work ever,and the performances are such which cannot be described. the only flaw with this movie is you cannot watch it in the theatre,because u'll laugh so hard that you might miss the next godly scene. Watch it at all cost.hail wiseau PS.to all the lovers of this movie also watch an Indian movie called gunda,which even tops this movie

This movie was really good it was very sexual and has lots of sex scenes but they're not that bad to watch. It was a good love movie to watch and the grandma was kind of getting on my nerves so that's how I know when actors did a great job. It was sometimes funny and uncomfortable. The Room really is like nothing else. I can't imagine what it must have been like for the initial lucky few that saw it when it was originally released, having gone in expecting a romantic drama, they got this. Nowadays though watching the Room in a Cinema is a completely different experience, a sea of people all in on the joke, it's just mesmerising. Believe me if you ever get the chance to go to a screening I highly recommend it, you won't regret it. Right from the moment Tommy first appears on the screen the film is utterly shambolic, so many weird moments, so many pointless establishing shots, dialogue that no human being has said or ever will. If this was aimed as a comedy it would be a complete dud, the unintentional laughter that comes from what was supposed to be a serious film just makes it. Wonderful.

review_title: A Shockingly Bad Yet Surprisingly Entertaining and Ironically Hilarious Piece of Cinema.
review_detailed_main:
The Room... directed by Tommy Wiseau... I don't need to say anything else about this movie. It basically speaks for itself. It's the most notorious indie-drama of the 2000s and it's production resulted in co-star Greg Sestero to write the novel 'The Disaster Artist', chronicling the making of 'The Citizen Kane of Bad Movies'. And now The Disaster Artist is getting its own movie; directed by James Franco, who will also play Tommy Wiseau in the film; additionally, Dave Franco will play Greg Sestero. And The Room actually deserves a movie based around its legacy, because this film has a cult following like no other and a warped-beyond-comprehension fandom that embraces the film's unintentional campiness. Basically, it's an ironic masterpiece that's so bad it's amazing!

The movie has dialogue that makes even the worst screen writing seem like the works of Robert Towne and Orson Welles; it's especially funny here because Wiseau actually cites Welles as a massive inspiration on his work. And... Tommy Wiseau has set such an admirably unique low-bar for indie-cinema that its effects on the indie film industry inspired lesser filmmakers to pick up their wits when making their passion projects. If Reservoir Dogs set the bar for quality and smart indie-cinema, then The Room set it for belief- suspending campiness full of WTF moments and nonsensical subplots that would inspire the likes of Birdemic, A Talking Cat and Cool Cat Saves The Kids. And The Room started this absurdity.

The Room; it's like an alien trying to figure out how character drama works without realising anything about natural human behaviour or character. And that alien would be a very 'special' one.
It really might be the worst movie ever made, but I love watching it.

The screenplay's dialogue perfectly ignores all rules: -All exposition is done through dialogue. The characters talk unrealistically explicitly.

-All subtext is revealed through the dialogue leaving nothing for us to solve for ourselves. It sounds like the character's thoughts rather than their talk.

The mom character keeps babbling about unnecessary stuff that is completely irrelevant to the story.

I cannot find any of the usual story beats in the story: There is no inciting incident, no plot point, no midpoint. The story leads to nothing. It makes no sense. It is like watching AI art.

Bla bla bla.

If an alien made a movie about Johnny, your typical american banker and his cheating good for nothing future wife Lisa, who is in the computer business and their life together in San Francisco.

It might not have talent or reason but it has a soul and not many movies have that. Worth watching.
This movie is so bad that people loved it like as comedy movie :)

review_title: I saw the sky it opened up and swallowed me
review_detailed_main: Overwhelming with drama and sparkles... Tommy confided in me.

"THE ROOM" (2003, Wiseau) is no masterpiece. It's not genius. It's not a happy accident. It is an atrociously acted, badly written film that cost the mysterious Wiseau a fortune of his own money.

You're better off watching the half an hour edit on YouTube as the full film gets boring fast.

review_title: Now now, it's not that bad
review_detailed_main:
when you're watching the movie with ...... The 'Bots!! Well, not really the 'Bots of the Satellite of Love, but with the guys of MST3K. That's right, folks!! The wonderful crew of Deep 13 are back again to show their love for this movie as they have in the past with such hits as Manos: The Hands of Fate, The Creeping Eye and other great horrible movies. The voices of Crow, Tom Servo and Mike are back again. So don't despair,watch the movie with your favey space pirates. http://www.rifftrax.com/the-room

Enjoy and please remember, Just repeat to yourself it's just a show, so you really should just relax. And one more thing, Hit the button, Frank!!!

What I can't get over is the sheer budget of this film. To be honest, I wouldn't care to watch or review if it were low budget, but actual money was put into making this very questionable movie!

The Room on the surface appears to be a comedy until you realize it's not. The acting is atrocious and the storyline and film style is tangential and unfocused. I can see why a film was made by James Franco and co essentially mocking the process this film went through to be made. I don't think Tommy Wiseau to this day realizes this! I suggest watching James Franco's portrayal and then watching The Room so you can appreciate this sheer travesty this film was.

review_title: Weird,Lame,boring movie ,definitely a waste of time .
review_detailed_main: First of all Tommy wiseau is neither a skilled scenarist nor a decent actor , you don't feel the character when he\s performing all you see is trying .generally the movie's trying to be drama but the viewers will laugh out , that's for sure. i expected lower budget but it shocked me really hard because i've seen many movies with lower budget did much better in comparison with this movie , i didn't like the sound mixing nor the soundtracks choosing , the successive scenes clearly messed up and not recognized , most of the actor crew are terrible , and the topic of the movie really confusing is it about the complexity of woman or about the cheating sociopath wife or it's about the naive sensible man! I don't recommend this movie to any person wants to save his time for good flick but if you want to get turned on then you can watch it because all they succeeded in doing here is the seducing/erotic scenes . Thank you for reading .

review_title: Movie in An Alternate Universe With Different Rules
So many unanswered questions... and I fell asleep
review_detailed_main: I just finished watching this movie and I have no words for what I just experienced. Plot points are brought up and never seen or answered at any point, you can tell Mark just never wanted to be there, and WHY ARE THERE SO MANY VOICE OVERS😂 despite all the horrible audio, the sound guys weren't even close to the main reason as to why this movie was absolute garbage stuffed in a pile of roadkill. I'm a fan of bad good movies, but I fell asleep half way through and was just praying it would be over soon. I finished the second half this morning, and I'm still just lost. I'm pretty sure I could've written a better script within the first months of learning to talk. I feel like I just donated precious time of my life to a man who wanted to show his over budget middle school movie project. Also, WHY ARE THE SEX SCENES SO LONG?!?!😂
This is a masterpiece. I will forever cherish every second i spent on watching this. Love it to its core.
I watched this movie and it's so bad!!! Maybe the worst movie I've ever seen. I rated it 5 because it's worth watching. I assure anyone who watches it that you'll laugh so much!!!
As a drama, like it was intended, this is a dumpster fire. As a comedy, it's... Slightly better. Laughed pretty good at all the bad acting and dialogue. Wouldn't watch it again but, oh hi mark.

review_title: Silly, Low Budget, and it Knows
review_detailed_main:
You probably watched this after that Vox video as I did.

The Room is a fun, low-budget film that doesn't hesitate to cover its mistakes. The movie tries to be serious but ends up as a comedy. It's a fun movie to watch with friends and is quite quotable.

1/5. Though I did have fun with this movie, I do have to be honest.

review_title: It's... certainly... a movie I watched...

review_detailed_main: I have seen this film just to see how bad it is. I know about it after watching "The Disaster Artist", which made me curious. This film is worth seeing as a joke. If you want to make fun of a film with someone you know, this movie is perfect. The acting is bad and the plot is trite. I wouldn't call it the worst movie to be made but it's good for a laugh.

I don't often say this, but I believe sometime it's important to watch the bad movies so that you can appreciate the good films even more. I had been holding out on watching The Room for a long time, but upon the release of The Disaster Artist, I felt it was the right time to divulge into the madness. And make no mistake, the film does not disappoint. This is easily one of the worst films ever made, if not the worst. But unlike many horrible films I have seen, there's a certain amount of undeniable enjoyment here. I know Tommy Wiseau has come out and said the film was purposefully comedic and should be considered a "dark comedy", but there's no way most of this film was this intentionally bad. Either way, there are so many memorably awful and funny things to come out of this. First off, unless it was just my copy of the DVD from the library, but it sure seemed like the words spoken and the timing of the characters mouth's moving were not linked up for most of the film. But that's the only major technical issue I noticed with the movie. Speaking of which, how in god's name did this film cost 6 million dollars to make? There's no action, shouldn't be any special effects, nor green screen scenes (though apparently Wiseau did actually do some of that). Why would this film cost that much? An even better question may be how the heck he came up with 6 million on his own to produce this? At any rate, The Room is one of the most fun mistakes Hollywood has ever produced. I'm already looking at YouTube constantly for these short clips from the film that make absolutely no sense to fulfill my entertainment for that particular moment. It's no wonder why James Franco was able to come up with an entire film worth of ideas and moments to make The Disaster Artist a success.

0.5/10

(.5 for the mere fact that this film is memorably atrocious)

review_title: Needs to be seen to be believed
review_detailed_main:
If I was rating on it's quality I would probably give less than 1 star , but The Room is not your average bad movie.....it's the baddest of them all.

I have returned to this movie countless times since I first watched it. It's bizarre directional choices , camera angles , flimsy dialogues , exaggerated acting are all part of it's charm. It's probably the most quotable movie you will ever watch.

I definitely recommend this movie to everyone. It must be experienced at least once in your life. You might even appreciate a lot of skills which we take for granted in any other movie.

Don't watch this movie alone but get your friends together and prepare to have a great time.

Truly the Citizen Kane of bad movies.
This has got to the best worst movie ever. Since i first watched it 6 months ago I have been obcessed. Everyone in the world should at least watch this movie once in their lifetime

review_title: The essential blueprint for "So bad, it's good"
review_detailed_main:
This is my first review for IMDb and of course, I want to review something special. Then again, how can it be special, when "The Room" has been analyzed, reviewed and thinkpieced to death already?

Music had its own "The Room" in 2016 with Corey Feldman's "Angelic 2 the Core": a work so utterly and baffingly bad yet driven by an unexplainable determination - and overconfindence - of its maker.

This is a 1/10 if there ever was one but at the same time, it will make your life richer, it will entertain you every single minute of its runtime. I don't if you could make a film this funny if you set out to do it. And it's a communal experience: You haven't really lived until you threw "Anyway, how's your sex life?" randomly into a conversation with friends, greet each other with "Oh, hi..." or reacted to something with "Hahaha, what a story!" (Unfortunately, I don't have many friends who know the film, so for now.... I did naaaaat.)

I could recount the story here but it's incoherent and irrelevant anyway. The film lives and breathes through its bad scene setting, plot holes as big as the Earth and the worst acting ever. Tommy Wiseau manages to keep his dialogue, his body language, his tone of voice and his facial expressions strictly seperate from one another. I would say it's like watching amateur theater if it wasn't so insulting to amateur theater. This is the bible of drunk/trash watching and if you like that concept in any regard, you HAVE to see this film.

The Room Is A Cult Classic For A Reason.

Tommy Wiseau's The Room is widely considered one of the most hilarious films ever made, and while it's far from a masterpiece, there's a certain charm in its chaotic, awkward energy that's hard to ignore. I love it! The plot, which revolves around a love triangle and the friendships, is melodramatic and overly simplistic, but that's part of the fun. The dialogue is only hindered by Wiseau's accent but hell, we're not all Brad Pitt!

It's the perfect movie for a movie night, offering laughs and awkward moments that bring a smile to your face. Watch this right away!

When you get a person that is totally disconnected from reality, with an unimaginably distorted view of his abilities, and combine it with the worst writing and acting, and throw in 6 million dollars, you get a movie that is so shamelessly bad that you enjoy watching it. I couldn't look away the first time I saw it. One of the reasons we love comedy or horror is that we're not the ones being laughed at or chased by a killer. This film has both, comedy of absurd with the horror of the most extreme side of the scale of terribleness. This is a must watch best worst film of all time.

review_title: Personally, I do not like it
This movie is a 10 at being a 1.
review_detailed_main:
Oh hi, Mark!

This is the best worst movie of all time. This movie is so bad that it has managed to circle back around to being enjoyable. It's a cult classic at this point, in the vein of Rocky Horror Picture Show and Firefly (albeit for very different reasons). If you watch this movie once, you might regret it. If you watch this movie twice, knowing what to expect, you will find it a completely different experience. And if you watch this movie a third time, you might develop just enough Stockholm Syndrome to see a rugged charm in it that is almost certainly not there without the projection of its audience, who by this point is firmly in on one of the largest inside jokes in movie history.

review_title: Worst movie ever...in all the best ways.
Stands Outside of Time, Space and Good Taste
review_detailed_main:
The Room is a film directed, written, produced, starring and likely catered by fame-seeker and wannabe cultural icon Tommy Wiseau. Johnny (Wiseau) our Dramamine swilling protagonist is a seemingly perfect human being who lives in San Francisco with his fiancée Lisa (Danielle). He exercises regularly running and playing catch with neighborhood urchin Denny (Haldiman). He also goes to his job to do business stuff. One day, Lisa wakes up realizing she no longer loves Johnny and seduces his best friend Mark (Sestero). All of the couple's mutual friends think Lisa's actions are despicable while Lisa's mother (Minnott) believes Johnny is the key to Lisa's financial security and she shouldn't call off the wedding. That is about as much plot as you can gleam out of this impossibly contrived film which aims for the melodrama of Dallas (1978-1991) but ends up feeling like a two act play written by second graders.

The Room is considered one of the worst movies ever made which, after a very brief first life in theaters, has become a midnight screening staple and so- bad-it's-good classic to eye-rolling hipsters and giddy schlock fans. Boasting inept direction, screen writing, cinematography, lighting, acting, special-effects, editing, et al., The Room is essentially a master course of what NOT to do when it comes to film-making. Yet despite the film's almost willful ignorance to straightforward storytelling, the film has an appeal that defies logic. Like watching the hypnotic gaze of an esurient asp, The Room puts you in a trance and forces you to sit through the entire f***ing thing; from it's softcore porn bedroom scenes to it's woman hating living room scenes.

I had the pleasure of sitting through this movie among the right crowd and found myself laughing often and hard. The film's artless bubbling; every moment of amateurishness was done in just about the worst way possible allowing the audience to become flabbergasted by it all. Wiseau has said that his biggest influences for The Room were films like Rebel Without a Cause (1955), and the collective works of Elizabeth Taylor, Tennessee Williams and Alfred Hitchcock. In reality the film is more an ugly-looking amalgam of everything an Eastern European immigrant would assume appeals to an American audience including extended moments of alley way football.

One would need to watch this affront to celluloid countless times before they can truly discover how a movie like this could be so popular among certain crowds. Perhaps one place to start looking would be Wiseau's absolutely appalling performance as Johnny. Unlike the other "actors" that flood the screen, Wiseau doesn't just approach the script with amateurish drudgery. His idiosyncratic delivery, clumsy blocking and confusing chatter reaches new heights in gleeful, over-the-top nuttiness. It feels as if Wiseau was sent from another planet to make a movie as a test to see if they can assimilate. If in the years to come it's discovered there's been a They Live (1988) meets The X-Files (1993-present) season 9 type conspiracy, one would only need to see The Room to discover where it all started.

The Room stands outside of time and space and certainly outside of the history of cinema. It's a movie that defies logic; a movie that proves quite entertaining if given the right circumstances but if slightly less overwrought would have been completely forgotten. Wiseau has appeared at many viewings of the film and bolsters his inflated ego as a purposeful disaster artist who revels in sardonic satire. I personally don't believe him for a minute. The frantic, neurotic emotional core of The Room is arguably the only thing about the film that felt genuine. That and two characters' uncomfortable obsession with chocolate. Seriously guys, get a room.

If anything, a lot of the reviews here understate what woefully piss-poor trashola this film is. It is an abject and aggressive failure on every conceivable level: costumes, score, acting, script, editing. And yet you must see it! Tommy Wiseau, the director, is a finger-painter who thought he was creating the Mona Lisa and accidentally drew the world's funniest and most wildly popular picture of a willy.

At the end of the day, you have to rate any creative endeavour based on how well it achieves its intended goals and that's why, with a very heavy heart, I must award The Room one solitary star. This star is awarded for the act of existing, and I present it out of sheer charity. If enjoyment could only be derived from an appraisal of technical skill, the only thing worse than this train crash of a film would be watching it on a crashing train.

But if you were to rate the experience of this movie it would get ten stars. Easy. The Room is unintentionally one hundred of the most riotously fun minutes out there and will propel you full-force into a state of hilarious insanity.

Yes, of course I've seen this film before. This review is kind of just for the books, because I've decided to write my cult film essay on it, so I had to rewatch it.

And you probably already know what I'm going to say, including, but not limited to:

The acting is pants throughout, from everyone, nearly all the time, but especially the auteur himself, Tommy Wiseau.

You could cut out something like two thirds of what passes for this film's "narrative" to no effect, because it is casually dropping new plot points and characters that go nowhere and are never heard from again right up until the final scene.

It's so poorly directed that I wouldn't be surprised at all if 95% of Tommy's directing was him saying "okay, now big emotions! Very good, hahahaha", followed shortly by "Action!", and there are absolutely zero interesting shots, unless you count the times that the camera was out of focus.

The soundtrack is godawful, sounding straight out of a 1980s straight to video porn, or maybe a 2000s straight to television romcom. Either or.

The dialogue is...perfect.

The sets are janky, never feel like what they're supposed to be, and feel like they'd fall apart if someone sneezed near them.

The characters all act like what a seven year old who somehow knows exactly what things like sex, cancer, and psychiatry are thinks grown up life is like.

And the pacing is as slow as a wheelchair on a gravel beach, mostly because of the aforementioned narrative being mostly comprised of characters being introduced and then forgotten about for long enough before the ending to make this feature length.

And I absolutely adore it. Seriously, this is one of those films you have to see to believe. If you haven't, don't look up anything else about it. Just go watch it now, because I promise at the very least it will make you feel...something.

For me, it soothed the fears I sometimes have of wondering whether I'm too nice/harsh on other films, because when I think about it, a lot of films, even if I think they're bad, do get a lot of things right, or at least competent. I don't tend to mention things like sets or pacing, but that's because a huge amount of films get those things right, so much so that sometimes I feel like I take it for granted. It takes a film this stupendously inept to remind me that if a film does get those things right, that's at least worthy of a little bit of praise.

And on the other side of the coin, sometimes when I worry I'm being too nice for a film for having, say, characters that are at least consistent, even if I don't like them, I can think back on a film like The Room to remind myself that, no, that is in fact worth a little bit of credit.

And sometimes when I worry that I should be getting on with other work because deadlines are on their way, I can think back on everything I've written here so far and stop dragging this review out.
